column3: The 20 best People Analytics articles: Sept & Oct 2017
column5:
[

It’s been an even more difficult task than usual for me to select the 20 best articles on people analytics and the future of work for September and October.

,

As I have seen for myself over the past two months when speaking at conferences in Berlin, Philadelphia, Moscow, London, Las Vegas and most recently at HR Tech World in Amsterdam (see Key Takeaways), the interest levels in people analytics continue to rise.

,

Whilst HR as a whole is still struggling to get to grips with analytics, there is growing recognition that i) demand for analytical insights from the business is high, ii) analytics is central to the digital transformation of HR, and iii) analytics is a core requirement for organisations looking to develop personalised consumer-like technologies for employees.

,

As usual Josh Bersin captures the mood perfectly in his blog to preview the publication of Deloitte’s HR Technology Disruptions for 2018, by writing:

,

That seems a good point to kick off the countdown, which starts rather aptly with…

,

Josh Bersin has been writing about people analytics for longer than most so it is refreshing that in this article he shares his belief that “people analytics has grown up.” Josh cites the exploding market of Organisational Network Analysis (ONA) as part of a shift in focus from employee engagement to employee productivity and performance. Naturally, these are the topics that CEOs and business leaders really care about. This means that people analytics is now “business critical, mandatory and must be supported well.” Look out for Bersin by Deloitte’s High-Impact People Analytics research, which has been led by Madhura Chakrabarti and which will be published in the coming weeks.

,

See Josh Bersin's recent presentation of the trends disrupting the HR Technology market and the consequent move to the mainstream of HR for people analytics

,

In this must-watch video, Prasad Setty asserts that research trumps best practice when it comes to making work better for employees. Unfortunately, as Prasad describes, the vast majority of HR programs simply replicate practices from other organisations. Given that each organisation has a different culture and what employees are looking for is also different, is it any surprise that many of these programs fail? Prasad provides examples of the research his people analytics team have conducted (see Figure 1) to help Googlers make better decisions in areas such as onboarding (by proactively seeking feedback), saving for retirement and diet. These examples all follow the principles of behavioural economics in terms of framing different choices, and all draw on the philosophies habitually used in consumer marketing.

,

Figure 1: Examples of people analytics projects at Google (Source: Prasad Setty, re:Work by Google)

,


,

Along with Jonathan Ferrar, Nigel Guenole and Sheri Feinzig this year published The Power of People book, which has rapidly become the Bible of people analytics. In this article, Nigel and Sheri adopt a mildly provocative stance and offer five generalisable ‘truths’ (see Figure 2 below) about workforce analytics based on their research and experience. The article has already prompted some lively debate, so it will be interesting to see how this continues to develop.

,

Figure 2: 5 Truths about Workforce Analytics (Source: Nigel Guenole & Sheri Feinzig, inspired in part by the findings of their HR Analytics Readiness white paper

,


,

I always enjoy Morten Kamp Andersen’s insightful (but alas these days all too infrequent) articles on evidence-based HR. His most recent effort is one of his best. There are two aspects of the article I’d like to highlight. First, as Morten says, “the purpose of evidence-based HR is not to find ‘the Right Answer’ – we are dealing with people after all. The purpose is to use all available evidence (research, internal data, analysis, experience, interviews etc.) to find the solution with the highest probability of adding the most value to your organisation.” This is our best hope of mitigating the bias and prejudice inherent to varying degrees in all of us. Morten then goes on to describe an approach (see Figure 3), which emphasises the importance of starting with the business challenge rather than getting lost in the data.

,

Figure 3: The HR Value Chain (Source: Morten Kamp Andersen)

,


,

My summary of the East Coast edition of the People Analytics & Future of Work (PAFOW) conference features insights from the likes of Al Adamsen, Arun Chidambaram, Ian O’Keefe, Geetanjali Gamel, Jonathan Ferrar, Guru Sethupathy, Rebecca White, Will Gaker, Chris Broderick, Ben Hawley and Ross Sparkman. As is typical with PAFOW events, the two days were a vibrant mix of education, inspiration and exploration as speakers, delegates and sponsors sought to share and collaborate to push the envelope on what could be possible with people analytics. The early program for PAFOW San Francisco on 1-2 February 2018 is up here and with the likes of Josh Bersin, Michael Arena, Alexis Fink, RJ Milnor, Heather Whiteman and Charlotte Nagy already confirmed as speakers it promises to raise the bar even higher.

,

Figure 4: Two of the presentations at PAFOW Philadelphia. On the left, Al Adamsen described how people analytics is evolving from a focus on employees to a broader ecosystem of work. Whilst on the right, Geetanjali Gamel spoke about some of the options for career development for people analytics professionals 

,


,

Jonathan Ferrar spoke at PAFOW about arguably the most important part of people analytics and certainly one of the biggest challenges facing practitioners – ethics and privacy. This article captures and expands upon the points Jonathan made in Philadelphia including the revelation from a recent study by Insight222 that 81% of people analytics projects (see Figure 5) are jeopardised by ethics and privacy concerns. Jonathan’s advice includes the need for people analytics leaders to work closely with their Chief Privacy Officer, publish a code of conduct, establish a governance council and above all put employee trust and transparency at the centre of what you do.

,

Figure 5: 81% of people analytics projects are jeopardised by ethics and privacy concerns (Source: Jonathan Ferrar / Insight222)

,


,

This article by Arnold Birkhoff on the Analytics in HR blog builds on the finding from the Insight222 research referenced in the preceding article. Birkhoff argues that this already high figure is set to deteriorate further if companies don’t get their act together in time of the EU’s enhanced privacy legislation –the General Data Protection Regulation, which comes into force in May 2018. Birkhoff then provides perhaps the best explanation I have read yet on GDPR from a HR context and how people analytics leaders can ready themselves and their organisations for this new legislation.

,


,

Josh Bersin’s article describes how ONA coupled with people analytics is helping firms to gain insights into what drives productivity, performance and collaboration within their businesses. This next two articles and the three presented at #18 all provide examples of ONA. First up, this piece in HBR by Ben Waber et al documents an experiment that investigated whether gender differences in behaviour drive gender differences in outcomes at one multinational organisation. The results, which combined anonymised data from emails and Humanyze sociometric badges, indicated that bias rather than differences in behaviour explained the differences in male and female promotion rates. These are not only powerful findings that demonstrate the value of people analytics, but they also highlight the fundamental challenge facing most organisations of the need to reduce bias.  

,


,

As Greg Newman highlights in this fascinating article, the Saratoga Institute advises that the average cost to business of employee turnover is 12% of pre-tax income and that for some firms this figure rises to 40%. So why, when an employee announces their intention to resign, are so many decisions on whether to retain the employee or let them go made on gut and opinion? Newman suggests that prioritising social capital data over traditional static human capital data provides a much better basis for an informed decision. He then goes on to illustrate through network analysis (see examples in Figure 6 below) how this can provide insights on the employee’s leadership potential, network size, relationship strength (internal and external) and impact as well as the network disruption that would be caused should s/he leave the organisation.

,

Figure 6: Rosalee is central to a large internal network, these are the people that she is influencing, leading, working, collaborating and innovating with (Source: Greg Newman)

,


,

As this cover article from HBR states, GE has transformed its business under the tenure of Jeff Immelt with 50% of its 300,000 employees having been with the company for less than five years. People analytics and algorithms have been central to helping this new talent assimilate and thrive with former head of people analytics and planning James Gallman explaining that the matching technology “can take a person and match him or her to something else: online or conventional educational programs, another person, or a job.” The article then goes on to outline how analytics is enabling the employee lifecycle in areas such as career development and succession, training, high potentials, retention, networking and even in supporting cultural change.    

,

______________________________________________________________________

,

Before we continue with numbers 11-20, a quick interlude. Those who tuned in last time will have seen that I featured the hiQ Labs vs. LinkedIn legal battle. At the time, the former had just won what we now know was the first battle over its right to use public data from LinkedIn (i.e. the data you and me are happy to be public) within its products that help customers predict and subsequently address employee skills gaps and flight risk.

,

Naturally I hope that the two parties, both of whom I have the utmost respect for, are able to come to a mutual agreement that suits both. However, it seems that the case will likely run and run all the way to the US Supreme Court.

,

The case has ramifications that go way beyond the world of people analytics and ultimately will define if public data on the Internet really is ‘public’ and who has the right to use and access it.

,

Moreover, the very survival of hiQ Labs is at stake as it faces a David vs. Goliath contest and crippling legal costs to continue its fight. As such, hiQ Labs has started a crowdjustice appeal to raise $100,000 towards its legal costs. If you’d like to find out more and/or contribute, please click here or on the image below. Whatever happens, I’ll continue covering the story here and how the twists and turns of the legal battle play out.  

,

______________________________________________________________________

,

This is both an honest and insightful piece by Alexis Fink, who has previously published a number of excellent articles in concert with Alec Levenson. Here, Alexis describes her realisation that there are four rather than three areas of expertise required for successful analytics projects highlighting ‘influencing’ alongside expertise in content, data and analytics. As Alexis explains as a scientist, this was tough for her to swallow, as good results should speak for themselves! Influencing means working with stakeholders to select the right projects at the outset right through to identifying actions from the insights that are feasible, effective and that will be endorsed. An invaluable read. 

,


,

This article distils the findings of a master thesis on how to bridge the gap between people analytics and decision-making, which as the authors correctly identify is a significant challenge for many practitioners. The advice offered is centred on the need for more effective collaboration between people analytics teams and HRBPs, which is illustrated below in Figure 7. The further commentary offered in the article provides in my view a sensible starting point for organisations seeking to enthuse, equip and enable their HRBPs from an analytics perspective.

,

Figure 7: Steps required to bridge the gap between analytics and decision-making (Source: Asbjørn Bloch Jensen & Marco Höpfl)

,


,

The second entry on this collection for Jonathan Ferrar, who has been somewhat of a prolific writer over the last few months. This article focuses on storytelling – a critical but often scarce skill when it comes to people analytics. Too many projects fail because they are not communicated in a way that resonates with their intended audience. Jonathan emphasises the need to tailor your message depending on the analytics expertise of your audience (see Figure 8 below), and provides a host of other invaluable tips to improve your storytelling skills.

,

Figure 8: Four essential audience categories for analytics storytelling (Source: The Power of People by Nigel Guenole, Jonathan Ferrar and Sheri Feinzig)

,


,

There has been a surge of interest in employee experience as organisations seek to apply the success of their customer experience programs to their workforce. In this piece, Laura Stevens describes the three elements she believes are required to understand, track and improve the employee experience. These are i) a continuous listening strategy, ii) cross-functional data sharing, and iii) investing in analytical skills or strategic partnerships, which are all included in Figure 9 below.

,

Figure 9: The critical components of an Employee Experience program (Source: iNostix by Deloitte)

,


,

Whilst demand from the business for workforce data and analytics is high and CHROs are increasingly supportive of this initiative, HR functions – particularly in Europe – are lagging behind. This was the headline finding of the UNLEASH / IBM Smarter Workforce Institute research I presented recently at HR Tech World in Amsterdam (see Slideshare below). A link to the white paper is provided above, along with articles by Michael Carty and me, which provide commentary on the research findings.

,


,

I expect that this article will prove to be very popular as Raja Sengupta and Sunil Meharia demystify statistics by answering 19 questions typically asked by practitioners just about to embark on their analytics journeys. As the authors opine, without grasping the fundamentals of statistics you cannot capitalise on the huge potential of people analytics. File under mandatory reading, and take a look also at Figure 10 below, which the authors use to highlight the risks associated with statistics if not applied properly. 

,

Figure 10: A rough guide to spotting bad science (Source: Compound Interest 2015)

,


,

Continuing the statistics theme, this entry is definitely one for the technically and statistically minded. The article sees three members of Shell’s rightly revered HR Analytics team (Esther, Vasileios and Linda) collaborating with academia (Paul and Zsuzsa) to make the case for two statistical methods rarely used in the HR analytics space. The paper explains the virtues of latent bathtub models (see Figure 11), and optimal matching analysis, and it is a fascinating read – even for this untrained eye!

,

Figure 11: A bathtub model of the mediating effect of employee engagement in the relationship between leadership training and team performance (Source: Wiley)

,


,

Continuing the ONA theme from earlier, these three articles describe how the technique is being used by organisations. First, Tushman et al describe how EY is analysing email and calendar data to help clients predict the likelihood of retaining key talent following an acquisition and how they can subsequently develop strategies to maximise retention. Then Aditya Hariharan’s excellent piece examines how ONA can help organisations identify and mitigate network disruption. Lastly, Philip Arkcoll focuses on how ONA can be used to improve team productivity. These are three superb articles.

,

Figure 12: Diagram comparing time spent on collaboration between team members inside a team with collaboration between the team and other parts of an organization (Source: Philip Arcoll, Worklytics)

,


,

There has been an explosion of interest in how wearable technologies and sensors can be used in the workplace with the debate centred on the need to balance ethics/privacy with employee/organisational benefit. The first three articles all touch on the possibilities and perils these technologies offer. Michael Schrage’s excellent piece focuses on how sensors can be used to measure mental health in the workplace. Next Geof Wheelwright reveals how sensory technology from SmartCap Technologies helps detect ‘microsleeps’ in truck drivers and other operators of heavy machinery. Then, Marissa Lang’s article contains an interesting view from Ben Waber that more regulation is needed in this burgeoning area. Given some of the examples of technology that Lang’s article exposes, I think he is right. Finally, Tom Cassauwers (featuring some sage views from Charles Givre, Sabina Leonelli and Jacob Metcalf) ponders whether data science needs its equivalent of the Hippocratic oath.

,


,

Finally, some analytics-themed inspiration from outside the HR realm: Francesca Gino writes on the rise of behavioural economics and its increasing influence on organisations (see earlier example from Prasad Setty on how Google’s people analytics team is applying this). Then Lori C. Bieda outlines common challenges facing many analytics teams (not just in HR) of i) demand (for analytics) outstripping supply (of analytical talent), ii) organisational immaturity, and iii) the promise of technology vs. the reality of data, and how leaders can navigate the path of disillusionment these challenges can bring. Next the McKinsey article (Richard Kelly et al) outlines seven rules manufacturers should follow with regards to IoT-enabled analytics, much of which has resonance for HR including rule #2 ‘capture the right data, not just more data’ and rule #4 ‘focus on outcomes not technology.’ Lastly, Eric Garton argues that our chronic underinvestment in people has led to our systemic problem with productivity. People analytics can help our leaders identify, measure and quantify the optimal areas of investment in human capital, so this seems like a good place to sign off until next time.

,


,


,

If podcasts are your thing then the last two months has seen a flood of excellent people data related gems. Here’s six of them. First up, my fellow co-chairs at the upcoming People Analytics Forum (book here and use DG25 for a 25% discount), Max Blumberg and Laurie Bassi bust a number of myths regarding engagement. Then Jacob Morgan services up three riveting episodes of the Future of Work podcast with Susan Steele, Cathy O’Neil and Seth Stephens-Davidowitz. Finally and returning to the topic of ONA, I joined Stela Lupushor and Antony Ebelle-Ebanda for TrustSphere’s webinar on The Role of People Analytics in ONA, and if this interests you also check out TrustSphere CEO Manish Goel’s discussion with Al Adamsen on the same subject.

,

That's all for this time...

,

______________________________________________________________________

,

,

column3: The rise of People Analytics & its impact on HR & the Future of Work
column5:
[

In a week that coincided with one analyst declaring that the global people analytics market will grow by 15% CAGR to over $1 billion by 2022, the timing of the East Coast edition of the People Analytics & Future of Work conference in Philadelphia could hardly have been better.

,

A vibrant and immersive two days provided a potent mix of education, inspiration and exploration as speakers, delegates and sponsors sought to share and collaborate to push the envelope on what could be possible with people analytics. One delegate (Simon Cockayne) captured the mood perfectly by describing the “effervescent curiosity” of all those attending.

,

Before we dive into the key takeaways, a word for Al Adamsen who surpassed even his own usual impeccable standards in the programming and facilitation of the event. People Analytics & Future of Work (PAFOW) is one of the holy trinity of conferences on the discipline along with the Wharton People Analytics Conference and Tucana’s People Analytics World and People Analytics Forum conferences. That is down to Al, who is one of the most knowledgeable and passionate people in the world when it comes to people analytics and the possibilities it offers to businesses and employees. It was an honour for me to co-chair such a fabulous event.

,

Closing the People Analytics & Future of Work conference in Philadelphia, co-Chairs Al Adamsen (R) and David Green (L) reflect on a memorable two days

,

In his opening address, Al Adamsen highlighted one of the key challenges of people analytics in striking a balance between driving better business outcomes at the same time as helping improve employee experience and wellbeing. This already delicate balancing act is further complicated as the people analytics discipline begins to expand its remit from providing insights and analysing the experience of full-time and prospective employees to the wider ecosystem of work as illustrated in Figure 1 below. This concurs with my own view that people analytics is moving from the periphery towards the centre of the future HR function. How this impacts the role of HR, and specifically people analytics teams will be a critical question over the coming years. Al also announced the creation of Insight222, which I will come back to later.

,

Figure 1: People analytics is evolving from a focus on employees to a broader ecosystem of work (Source: Al Adamsen/Insight222)

,


,

PAFOW once again highlighted the high calibre of talent in the people analytics space. The possibilities people analytics offers continues to attract new blood to the discipline such as economist Guru Sethupathy, recently appointed as Head of People Analytics at Capital One. Guru provided a refreshing and captivating talk on the diminishing half-life of skills and the consequent impact on workforce planning. The answer, according to Guru, cannot be solely provided through recruiting, although hiring for aptitude and growth mindset is likely to become increasingly more important. Guru believes, as do I, that the answer lies in raising the focus on learning – and people analytics can help immensely here by providing the foundation to programs that identify, personalise and deliver the right learning at the right time to the right individuals in an organisation. This is but one example of the broadening of the remit of people analytics that Al referred to in his opening address.

,

Figure 2: Calculating 'engaged' human capital (Source: Guru Sethupathy)

,

PAFOW Speakers (from L to R): Arun Chidambaram, Jonathan Ferrar and Ian O'Keefe

,

One sign that people analytics is maturing as a discipline is that instead of speakers providing tips on how to get started, the focus was very much on how to build sustainable capability in people analytics within organisations. This was something that a number of speakers including Ian O’Keefe (JP Morgan Chase), Ben Hawley (Unilever), Arun Chidambaram (Pfizer) and Geetanjali Gamel (Merck) spent a significant part of their presentations on. Some of their combined advice included:

,

Set a clearly defined vision and mission - to create an identity and mobilise the team, and also communicate to the business what your purpose is. See example of Merck’s as presented by Geetanjali in Figure 3 below.

,

Figure 3: Merck's mission statement for its people analytics team (Source: Geetanjali Gamel)

,

Collaborate with other analytics teams in the business – not only to augment the skills and capabilities in your own team but also to get access to additional data sources so you can combine forces to solve key business challenges facing the organisation.

,

Invest in enabling the wider HR and HRBP community – this is critical in developing sustainable capability. A number of speakers described how they had created training (classroom and social), community of practices and advocates outside the core team.

,

Don’t forget the basics – This was a point emphasised by Ben Hawley in that you will quickly lose credibility in the business if for example you provide inaccurate data on FTE. Similarly, Ian O’Keefe stressed the importance of an analytics strategy being underpinned by a measurement strategy.

,

Focus on developing your team - Arun Chidambaram struck a chord when he described how the demand for mid-career people analytics practitioners far outstrips their supply. This demonstrates the importance for organisations in defining career paths for their analytics teams. The focus of Geetanjali Gamel’s presentation was very much on this subject, and Figure 4 below illustrates some of the possible career paths for people in our discipline.

,

Figure 4: Options for career development for people analytics professionals (Source: Geetanjali Gamel)

,


,

The subject of ethics and privacy is arguably the most important part of people analytics and also its greatest challenge. This will only be exacerbated as we seek to personalise the employee experience and analyse new and emerging data sources such as wearables, biodata, email and social networks. Jonathan Ferrar presented research by Insight222, which showed that a staggering 81% of people analytics projects are jeopardised by ethics and privacy concerns (see Figure 5 below). In recommending how to tackle this, Jonathan highlighted the need to work closely with your Chief Privacy Officer and establish a governance council and code of practice. He also emphasised the need for organisations to be open with employees and clearly articulate the benefits they can expect to receive from sharing their data. This focus on transparency and trust was also the subject of Chris Broderick’s presentation where she provided compelling evidence that companies with high trust cultures not only had happier and more engaged employees, but also had better business performance too. The debate of privacy vs. trust is set to be a defining one in the years ahead and it is important that people analytics leaders and practitioners get this right. If we get it wrong, we will set the discipline back – perhaps irretrievably. 

,

Figure 5: 81% of people analytics projects are jeopardised by ethics and privacy concerns (Source: Jonathan Ferrar / Insight222)

,


,

Diversity featured highly at the Wharton People Analytics Conference also in Philadelphia earlier this year (see my key takeaways), and the topic figured prominently at PAFOW too. Will Gaker provided a hugely well-received practical playbook on how to build a diversity strategy including what data you should analyse and how to analyse it. There were many takeaways from Will’s excellent presentation, but Figure 6 captures the two that particularly resonated with me: i) companies must analyse the whole workforce to increase diversity – not just recruiting, and ii) analytics should be used to identify gaps in order that a strategy can be created to close them. Will’s former colleague at LinkedIn, Rebecca White, provided a detailed case study on how analytics has underpinned their DIBs (Diversity, Inclusion & Belonging) program. My key takeaway from LinkedIn’s story is that these programs take time – the journey has been a four-year one and has been incremental. For example, Becca explained how cognitive diversity and a focus on teams are two initiatives that have now been incorporated into the program. 

,

Figure 6: Organisations must analyse the whole talent management system to increase diversity (Source: Will Gaker)

,

PAFOW speakers (from L to R): Ben Hawley, Ross Sparkman and Geetanjali Gamel

,

The conference confirmed that people analytics has helped reinvigorate and now underpin several important disciplines within the people and HR space. Two examples are in the areas of strategic workforce planning and in organisational network analysis:

,

Strategic Workforce Planning: Ross Sparkman of Facebook provided a compelling case that you can’t have workforce planning without it being underpinned by people analytics. Indeed, Ross described people analytics as one of the four key components of workforce planning. The others being supply planning, demand planning and workforce strategy. Ross’ forthcoming book ‘Strategic Workforce Planning’ certainly promises to be a must-read. I also enjoyed Daniel Houston’s presentation where he provided an in-depth guide to how people analytics in combination with workforce planning had enabled Comcast xfinity to optimise the number and mix of full and part-time employees at their retail stores in line with customer demand and traffic.

,

What Workforce Planning is and isn't (Source: Ross Sparkman)

,

Organisational Network Analysis (ONA): For me, the growth in ONA is one of the most exciting developments in the people analytics space and one that provokes huge interest amongst practitioners (see also next two takeaways). Many examples of ONA in action were provided by speakers over the two days: Arun Chidambaram described how Pfizer is using ONA to look at areas such as innovation and leadership behaviour whilst Ben Hawley explained how Unilever had harnessed ONA to study areas such as collaboration and location strategy.

,

PAFOW Speakers (from L to R): Rebecca White, Chris Broderick and Guru Sethupathy

,

As the conference closed Al and fellow Insight222 co-founder Dirk Petersen, ran a live polling of delegates, which identified that ONA is the innovation in the space that attendees were most interested in. ONA was closely followed by employee sentiment and AI/Machine Learning (see Figure 7 below). This tallies with what I am seeing elsewhere and in my conversations with people analytics leaders around the globe. What this highlights is that the discipline is both exciting and dynamic, set to underpin the future HR function and reinforces the importance of getting the trust/privacy/ethics balance right. Finally, it also demonstrates the rising importance of people analytics. You can’t do AI in HR especially when it comes to personalising the employee experience without analytics.

,

Figure 7: The innovations in people analytics of most interest to PAFOW attendees (Source: Insight222)

,

PAFOW Speakers (from L to R): Will Gaker, Al Adamsen and Daniel Houston

,

One of the characteristics I enjoy about PAFOW is that each vendor gets to have their time in the spotlight to pitch on the business problem they are trying to solve with their product. The 15 or so vendors that showcased their products demonstrated the innovation, diversity and dynamism of the people analytics vendor space. The ones that stood out for me were: TrustSphere, Worklytics, TI People, The Chemistry Group, Visier, Virgin Pulse, Glint and Zeroedin.

,

Three of the vendors showcasing their products at PAFOW (from L to R): Manish Goel of TrustSphere, Volker Jacobs of TI People and Zack Johnson of Visier

,

As referenced earlier, Al Adamsen announced the creation of Insight222 during his opening address at PAFOW. This is an exciting and much needed development in the people analytics space. As co-founder Jonathan Ferrar explains here Insight222 is “dedicated to the professional development of People Analytics practitioners globally and the People Analytics function as a whole.” Services offered by Insight222 include:

,

You can find out more here and I for one wish my good friends and co-founders Al, Jonathan, Volker Jacobs and Dirk Petersen well.

,

Welcoming a new name to the people analytics space - Insight 222 - me with three of the co-founders (from L to R): Al Adamsen, Dirk Petersen and Jonathan Ferrar

,

At the start of the conference, Al Adamsen promised that the two days would provide a heady mix of education, inspiration and exploration. He was right and the reaction from the many delegates I spoke to confirmed that the thirst to learn, share and collaborate is immensely high in the people analytics space and augers well for the continued development of the discipline. The value of people analytics to the future HR function and business – and the change in mindset required for most organisations - was perhaps captured best by Ian O’Keefe in the final words of his superb presentation.

,

The networking is one of the features of PAFOW: Ross Sparkman (far left), Al Adamsen (far right) and me (2nd left) posing with Soumya Bonantaya

,

That seems like a perfect final takeaway. Thanks again to Al for inviting me to co-chair the conference. See you at the next PAFOW on 1-2 February in San Francisco. Check the PAFOW site for details, which will be announced shortly.

,

Finally, the best conferences put networking front and centre and that certainly applies to PAFOW. Whilst it is impossible for me to remember everyone I spoke to (blame my premature senility for that!), in addition to those already referenced in this article, I’d like to give an appreciative shout out to: Simon Cockayne, Paul Edelman, Hagan Risner, Erik van Vulpen, Nando Steenhuis, Philip Arkcoll, Patrick Riley, Soumya Bonantaya, LaShonda Rahming, John Miller, Shawn Woodring, Sheri Feinzig, Karyn Marciniak, Han Hu, Mike West, Ryan Hammond, Michael Tocci, Stela Lupushor, Mick Collins, Lara Osborne, Tom Quayle, Torrey Coriden, Jeff Seitz, Antony Ebelle-ebanda, Manish Goel, Suvarna Joshi, Charlotte Nagy, Wesley Barreto, Liz Farrelly, Andrew Jacobus, Zack Johnson, Steve Noglows, Chris Moore, Caroline Brant, Jeff Chen, Jared Barrett – the people analytics space is all the richer for your involvement. Keep up the good work.

,

Last week was an unbelievable week for people analytics events as I also attended the HR Analytics Meetup group in New York. This is a vibrant group, which has been running for a number of years, and over 100 people attended a panel discussion on the current and future state of people analytics. The panel comprised some of the most eminent practitioners in the space: Ian O’Keefe, Arun Chidambaram, Will Gaker, Jeremy Shapiro, Amit Mohindra and RJ Milnor, as well as host Nik Shah, and the fortunate attendees left with many invaluable learnings.

,

column3: The 20 best HR Analytics articles: Jul & Aug 2017
column5:
[

Summer, at least for those of us in Europe and North America, is entering its twilight and in line with Game of Thrones, winter is coming. Thankfully, the House of HR won’t have to face the Night King, his newly acquired dragon, the White Walkers and the Army of the Dead, although for those HR leaders that wait any longer to adopt analytics you never know!

,

Like the first six months of 2017, July and August saw a flood of excellent articles on people analytics and selecting the top 20 has once again proven to be a challenging task.

,

Before I start counting down the articles, I just want to highlight the superb People Analytics & The Future of Work conference, which I will be co-chairing with Al Adamsen from 20-21 September in Philadelphia. There are still some tickets available, so if you want to hear from some of the best people analytics leaders on the planet such as Ian O’Keefe (JP Morgan Chase), RJ Milnor (McKesson), Arun Chidambaram (Pfizer), Ben Hawley (Unilever), Rebecca White (LinkedIn), Ross Sparkman (Facebook), Guru Sethupathy (Capital One) and many others click on the image below to book your space.

,

On to the top 20 articles for July and August:

,

Forget Callum McGregor’s ridiculously over-hyped bout with Floyd Mayweather, the real David vs. Goliath contest this summer was hiQ Labs vs. LinkedIn/Microsoft. A brief précis: hiQ Labs is an innovative people analytics technology provider that harnesses LinkedIn public data to help customers predict and subsequently address employee skills gaps and flight risk. As the legal page on the hiQ website describes, LinkedIn sent a cease and desist notice to hiQ CEO Mark Weidick in May. The very survival of the company was at stake, so hiQ decided to fight. The case, which has ramifications way beyond the world of people analytics, really caught the attention and the ruling went in favour of the underdog. There have been a myriad of articles written since the judge announced he had come down on the side of hiQ – these are a selection. First, attorney Anne P. Mitchell provides a helpful explanation of what the ruling actually means. Then Brian Fung’s article in the Washington Post attempts to explain the motivation of LinkedIn/Microsoft and how they have pledged to fight on. Next, Matt Charney in Recruiting Daily provides his unique and satirical analysis on what the implications are for the world of recruiting. Finally, you can hear Mark Weideck himself in conversation with Joel Cheesman and Chad Sowash on their podcast. I’ve got no beef with LinkedIn – it’s a great company and I’ve met some fantastic people that work there, but I’m delighted that as things stand hiQ will survive and hopefully thrive. hiQ doesn’t just provide technology to customers they also provide a forum with hiQ Elevate and the hiQ Podcast to support the people analytics community. Keep up the good work Mark, Darren Grant Kaplan, Genevieve Graves, Darin Medeiros et al.

,

This tremendous McKinsey Quarterly article implores HR to step out of its traditional silo mentality and embrace a new mindset of explicitly using talent to drive value rather than just responding passively to the routine needs of businesses. The authors set out a four-pronged strategy (see Figure 1) that places people analytics and data driven HR front and centre. The article argues that “companies that take these steps will move toward a next generation of HR that’s data driven, not experience driven; systematic, not ad hoc; and consistent, not hit and miss.” This is a must-read for all CHROs and augers well for the continued growth and influence of analytics in HR.

,

Figure 1: The CEO agenda for the 'New HR' (Source: McKinsey)

,

Last time I featured The Power of People by Nigel Guenole, Jonathan Ferrar and Sheri Feinzig and described it as the best book written to date on people analytics. In this article on HR Zone, Jonathan draws on research from the book to outline the key ingredients required to be a successful people analytics leader. The first is that the role should report to the CHRO not least as it sends a clear message that “the CHRO is putting analytical decision making at the heart of the HR function.” Jonathan then describes how business acumen (comprising financial literacy, political astuteness and awareness of both the internal organisation and the external marketplace) is the most important skill for people analytics leader to have. The organisations that are furthest forward with people analytics have great leaders and those that aspire to emulate these companies would do well to heed the advice Jonathan offers here. You can also hear Jonathan speak at the aforementioned People Analytics & Future of Work conference in Philadelphia on 20-21 September. Find out more here.

,

One successful people analytics leader who possesses all of the attributes described by Jonathan is Dawn Klinghoffer, who leads the team at Microsoft. In this article, Dawn cleverly combines her twin passions of cooking and analytics to share some of the lessons she has learned as a people analytics leader. These include: the need to understand what is important for your business leaders, getting to the ‘why’ rather than stopping at the ‘what’ and the importance of knowing your audience when it comes to presenting insights in a way that will resonate. A perfect recipe! If you want to read more about the people analytics journey at Microsoft, please feel free to read my interview with Dawn.   

,

Like Dawn, Keith McNulty is the epitome of a successful people analytics leader. He has also emerged as one of the foremost writers on the subject and publishes a regular flow of insightful articles on LinkedIn (see here). In this article, Keith cites the advances in technology, digital and innovation as the fundamental cause of the increased hype, interest and adoption of people analytics. Keith then describes the opportunities these advances provide when it comes to understanding and analysing people: namely the enrichment of the digital exhaust, new people data to analyse and new ways to analyse people data. 

,

In my interactions with companies and people analytics leaders, I see a lot to be optimistic about the continued growth of people analytics and data driven HR. In this article for HR Zone, I describe how people analytics is moving from the periphery to the centre of the HR agenda (see Figure 2) and cite six trends that are underpinning this transformation. This includes the need to first invest in people analytics before you can do AI in HR, new work models and emerging data sources such as wearables. Analytics is a core component of the future of HR and is absolutely critical if the function is going to provide a positive impact to the business and its employees.

,

Figure 2: People Analytics moves from the periphery to the centre of the HR agenda - includes 'Workforce Analytics is the centrepiece of a digital agenda for HR' model by Volker Jacobs | TI People

,

Tracey Smith has featured in my ‘Best articles…’ series several times. Not only is she one of the leading consultants in the space, her writing is thoughtful, practical and unafraid of offering a different opinion. That is certainly the case with this article, which confronts many of the debates currently raging in the community. Should we regulate HR metrics and force companies to make this data public? Should we develop certifications for HR/People Analysts? Is it HR Analytics or People Analytics? Tracey tackles all of these questions and presents a compelling case for her positioning on all. As she rightly says, instead of wasting our time on trivial arguments, we’d be better focused on improving business and employee outcomes. Read more of Tracey’s Numerical Insights blog here.

,

One way to help the continued growth of people analytics is the publication of case studies so that HR professionals can be inspired and learn from the successes others have had and apply these to their own organisations. What makes this example of a fast food restaurant chain so instructive is i) it demonstrates the power of people analytics on frontline staff, ii) the insights derived have led to dramatic improvements in customer satisfaction, service performance, and overall business results, and iii) the analysis busted a number of myths (see Figure 3) that had pre-existed within the organisation. Finally, the case study is in-depth, well-written and also demonstrates that one way of accelerating progress in people analytics is to partner with an external party (in this case McKinsey).

,

Figure 3: Employee features correlating to the desired outcomes (Source: McKinsey)

,

Many of the organisations I’ve studied with at least some capability in people analytics tend to have focused on just one or two areas of the employee lifecycle – typically recruitment and/or retention. In this article, Mark Lawrence explores the opportunity to not only apply analytics across the employee lifecycle (see Figure 4) but also to link the insights generated together to gain a more holistic view and have additional impact. This is an excellent article for those getting started with analytics or those seeking to expand their efforts across the employee lifecycle.

,

Figure 4: The Employee Lifecycle Teardrop (Source: Mark T Lawrence)

,


,

Tucana’s People Analytics Podcast, which is expertly hosted by Max Blumberg (and occasionally by me), certainly has a knack of attracting some terrific guests and provoking some stimulating debate. The highlights of season 2 are wittily and succinctly summarised in this article by Andrew Spence. As Andrew writes, the guests collectively represent academia (John Boudreau and Alec Levenson), people analytics practitioners (Jordan Pettman, Ross Sparkman, Kevin Moore and Becky Thielen) and consultants (Bernard Marr and Laurence Collins), which provides the listener with a broad view of where the space is today and where it is heading. Speaking of Tucana, I’ll be chairing their People Analytics Forum in London on November 29-30 – click here to find out more.

,

With the digital revolution upon us, companies now seem to be in a state of perpetual transformation, which means that the importance of truly strategic workforce planning is paramount. As Alec Levenson and Alexis Fink write, this represents an excellent opportunity for people analytics leaders and teams to increase their impact on the business. Strategic workforce planning is not just about people now either as technology creates a dynamic reality for organisations (build, buy or bot). The advice and practical examples offered represent an indispensable guide for those seeking to understand how strategic workforce planning continues to evolve and its intrinsic link to people analytics.

,

Analytics in HR is a superb blog and resource for anyone working or interested in people analytics. Erik van Vulpen, one of the co-founders, has written a number of excellent articles and this recent piece tackles the subject of employee engagement. The big question Erik seeks to answer is ‘Does Engagement lead to better business performance?’ The advice and suggested methodology offered is a good guide for those seeking to demonstrate the true value of employee engagement and how people analytics can help link this to business performance.

,

Citing an infamous example from Fox News, Ridwan Ismeer writes about the difficulties and inherent risks in building employee performance models (see example in Figure 5 below). He then describes six ways to mitigate these risks including not defining performance with a single metric, being cognisant of bias and using reverse causality. An insightful read.

,

Figure 5: Two alternative views on employee performance (Source: Ridwan Ismeer)

,

We hear a lot about the need to democratise data within organisations and many commentators cite it as a trend that is helping drive growth in people analytics. For the uninitiated (or indeed those trying to convince the uninitiated of the merits of data democratisation) this excellent guide by Bernard Marr on what data democratisation actually is, the pros and cons and the technology that is helping to propel it is a must-read.

,

When I talk to people analytics leaders, the subject of organisational network analysis (ONA) is often referenced as an area where projects are either currently underway or being planned. Much of the data being used for ONA comes from email, but as Philip Arkcoll writes used alone email can provide an incomplete picture. Philip illustrates this perfectly in Figure 6, which shows six different network relationships from different tools in one organisation. 

,

Figure 6 - Diagram showing some of the many networks that exist within different tools in a single organisation (Source: Philip Arkcoll)

,


,

Continuing the ONA theme is this pair of excellent articles. First up, on the Analytics in HR blog, Richard Santos Lalleman, describes how people analytics in tandem with ONA has helped researchers determine the three percent rule (see Figure 7). This infers that if you can identify the right 3% (of key influencers) you can reach 85% of other employees. This is a critical imperative for effective change management within an organisation. In the second article, Rob Cross provides some fascinating insights around the burnout risks to top performers and how organisations can encourage these critical employees to disengage from their networks to recharge and refresh.   

,

Figure 7: The Three Per Cent Rule (Source: Richard Santos Lalleman)

,

The capability to translate people data and insights into compelling stories is paramount to getting stakeholder buy-in and having your recommendations implemented. Steffen Maier provides some tips on how this can be achieved in this article on the HRN Blog. Tips include the need to know your audience and adapting your story accordingly, the use of context and presenting actionable solutions and recommendations. Of course, HRN organises HR Tech World, the next instalment of which takes place in Amsterdam on 24 and 25 October. I'll be speaking in and moderating the Smart Data track. IBM and HRN have partnered on research exploring people analytics readiness and, crucially, attitudes towards new and emerging employee data sources. The results of the research will be revealed at HR Tech World. Take the survey here (or click on the image below) for a chance to win some free tickets to the show.

,

Click on the image above to take the survey and a chance to win some free tickets for HR Tech World in Amsterdam in October.

,

Recent research by Insight222 revealed that 65% of companies surveyed are not on track to comply with the EU’s General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR), which comes into effect in May 2018. The legislation, which is all about privacy, has some pretty serious implications for people analytics as it changes the way organisations can collect and process data about employees and job candidates. These three articles provide more information. Rand Hindi’s article distils what the legislation actually is and the potential ramifications whilst the other three articles from SHRM, People Management and Jan Tegze on Recruiting Daily focus on what HR and recruiting needs to do to get their houses in order.

,

Closely related to the GDPR and the wider importance of employee trust when it comes to people analytics is the adoption of emerging data sources such as wearables and sensors. A couple of recent articles caught my eye on this subject. First, the New York Times reports that Three Square Market, a Wisconsin tech company, has enabled employees that opt in to have a chip the size of a grain of rice injected between their thumb and index finger. Once that is done, any task involving RFID technology — swiping into the office building, paying for food in the cafeteria — can be accomplished with a wave of the hand. The second article in Bloomberg reports that Barclays has installed sensors to check when employees are at their desk. Then, David Creelman ponders whether Facebook will one day extend the technology it already has so that organisations can monitor the mood of their employees. Finally, it seems opportune to once again include Andrew Marritt's excellent article on the most important element of people analytics - employee trust, which has been resurrected on the Analytics in HR blog.

,

As I wrote last time, one of the advantages for HR in being the last major business function to adopt a data driven approach is that there is plenty to learn and be inspired by from outside the function. Three examples are provided here. First, McKinsey research provides nine insights on how business leaders are – and are not adapting – to the analytics revolution. Next, three professors from the Rotman School of Management explain that whilst the predictive capability of AI will supplant human prediction it will also complement human judgement and generate more demand for decision making. Finally, Adele Sweetwood describes the mistake many organisations make in of conflating analytics training with data adoption. As Adele explains whilst training is critical, having an adoption plan in place is even more essential. This certainly applies when it comes to creating sustainable capability and a data driven mindset in HR and tallies with the advice offered in the McKinsey study.

,

One of the characteristics I've seen in companies that do people analytics well is that they have a CHRO who not only sponsors but is involved in people analytics. I saw Leena Nair, CHRO of Unilever, speak recently at the Beyond Global HR Leadership Forum and was hugely impressed. During her speech, Leena emphasised that “we can't say the world around us is changing, but HR will keep doing what we've always done.” Her passion for staying human in a technology obsessed world is the central theme of this captivating podcast with Jacob Morgan. Leena believes that technology, AI and analytics can help us be more human through helping personalise HR services such as learning and recruitment (as Unilever has done) and consequently improve the work experience for employees. It is perhaps no coincidence that Unilever is one of the organisations furthest forward with people analytics (Leena references in the podcast the $100m+ saving Unilever has made as a result of predicting and preventing regretted attrition). The podcast is a great listen and exemplifies that Leena is one of a growing breed of 21st Century CHROs who combine data with intuition and experience to make decisions. You can listen for yourself by clicking on the image below.

,

That's all for this time...

,

,

column3: 6 reasons why People Analytics will be central to the future of HR
column5:
[

The Danish physicist and Nobel Prize winner Niels Bohr once mused, “Prediction is very difficult, especially if it’s about the future.”

,

This is partly why I have finally given up predicting at the start of each season that Liverpool will win the Premier League, and have demurred in forecasting that 2017 will be the year that people analytics will go mainstream.

,

There are many reasons why people analytics has not yet crossed the chasm and widened its adoptees beyond visionaries to pragmatists.

,

Firstly, like pretty much any business trend, growth tends to be exponential rather than linear.

,

Secondly, and perhaps more pertinently, many professionals (in particular Chief Human Resource Leaders and HR Leaders) have still not grasped what people analytics is (clue – it’s not reporting) and the potential it offers to drive better business outcomes as well as improved employee experience and wellbeing.

,

Nevertheless, there are reasons for optimism as a number of indicators suggest exponential growth is close. As such I feel safe in writing that in the next three to five years, analytics will become a core and central discipline of HR.

,

Here are six reasons why I believe that people analytics is shifting from the periphery to the centre of the HR agenda.

,

We are in the midst of the fourth industrial revolution. Digital is challenging every single business model and reshaping the way we work as well as our experiences as customers and employees.

,

Regarding the opportunity digital offers to HR, CHRO of Unilever Leena Nair said in her keynote at the recent Beyond Global HR Leadership Forum “we can't say the world around us is changing, but HR will keep doing what we've always done.”

,

This definitely applies to the need to embrace analytics; not only will the next wave of HR transformation be digital, but people analytics will be at centre of this agenda.

,

I like the model below from TI People, which illustrates how developing capability in people analytics is required to deliver initiatives to i) improve and personalise the employee experience, and ii) design new organisational structures and how work gets done.

,

column3: The 20 best HR Analytics articles: May & Jun 2017
column5:
[

Regular readers may have noted my fondness for music and pop culture analogies. Well, imagine if you could organise a concert of your favourite artists of all time. No longer being on this mortal coil is not a barrier. My selection would include (but not be limited to) the likes of Bowie, The Beatles, The Clash, The Velvet Underground, New Order, Billy Idol (yes, I know - call it a guilty pleasure) and The Stones (both of the Roses and Rolling varieties).

,

This bi-monthly collection of the best people analytics articles from May and June is in HR terms at least on a similar grand scale. Some of the global giants of HR and analytics are present – Bersin, Boudreau, Cappelli, Ulrich, Briner, Davenport and Cross. People so recognised that they are known by their surnames alone.

,

The marvellous part about it is that they are all writing about people analytics and its role in helping organisations tackle some of their biggest challenges. With interest levels soaring, the number of conferences on the subject doubling in the last 12 months and adoption levels rising, all indicators seem to be pointing in the right direction. This is despite (as some of the articles included recognise) the road being bumpy and at times treacherous for organisations growing their capabilities.

,

Collectively, the 20 articles cover pretty much everything in the world of people analytics: case studies, challenges, ethics, employee experience, the future of work, diversity and inclusion etc as well as the best book yet published on the subject (see #1). There are contributions from practitioners, analysts, academics, consultants and some of the most exciting vendors in the space.

,

On the subject of exciting vendors and before we plunge into the 20 selected articles, I’d like to first highlight the ongoing legal battle between hiQ Labs and LinkedIn (see here and here), which came to my attention over the last two days. hiQ Labs, co-founded by Darren Grant Kaplan, is one of the most impressive start-ups I’ve come across in the people analytics space and up until now has been using public LinkedIn profiles to help customers i) identify critical employees that are a flight risk, and ii) map the skillset of their workforce. The judgement will be very interesting as it essentially pits privacy rights against the freedom to public information. This one is set to run and run.

,

Now without further ado, let’s get on with the 20 articles that have made the cut for this edition:

,

If you already work or are interested in the people analytics field, you must read this book. If you are a HR leader wishing to increase the impact of your people analytics function, you must read this book. If you are a business leader who expects more from HR, you must read this book. Nigel Guenole, Jonathan Ferrar and Sheri Feinzig have written what is for me (and many others I have spoken to) the definitive book on people analytics. The Power of People has in part been informed through interviews the authors conducted with a veritable who’s who of the people analytics field encompassing practitioners, academics, analysts, HR and business executives and consultants. The results speak for themselves. To find out more check out Jonathan’s articles (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4), previewing the book and in the case of Part 3 outlining the Eight-Step Model for Purposeful Analytics (see Figure 1 below), which is described in more detail within the book.

,

Figure 1: The Eight-Step Model for Purposeful Analytics (Source: The Power of People: Sheri Feinzig, Nigel Guenole and Jonathan Ferrar [Pearson FT Press – 2017])

,

As Dana Minbaeva, Founder of the Human Capital Analytics Group at Copenhagen Business School, muses in this article despite overwhelming consensus that analytics and evidence based decision-making will be a mandatory part of the future, HR still isn’t quite there when it comes to widespread adoption. The ‘Why Aren’t We There Yet?’ question inspired Dana to edit a Special Issue of the Journal of Organizational Effectiveness, People and Performance on Human Capital Analytics. I was humbled to be asked to contribute my ‘The Best Practices to Excel at People Analytics’ article – especially as the other contributors (see list of authors above) represent some of the leading thinkers in the field. All the articles by my fellow contributors warrant inclusion in this list on their own, but it is far more generous to include them all!

,

One of the most fascinating uses of people analytics is how it is being used together with Organisational Network Analysis (ONA) to uncover insights in areas such as team effectiveness, collaboration and organisational design. A captivating example is provided in the MIT Sloan Management Review, which provides details of a ten-year study led by Rob Cross (aka Mr ONA) combining academic research and business to answer the question: How do we best connect employees in ways that more systematically unleash emergent innovation? The findings are illuminating and in brief include highlighting the importance of Adaptive Space (see Figure 2). Other highlights include a compelling case study of the work Michael Arena has led at GM, as well as a description of the three key roles within a network (Brokers, Central Connectors and Energisers). A terrific read with plenty to learn and be inspired by.

,

Figure 2: Adaptive Space - the network and organisational context that allows people, ideas, information, and resources to flow across the organisation and spur successful emergent innovation - Source: MIT Sloan Management Review  

,

One must-read study follows another. In this example, Dave Ulrich and the RBL Institute conducted research to assess the impact of competence in HR Analytics on three outcomes: i) personal effectiveness, ii) stakeholder value, and iii) business performance. The results weren’t those that those of us in the people analytics field would have hoped for, with the impact on business performance being fairly modest. Ulrich also notes his surprise at the findings, but offers suggestions on how to transform analytics into a sustainable and value-added HR practice. First, he confirms that analytics do matter and how used effectively can only improve decision-making. Then he recommends the need to i) focus analytics on the right business issues, ii) manage expectations by linking analytics projects to business outcomes, and iii) to build analytics on previous research. It will be fascinating to see how business impact rises as people analytics continues to mature and becomes a core component of HR.

,

One of the reasons Ulrich cites for the lower than expected impact of people analytics is the failure to focus on the right business challenges. The intrinsic link between people analytics and strategy and the ability this provides to focus on the right projects is the central theme of Patrick Coolen’s terrific article. Patrick describes the four-year evolution of the people analytics function he leads at ABN AMRO. These cover evolutions in the tools and techniques used, the analytical service offered, the capabilities of the team, where the team sits within the bank (now as part of HR Strategy and Change) and how analytics has become a core component of HR’s DNA. As ever with Patrick’s articles there is plenty to learn from and to be inspired by.

,

Ethics and trust is arguably the most important part of successful people analytics and is also the biggest challenge facing the majority or practitioners I speak to. With the likes of new legislation (e.g. the EU’s General Data Protection Regulations), emerging data sources (e.g. wearables) and the rush to personalise services to employees this is a fast developing and often confusing part of analytics. These two articles from Michael Stanka and Jouko van Aggelen (on the excellent Analytics in HR blog) provide both the context and sound guidance required by practitioners concerned about this critical subject. I certainly concur with the advice to put employee trust and transparency to the fore.

,

Ethics was one of the six trends I identified in my recent article for the HRN Blog, which focused on organisations that have already successfully built capability in people analytics. The other five trends focused on how organisations are i) seeking to make analytics part of the core organisational DNA, ii) embracing new and emerging data sources, iii) exploring new ways to analyse and democratise data, iv) enabling the future of work and consumerisation of HR, and v) reshaping their organisations. In summary, these organisations see analytics as a core component of HR strategy and critical to improving the impact of the function on the business. I presented these findings at the recent HR Tech World show in San Francisco (see Slideshare below and key learnings blog). Two of my fellow presenters were...

,

If Josh Bersin earned $1 every time Bersin by Deloitte’s 2013 High Impact People Analytics Study was quoted in a conference speech, slide or article then he would be a very rich man. The successor to this seminal study will be published later in 2017, and Madhura Chakrabarti revealed the early findings at the recent HR Tech World show in San Francisco (see Figure 3 and Slideshare below). The research indicates that companies who have built successful people analytics practices recognise the need to i) build data literacy across HR, ii) engage with the right stakeholders in the business and iii) infuse people analytics into business decisions. These findings are significant and augur well for continued and sustainable growth in the space.

,

Figure 3: What characteristics predict organisations with high-impact people analytics functions? - The early indicators from Bersin by Deloitte's 2017 study

,

As a bonus, the Slideshare from Josh Bersin’s superb ‘The HR Tech Market Reinvents Itself’ presentation at HR Tech World is also provided below.

,

Next, I want to introduce you to a terrific initiative outlined in this article by Volker Jacobs. Whilst I am confident that we will continue to see individually driven advancement in the space, it is collaboration, shared learning and co-creation by people analytics practitioners that will accelerate this process and improve both business impact and employee wellbeing. This program is different from others in that it is being led by Jonathan Ferrar and Al Adamsen (together with Volker and Dirk Petersen) - who are not only hugely respected by their peers but critically have both been people analytics leaders themselves. Volker’s article outlines the launch meetings taking place in July, which will be hosted by some of the leading lights in the world of people analytics: Patrick Coolen, Alexis Fink, Arun Chidambaram and Ian Bailie. I’m delighted to have been asked to join these meetings and will watch how the program, which officially launches in September, develops with interest. The space needs initiatives such as these.

,

Figure 4: Workforce Analytics is the centrepiece of a digital agenda for HR (Source - Volker Jacobs, TI People)

,

Unless your name is Rip van Winkle you can’t fail to have noticed that there is a lot of hype about how AI will transform HR. I believe that in the clamour to be hipper than thou many organisations are trying to put the AI cart before the analytics horse. Without first developing capability in the latter it will be difficult if not impossible to reap the benefits (to businesses and employees) of infusing AI into HR services. This is the premise of the first article in HBR by Nick Harrison and Deborah O’Neill, which whilst not specifically focused on HR does emphasise the need for businesses to get the basics right first before plunging head first into sophisticated AI (this definitely applies to HR). Not content with releasing (together with Jonathan Ferrar) the definitive book on people analytics (see #1), Nigel Guenole and Sheri Feinzig (together this time with Chris Lamb) offer some practical advice on a key building block for AI in HR – the need to audit your organisation’s competency frameworks. The white paper outlines the taxonomies that competencies are comprised (see Figure 5 below), why CHROs should either develop and/or audit their existing frameworks, the uses of competencies in AI infused recruitment, career development and learning, and the role of competencies in the future of HR.

,

Figure 5: KSAO - The taxonomies that competencies are comprised (Source: IBM Smarter Workforce Institute)

,

In the last round-up of articles from March and April, I featured Part 1, Part 2 and Part 3 of Keith McNulty’s superb series on machine learning in HR. If you haven’t already, I recommend reading the articles in sequential order. Once you have you’ll be set up nicely for the fourth and final part, To conclude the series, Keith advises first on how to decide if the output of your algorithm is good enough to do something with. Then Keith looks at how to implement it effectively as a predictive tool to support (not replace) human judgement, ensuring that the right processes and procedures are put in place to ensure that potentially damaging aspects of the model are appropriately managed.

,

Greg Newman has rapidly become a reliable source of high-quality articles on people analytics and organisational network analysis. In this example, Greg describes how analysing email meta data can help shine a light on a huge problem for many businesses – employee burnout. This is a major contributory cause of attrition and impacts on efforts to build an engaged workforce. As Newman describes, many of the variables required to analyse burnout are visible in our email activity – see four of these in Figure 6 below – and as email detail is constantly changing organisations can take the steps necessary to mitigate burnout. Newman’s company TrustSphere are definitely onto something here as this insight would be invaluable for pretty much every company I know.

,

Figure 6: Four variables of employee burnout that can analysed from email meta data (Greg Newman)

,

The vast majority of HR leaders recognise how analytics can support better decision-making, but as David Creelman describes in this helpful article on the Visier blog, many are unsure how to do so. Creelman then reels off three mistakes to avoid: i) rebranding the HR Reporting Team by adding the word ‘Analytics’ without providing additional resources, ii) hiring data scientists and asking them to search for insights in the data instead of focusing on the critical business issues, and; iii) overlooking the rest of HR and not taking the steps to improve their data fluency and therefore raise the overall analytical capability within HR. Creelman then provides some good tips on how to avoid falling into these traps.

,

I always enjoy spending time with Rupert Morrison and his super smart team at OrgVue. Like me they advocate that people analytics isn’t about providing insights that help HR – instead it should be about improving the organisation. In this terrific article, Rupert offers five mindsets HR should adopt to win hearts and minds within the business. Two suggestions I’d particularly like to highlight are first the need for HR to couple analytics with organisational design to answer the question “how good is my workforce in executing the business strategy?” Secondly, Morrison’s suggestion to gamify and crowdsource the data collection and cleaning process is also quite brilliant. A must-read.

,

If people analytics is to become a core component of the future HR profession then it is vital that the professional bodies support and enable their members. The CIPD under Peter Cheese has taken a lot of steps in this direction and the work of Edward Houghton has done much to steer things forward. This article presents some of the fruits of his labour: three reports that designed to help practitioners continue to advance and innovate in the field. The first report Human Capital Analytics and Reporting: Exploring Theory and Evidence was written by Edward himself whilst the second two reports - Assessing the Evidence of the Value and Impact of People Data (by Andy Charlwood, Mark Stuart and Clive Trusson) and Assessing the Evidence for the Value and Importance of People to Organisational Success (by Martin McCracken, Ronan McIvor, Raymond Treacy and Tony Wall) are also tremendous contributions to the practice of people analytics.

,

As Laura Stevens outlines at the start of this excellent article, in the rush to jump on the employee experience bandwagon many organisations are investing in survey apps and tools before properly designing their strategy. Developing a thoughtful approach to how continuous listening and the data it generates can be translated into relevant insights and actions towards improving the employee experience should be a priority. Laura’s article provides five tips on how to achieve this. The one I’d like to highlight is the fifth on ensuring that you apply advanced analytics to the data you collect. This highlights the pivotal role analytics is playing in the evolution of employee engagement – I know of many people analytics functions who have now taken on additional responsibility for survey management, employee listening and expect this trend to continue. 

,

This HBR article by Peter Cappelli has provoked some heated debate. The majority seem to have sided with the distinguished professor and concur that HR does not actually have big data. Certainly, few would disagree with Cappelli’s assertion that the challenge for most HR functions is simply to use data at all. However, some would argue that analysing email data, employee sentiment, data from wearable devices and external talent supply and demand data as some organisations are beginning to do does deserve the ‘big’ descriptor. In many respects though this article is one where you need to look past the headline as much of the advice Cappelli offers is both relevant and salient.

,

Any article that starts with a sports analogy is guaranteed to lure me in and Ridwan Ismeer’s recollection of Real Madrid’s ill-fated 2003-04 season was no exception. Even better it’s packed with great insights on people analytics. First, Ridwan provides a pretty sound analysis on the common characteristics of successful people analytics programs. Then he summarises the typical employee attributes used to build models and herein lies the ‘missing’ element in the article’s title. Pretty much all of this data can be classed as human capital data stored in HR systems, but as Ridwan argues what about social capital and the relationship and network data that this is comprised of? He then provides a compelling example from a survey he conducted in an organisation himself – see Figure 7 below.

,

Figure 7: Examples of relationship analytics (Ridwan Ismeer)

,

One of the few (only?) advantages of being the last major function in the business to embrace analytics and a evidence-based culture is that there is plenty to learn from and be inspired by from outside HR. Three examples are provided here. First, research from McKinsey focuses on the current and next wave opportunities in digitisation, analytics, artificial intelligence, and automation, their potential impact on employment and work plus advice on what leaders should do. Next, Todd Clark and Dan Wiesenfeld describe three things holding back analytics in business: structure, culture and methodology (sound familiar?). Finally, Tom Davenport (the man who helped popularise analytics and then people analytics with his and Jeanne Harris’ seminal Competing on Analytics book in 2006 and subsequent Competing on Talent Analytics article for HBR in 2010 – the latter also co-authored with Jeremy Shapiro) examines the progress of analytics in the ensuing ten years, focusing on some of the technological advances that have changed the ways analysts do their work.

,

As I touched on in the last collection, the question as to whether people analytics reduces or exacerbates bias or supports or hinders diversity initiatives is a contentious issue at many conferences I attend. This quintet of articles provides some contrasting views. The first article centres on Maxine Williams’ (Facebook’s Global Director of Diversity) speech at the recent Wharton People Analytics Conference, where she challenged the people analysts present that they needed to do more particularly in the area of race under-representation. The second article (Rob Briner et al) describes how using evidence (and data) can help HR drive change with regards to D&I within their organisations. Next, Hyon S Chu describes the main findings of a joint study by Culture Amp and Paradigm (CEO Joelle Emerson also features in the Wharton article too) on D&I specifically in the technology industry. Finally, Frida Polli of Pymetrics argues that whilst it is impossible to remove bias from humans, it is possible to remove it from algorithms through training, engineering and testing. Al as a powerful force for good – that seemed a good point to conclude the countdown for this time until the Wall Street Journal article appeared on Unilever, one of Pymetrics’ customers, and how they have ditched resumes and traditional campus recruiting in favour of algorithms for some early-career roles.

,


,


,

If you prefer listening rather than reading about people analytics, then I strongly recommend you check out the Tucana People Analytics Podcast, which is usually hosted by Max Blumberg. Three podcasts have been published over the last two months. First, Alec Levenson talks about how to make people analytics more focused on the business. Then Becky Thielen and Jeremy Tyers describe how Microsoft has used people analytics to amongst other projects evaluate whether managers matter and if so what behaviours correlate with employee engagement and productivity. Finally, Kevin Moore provides a fascinating description of how USA Today built people analytics from the ground up. If you like podcasts, please feel free to also check out my guest appearance on Matt Alder’s Recruiting Future Podcast where we talked all things people analytics particularly in relation to talent acquisition. Do also check out Matt’s fascinating podcast with Jacob Morgan on Employee Experience and be prepared for some very interesting findings on the ROI of companies that provide a high-level of experience for their employees.

,

That's all for this time...

,

______________________________________________________________________

,

David is a respected influencer, writer and speaker on people analytics, data-driven HR and the future of work. He was recognised as Best Writer at the 2015 HR Tech Writers’ Awards, and was awarded one of ten LinkedIn Power Profiles for HR in 2016. David’s role as Global Director, People Analytics Solutions at IBM enables him to help clients apply an analytical, insight led and business outcome focused approach to their talent strategies and people decisions.

,

David is chairing, speaking and/or attending the following conferences between now and June. If you are going to one of these conferences and would like to meet up with David, please feel free to contact him via LinkedIn:

,

Connect with David on LinkedIn, follow him on Twitter and read his blogs here on LinkedIn and also on HR Tech World and ERE.

,
