]

column3: The 20 best HR Analytics articles: Mar & Apr 2017
column5:
[

Can it really be May already? 2017 is simply flying past and already this year promises to be a pivotal one for the practice of people analytics. Will this be the year when it becomes absorbed into the wider fabric of HR? Maybe. Maybe not.

,

Whether it does or whether it doesn’t, one thing is for sure interest levels in data driven people decisions has never been higher. The recent people analytics conferences hosted by Wharton and Tucana in Philadelphia and London respectively were attended by in total close to 1,000 people. The number of articles published on the subject continues to rise and the diversity of subjects describing the challenges people analytics is helping to tackle is stark.

,

This makes collating the best articles both more enriching and increasingly challenging, but after much deliberation spent listening to Sandinista! - The Clash's monumental 36 track triple album - here are the 20 articles that stood out in March and April:

,

Let’s open with one of the most important articles written yet on the subject of people analytics. In many respects the practice of people analytics is going in the right direction – interest levels have soared, adoption is rising and significant sums are being invested in the space by large consultancies, tech giants and start-ups alike. However, as Max Blumberg and Mark Lawrence so passionately argue, continued growth of people analytics is under threat. They cite a potent mix of ill-conceived products, consultants that promise the earth but fail to deliver, uneducated opportunists chasing filthy lucre and naïve consumers who are too easily satisfied by a funky dashboard. Max and Mark’s call for a professional body to outline competencies, define training, provide certification and perhaps most importantly a code of ethics is long overdue. Let’s see if anyone is willing to take up the challenge… 

,

One of the criticisms that can be levied at the majority of people analytics articles is that they are too short and therefore only scratch at the surface of the issue they are attempting to tackle. This certainly doesn't apply to this phenomenally superb series by Keith McNulty, who leads McKinsey’s internal people analytics and assessment capability globally. Throughout the course of three excellently crafted articles (Part 4 - the final episode will follow soon) Keith demystifies machine learning and predictive analytics in HR. In broad terms, Part 1 focuses on preparing your organisation, Part 2 looks at structuring the problem you are trying to solve ("what do you want to model and why do you want to model it") whilst Part 3 examines how to prep the data and choose the right algorithm. Do read the articles in sequential order, as there is much to absorb and learn. It is an invaluable contribution to the practice of people analytics. Thank you Keith, I’ll add Part 4 once you publish it!

,

Mark Berry has already trod the path I predict many heads of people analytics will follow – all the way to the CHRO role as the practice of HR finally becomes more evidence based. This two-part article in John Sumser’s excellent HR Examiner provides the perfect roadmap for success. Part 1 outlines 10 of the key steps (see Figure 1 below) Mark followed, whilst Part 2 looks at each of these steps in more detail. Mark’s passion, knowledge and humour shines throughout what is both a hugely enjoyable and insightful read. See also my interview with Mark Berry for more on his fascinating insights on people analytics, the role of the CHRO and the future of HR.

,

Figure 1: 10 steps to evidence based HR - Mark Berry

,

This HBR article presents the findings of a fascinating four-year study by Adam Grant and Reb Rebele and is an example of the magnitude of impact ambitious people analytics projects can have on both individuals and organisations (as well as being a project that really resonated with me personally). The study examines perhaps the most important people in any organisation – the ‘givers’, how uncontrolled their generosity puts them at risk of burnout and outlines the steps they can adopt so that they don’t wear themselves out. The advice offered (see also Figure 2 below) broadly falls into three areas: i) be more proactive and less reactive about how you help, ii) focus on lower cost and higher impact ways of helping, and iii) be more selective rather than helping everyone with everything. For more on this subject, read Grant and Rebele’s follow-up article – More on Being Generous Without Being a Doormat and watch this video.

,

Figure 2: Where are you on the generosity spectrum and 7 habits of highly productive giving - Adam Grant and Reb Rebele

,

This is a first. Previously, I've baulked at including any of my own articles in these ‘best of’ retrospectives, but this entry isn’t about me. It’s about the inspirations, key discussions and stunning work exhibited at two of the holy trinity of conferences dedicated to people analytics – Wharton’s People Analytics Conference and Tucana’s People Analytics World (the other is Al Adamsen’s People Analytics & The Future of Work). My summation from the Wharton conference features insights from the likes of Adam Grant, Kieran Snyder, Dawn Klinghoffer, Cade Massey and Linda van Leeuwen, whilst my round-up of the Tucana conference (which I also had the good fortune to chair) features the likes of Patrick Coolen, Arun Chidambaram, Bernard Marr, Luk Smeyers and Ian Bailie. It is conferences such as these that help move the practice forward.

,

Click on the image above to read the key takeaways from April's People Analytics World Conference in London

,

Two more articles inspired by the People Analytics World conference. Firstly, Cathryn Newbery provides an impeccable summary of the keynotes by Alec Levenson and Peter Howes, which together outlined seven areas where the people analytics profession needs to do better. Michael Carty’s equally excellent article also refers to the Levenson and Howes keynotes but touches too on Cole Nussbaumer’s masterclass in storytelling with data before focusing in depth on fascinating insights from Ross Sparkman in how Facebook uses analytics to support workforce planning, hiring and succession planning.

,

(L-R) Peter Howes, Ross Sparkman and Alec Levenson speaking at People Analytics World

,

Alec Levenson also features in my next entry together with Alexis Fink, who heads up Talent Intelligence and Analytics at Intel. Two of the sharpest minds in our space surmise (correctly, in my view) that most companies are still struggling to get business insights from their HR data, and also cannot yet focus on advanced analytics and prediction. All is not lost though as they then provide some practical steps to follow, which can be boiled down to choosing the right analysts (combining business acumen with an understanding of people) and then deploying them to work most effectively with both the business and HR. The advice provided on asking the right questions (as opposed to starting with the data) particularly resonates. A must-read.

,

This report examines the state of analytics across the enterprise but there is much for those involved with people analytics to learn. The first is that we are not alone when it comes to struggling to execute a strategy for what we want to achieve with analytics. A second is that whilst analytics is now a mainstream idea it is still not a mainstream practice - this is particularly true of course for people analytics. The report presents five key findings: i) Competitive advantage with analytics is waning, ii) Optimism about the potential of analytics remains strong, iii) Achieving competitive advantage with analytics requires resolve and a sustained commitment to changing the role of data in decision making, iv) Companies that are successful with analytics are much more likely to have a strategic plan for analytics, and this plan is usually aligned with the organization’s overall corporate strategy, and; v) Most companies are not prepared for the robust investment and cultural change that are required to achieve sustained success with analytics. This report is a must-read.

,

The premise of this excellent article by Bernard Marr is that, in the information age, people data is rapidly becoming the most valuable source of data in the business. Marr cites the spike in companies investing in technology that can measure and analyse the behaviour and performance of their employees. One example is Deloitte with their ConnectMe HR analytics platform, which is focused firmly on the needs of employees. Marr’s discussion with Deloitte principal Michael Gretczko about the platform is revealing, and we can expect to a see a flood of companies adopting similar platforms that are “tailored specifically for employees” (we have similar platforms at IBM), which like ConnectMe “bring personalised content and experiences based on what employees need”. I concur with Marr’s quote below and believe that it distils the central theme for people analytics moving forward perfectly. For more insight from Bernard Marr, check out this episode of the Tucana People Analytics Podcast, where he speaks to Max Blumberg.

,

Click on the image above to listen to Bernard Marr on the Tucana People Analytics Podcast

,

Initially I was going to select just one or maybe two of these articles, but given they all fall under the category of 'practitioner guidance and/or case studies', I thought readers would want to have easy access to all four. First up is another great HR Open Source case study (do check out what Lars Schmidt and Ambrosia Vertesi have created with #HROS if you haven’t already), this time from Chris Brown describing Soundcloud’s people analytics journey. Then Hasher Ahmadi, who is building KLM’s people analytics capability, provides a step-by-step guide on how to implement analytics on the Analytics In HR blog. Next Keenan Steiner describes the superb use case of Piyush Mathur and Doug Shagam on how they quantified the cost of a single percentage point of attrition to mobilise stakeholders around a strategy to promote lateral moves at Nielsen. Finally, Fredrik Johnsson of Spotify outlines how using the right data at the right time is absolutely pivotal to making the right hiring decisions.

,

The deck from Nielsen's presentation at Talent Connect upon which the article referenced above is based - Piyush Mathur and Doug Shagam

,

There are more great practitioner stories in my next entry too. The video panel features RJ Milnor, who heads up Talent Analytics globally at Chevron, and Will Gaker of LinkedIn’s Talent Analytics team in discussion with Pat Wadors (LinkedIn CHRO) and Brendan Browne (Global Head of Talent Acquisition, LinkedIn). RJ and Will describe the importance of talent analytics in their companies, whilst the accompanying blog outlines three examples – one each from Chevron and LinkedIn and also an example featuring Boryana Dineva on how Tesla used analytics to gain invaluable (and counterintuitive) insights into its employee referral program.

,

WATCH: Will Gaker (left) and RJ Milnor discuss how data and analytics has helped shape the talent strategies at LinkedIn and Chevron

,

A regular inclusion in these ‘best of’ retrospectives, Sam Hill provides a regular supply of great content to organisations and practitioners looking to get started with people analytics or those seeking to build on their initial foundations. This article focuses on Sam’s view (based on his experience and research) that organisations that have invested in a Centre of Expertise have invariably been those that have had more success in building a more credible, agile and sustainable People Analytics proposition. Sam then outlines some of the building blocks involved including: appointing the right leader, determining an appropriate agenda/vision, assembling the right skill-sets (see Figure 3 below) and agreeing success criteria with the business. A hugely insightful read once again from Sam.

,

Figure 3: Skills required in a People Analytics CoE - Sam Hill

,

The next three articles focus on the evolution of employee engagement and its increasing underpinning by analytics...

,

One of the emerging topics in people analytics and potentially one of its most important benefits is how it can underpin efforts to understand, improve and personalise the employee experience. This superb article by Laura Stevens of iNostix by Deloitte outlines first why investment in people analytics is a pre-requisite and then describes three ways analytics can boost programs in this area: i) segmentation, ii) targeting and prioritising investment as well as iii) understanding and demonstrating value.

,

Jacob Morgan’s new book ‘The Employee Experience Advantage’ comes highly recommended as this teaser in the Harvard Business Review demonstrates. In the article, Jacob compares organisations that have invested long-term in ‘experience’ to those that have invested short-term in ‘engagement’. The results Jacob presents are highly interesting – both in terms of business metrics but also stock market performance (as illustrated in Figure 4 below). Given that people analytics is crucial to understanding and improving the experience in the three environments outlined by Jacob as most important to employees (cultural, technological and physical), these are highly compelling findings.

,

Figure 4: Companies that invest in Employee Experience outperform those that don't - Jacob Morgan (The Employee Experience Advantage, Wiley 2017)

,

The third and final entry in this edition on the subject of the evolution of employee engagement and its increasing underpinning by analytics comes from another excellent piece on the Analytics In HR blog. Raja Sengupta and Soumyasanto Sen provide a detailed walk through the hotly debated topic of engagement, demonstrate some of the new thinking in this area (from the likes of Andrew Marritt and Josh Bersin) and suggest a model (see Figure 5 below) on how you can deploy engagement analytics over time.

,

Figure 5: Deploying Engagement Analytics over a period of time. From proof of concept till establishing analytics in an organisation or culture - Raja Sengupta & Soumyasanto Sen

,

Storytelling is often cited as one of the capabilities many people analytics teams struggle with. Without a compelling story and effective communication you will not be able to turn your hard earned insights into actions. This excellent article by Ian Cook distils storytelling with data into four simple and easy to follow steps addressing the plot (what questions are you addressing), the context, understanding your audience and summarising.

,

Proficiency in storytelling aside, three other perhaps more foundational challenges are often cited by organisations struggling to build capability in people analytics: criticality (where to focus), capability (where to develop the skills of the team) and credibility (how to increase influence and impact). These three areas and the ways to mitigate them are described on the excellent Inside HR blog by Aaron McEwan of CEB. This is an invaluable read for those starting out or those struggling to make an impact with people analytics.

,

Finally, I look at three emerging topics in people analytics and highlight the best recent articles on each topic. First up is the re-emergence of Organisational Network Analysis then tackling bias and we ending with ethics, privacy and trust.

,

As adoption of people analytics continues we have also seen in parallel a revitalisation in the interest of Organisational Network Analysis (ONA). Four examples are included here. First, Greg Newman of the pioneering TrustSphere examines how combining ONA with people analytics supports the identification and retention of HiPOs. Then Andy Spence looks at how ONA can be used to understand and enhance team dynamics and collaboration. Next, Saskia Menke takes a broader view on the uses of ONA for people analytics (inc. in M&A) before finally, re:Work by Google recounts a specific example from Ben Waber of Humanyze on the effect networks and day to day employee interactions had on performance across a European bank’s branch network.

,

Does analytics reduce or magnify unconscious bias? This is another contentious area that is regularly debated at conferences and in the press. This trio of articles highlight with the right science and approach, analytics can significantly mitigate the dangers of unconscious bias. Firstly, Thomas C. Redman offers some great advice on rooting out bias from your decision-making. Then two articles from the FT focus on the specific topic of diversity recruitment and what companies such as KPMG, Vodafone and Microsoft are doing to remove gender bias from the recruitment process. Look out for some telling advice from Theresa McHenry, Martin Blackburn and Catalina Schveninger in the first article, and also how Catalina has employed technologies such as Textio and Headstart at Vodafone to support this initiative. Textio also features in Jane Wild’s piece, which looks at the fascinating subject of how language and imagery can detract or entice female jobseekers – Kieran Snyder, CEO of Textio, and Joelle Emerson of Paradigm both feature here. 

,

Finally, we end with the subject that is provoking more debate than anything else when I speak to practitioners and attend conferences: ethics, privacy and employee trust – much of it fuelled by the increasing number of companies looking to gain insights from employee data collected from wearable devices. I’ve included a selection of articles here: Jane Wild’s article in the FT describes some of the quandaries employers are facing and features views and advice from the likes of Laurence Collins, Edward Houghton of the CIPD and Anthony Bruce. The article also references the EU’s pending GDPR, which is the subject of Raghav Singh’s piece. Then there is a well-balanced Newsnight report (see video below) on the growth of wearables, which includes comments from Ben Waber of Humanyze. Next up, Sarah Butcher’s article looks specifically at the use of people analytics in the financial services sector – look out for some sage observations from Morten Kamp Andersen here. Finally, Ben Eubanks offers some sound advice to organisations (with some additional comments from yours truly) on the importance of putting employee trust front and centre when it comes to using their data. This debate will only intensify, which seems a nice place to finish this round-up of the best articles!  

,

WATCH: BBC Newsnight report on the growth of wearables in the workplace and the implications for employee trust and privacy

,

column3: Key takeaways from People Analytics World
column5:
[

For the third consecutive year, I had the honour of chairing Tucana’s People Analytics World Conference (#PAWorld17) in London on 25-26 April, which has firmly established itself as the premier gathering of the people analytics community in Europe.

,

Whilst the conference demonstrated that interest levels and adoption of people analytics continue to go in the right direction, the practice needs to overcome a number of obstacles before it can be said to have truly arrived. Like Anthony Joshua, who triumphed in the other big event to take place in London last week, people analytics can certainly pack a punch. Nevertheless, it is also susceptible to a counterpunch from a more experienced (and in the case of many HR leaders, a highly sceptical) opponent.

,

Here are my key takeaways from an enjoyable and thought provoking two days, which are split as follows. First, takeaways #1 to #5 provide a critical view of the current state of people analytics, takeaways #6 to #9 describe some of the best practices exhibited at the conference, #10 to #13 look at the opportunities afforded by the future and the consequent focus on ethics whilst #14 to #16 wrap-up proceedings. Enjoy and do please let me know in the comments your thoughts.

,

Despite the steady growth in interest, adoption and sophistication of the case studies on show, the practice of people analytics continues to be a work in progress. The number of organisations who have used people analytics to move the dial on business performance and employee wellbeing is still too small. Many more are stuck in an endless cycle of reporting and are too focused on the data to see the bigger picture within their organisations. Whilst the talent, enthusiasm and camaraderie of the delegates at #PAWorld17 was inspiring, it is not enough. People analytics now needs to move beyond this growing, highly capable but still relatively small group to the wider HR community. Developments in technology, the need to embrace digital and a thirst to develop consumer like experiences for employees are all helping to propel people analytics forward. The time to push even harder towards widespread adoption is now. I concur with Josh Bersin that “Analytics is no longer a ‘good idea’ for HR – it is now mandatory,” but that there is still a tremendous amount of work to do before this vision is realised.

,

Alec Levenson (left) and Peter Howes both delivered a much-needed wake-up call in their People Analytics World keynotes (Photos by Andreas Grieger)

,

“I see a great deal of potential for HR analytics, and I’m very, very afrai” said Alec Levenson as he began his provocative opening keynote at #PAWorld17. Levenson struck a chord with many gnarled people analysts in the audience when he added that we are “not focusing enough on the questions that matter and too much on the data in front of us.” This is perhaps the key challenge that is holding the practice back, and one that we revisit time and time again at every people analytics conference I attend. So what should we do differently? Perhaps, as Levenson suggested, instead of concentrating our solutions at the individual level we need to turn the traditional approach of people analytics on its head and start with the business results to be achieved (see Levenson’s model in Figure 1 below). I can certainly see that this approach will help people analysts to focus on the questions that really matter to the business, eschewing work Levenson describes as “keeping the lights on” and instead help the business “move the needle strategically”. For more on Levenson’s keynote, please see this superb write-up by Cathryn Newbery, and also Levenson’s superb book Strategic Analytics, which explores this concept in much more depth.

,

Figure 1: Start with the business results to be achieved - Alec Levenson

,

When I speak to many people analytics practitioners especially those just starting out or at the intermediate level of maturity, the Holy Grail they seek is return on investment. But are we aiming too low? Levenson thinks so surmising that restricting yourself to ROI immediately puts you on the back foot – especially with our traditional foes in finance. As Levenson explained, using Figure 2 below, ROI only offers a short-term financial return. Far better to focus on investments that improve competitive advantage and consequently provide long-term financial return. Ultimately, this approach will enhance the practice of people analytics in the long-term and help turn the dial on the reputation of HR at the leadership level and throughout the business.

,

Figure 2: ROI vs. Competitive Advantage - Alec Levenson

,

Like Levenson, Peter Howes is one of the foremost respected brains globally on people analytics and also like Levenson, Howes’ keynote provided another much-needed wake-up call to the #PAWorld17 audience. Howes was in fine form as he expressed doubts that even 5% of organisations were really doing analytics (instead confusing 'analytics' with reporting and creating dashboards) with their people data. This means as Howes described that “we are just publishing stuff; this is important from a hygiene perspective, but it doesn’t add value and it doesn’t demonstrate credibility.” Howes believes much of the problem can be attributed to the plethora of maturity models published by consultants. These preach the need to develop incrementally through the various stages of reporting before tackling predictive analytics. Howes argues (and I agree) that neither the skills mix of the team nor the expectations of stakeholders grows incrementally. Certainly, people analytics leaders such as Patrick Coolen of ABN AMRO have had success in developing reporting and analytics in parallel. Up until now, people like Patrick have been the exception rather than the norm. It will be interesting to see if this continues to be the case moving forward as the urgency for organisations to develop capability in people analytics intensifies. Figure 3 below summarises Howes’ sage advice on what analytics CoEs typically currently do versus what they should be doing. 

,

Figure 3: Skills typically present and missing from Workforce Analytics CoEs - Peter Howes

,

Storytelling is a capability that is often overlooked when companies are building their people analytics teams. This is a mistake as without a compelling story and effective communication, stakeholders are unlikely to action the insights you have toiled so hard to uncover. Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic’s book ‘Storytelling with Data’ is a must-read for anyone who works with and presents data and her keynote at #PAWorld17 was probably the most universally well-received presentation of the whole conference. To pick just one nugget out, Nussbaumer’s suggestion that your story should follow a narrative arc as opposed to the traditional linear method really resonated (see Figure 4 below).

,

Figure 4: Typical stories follow a linear path, but stories should have shape - Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic

,


,

Whilst people analytics can certainly not afford to rest on its laurels, there was much at #PAWorld17 to inspire confidence for a brighter future. Takeaways #6 to #9 explore some of these:

,

It may sound like a cliché, but people analytics really is a journey. For most companies this means 3 to 5 years. Stories of overnight success are rare and there will be bumps along the way. Organisations that stay the course, learn equally from their successes and failures, maintain their focus on the challenges facing the business, and partner with colleagues outside HR and even the company are the ones that are typically successful. This is certainly true for the likes of ABN AMRO and Cisco, where each time I’ve seen Patrick Coolen and Ian Bailie speak their organisations have moved further along the road. Similarly, the likes of Eden Britt (HSBC), Olly Britnell (Experian), Gary Kildare (IBM) and Blair Hopkins (EY) all demonstrated how their organisations had grown their people analytics capability over the course of a number of years. Perhaps the best example I saw in the Strategy track at the conference came from Brydie Lear, Global Head HR Intelligence & Analytics at ING. The journey (see Figure 5 below) started in 2013 and has comprised three chapters to date. Chapter 1 saw eight successful pilots, which gave the momentum for further investment in talent and tools in Chapter 2. Challenges faced included the length of time required for modelling and advanced analytics, the lack of analytical skills among HRBPs and the infrastructure that was holding the team back. Fortunately, the combination of a fully supportive CHRO (to whom Lear now reports to) and a new bank-wide strategy that placed data and analytics at its heart helped to ING overcome these obstacles and Chapter 3 now sees people analytics as a strategic priority.

,

Figure 5 - Highlights of the People Analytics journey at ING - Brydie Lear

,


,

One of the ingredients I’ve witnessed in organisations that have successfully built people analytics capability is that they have a brilliant and inspirational leader. This was once again eminently visible amongst speakers and delegates at #PAWorld17. As I’ve written previously, the Head of People Analytics role is multi-faceted. You need to have business acumen, be able to develop a winning strategy, build organisational capability, manage stakeholders across the business and have the political astuteness required to drive actionable insights into business outcomes. The complexity of the role was highlighted superbly by Arun Chidambaram, Global Head of Talent Analytics at Pfizer, in Figure 6 below, during his and Bennet Voorhees’ presentation.   

,

Figure 6: The intra- and inter- company responsibilities of the Head of People Analytics - Arun Chidambaram

,

Building people analytics capability is a significant undertaking, but sustaining it is even more challenging. For most organisations this means enabling and supporting HRBPs and building an analytical culture within HR. Several speakers touched on this, notably Sjoerd van den Heuvel whose session on the culture and partnerships that make people analytics sustainable was well received. Other speakers such as Brydie Lear, Mariëlle Sonnenberg and Patrick Coolen also highlighted this critical component. Arun Chidambaram’s advice on how his team continue to work with HRBPs and the business to implement the insights derived from their projects particularly resonated. Without partnerships like this your people analytics efforts risk being unsustainable, lacking impact and are ultimately at risk of being cut when the budget monster rears its ugly head.

,


,

The conference provided several examples of innovative uses of ‘emerging’ or non-traditional data. Perhaps the most innovative came from Randy Knaflic, VP HR & Internal Operations at Jawbone during his well-received keynote aptly entitled ‘Crazy, Scary People Data.’ Knaflic spoke about how Jawbone is combining wearable data (e.g. sleep and heart rate) with HR data to derive new insights such as how sleep patterns are affected in the run-up to a new product launch. This was a fascinating peak into a potential future for people analytics and whilst Knaflic stressed that use of this data was opt-in (over 90% at Jawbone), anonymised and aggregated the debate it prompted suggested this one will run and run. Other examples of innovative data uses came from:

,

Figure 7: Philips' project to understand the people factors that best contribute to business performance - Franc Damhuis

,

As we look to the future, there is also much to be optimistic about when it comes to the continued growth and eventual widespread adoption of people analytics.

,

It is doubtful whether any industry commentator has their finger on the pulse of what the future of technology, data and analytics can offer more than Bernard Marr. In an inspirational speech, Bernard described how the leading organisations are building enterprise analytics team that capitalise on new technology, tools and techniques. He also outlined the four key pillars of how companies derive value from their data (see Figure 8 below) – and the lessons HR can learn from this. Being the last business function to adopt analytics may at times be embarrassing for HR, but at least it means we have plenty of places and talent elsewhere in the business from where we can draw inspiration from!

,

Figure 8: The four pillar model of how companies are deriving value from data - Bernard Marr

,

Organisations that have already invested in getting their people data in order and harnessing analytics are the ones best placed to capitalise on the opportunities and requirements of the future of work. Laurence Collins and Luk Smeyers of Deloitte ably demonstrated how some of these organisations have already introduced automation and AI into their HR services, whilst offering a path for others to develop their capability. Two organisations that have already started to see the benefits of their investments in this area are IBM and Cisco. Gary Kildare, CHRO Europe, described how IBM has used cognitive technology and analytics to support internal mobility, executive hiring, career development and workforce planning as well as a Manager’s Playbook (see Figure 9) that supports managers and helps them personalise coaching to employees. Similarly, Ian Bailie highlighted how Cisco has developed capability to push recommendations to employees around areas such as mobility, learning and career pathing.

,

Figure 9: Example of how IBM uses analytics and cognitive to support manager interactions with employees

,

The shift from ‘engagement’ to ‘experience’ when it comes to listening and understanding employees, and linking this to business performance was rightly described by several speakers as a huge opportunity for people analytics. The cognitive tools described in #11 and developed at IBM and Cisco (see also Figure 10 below) for their employees are two examples of this. A third came from Stefan Hierl of Adidas, who described how the sportswear giant has harnessed techniques used to understand customer experience (e.g. NPS) and applied this to employees. This is an area of HR – and people analytics – that is set to grow significantly.

,

Figure 10: Ian Bailie described how Cisco is pushing data and personalised recommendations to Cisco employees

,

As the focus on data sources shifts to new and emerging people data sources (e.g. email, health/wellbeing, internal/external social media) so the focus on ethics, privacy and trust intensifies. Marielle Sönnenberg, Global Director HR Strategy & Analytics at Wolters Kluwer), captured the mood perfectly by emphasising that when it comes to people analtics “we have to be right – it’s about people and people’s lives”. Employee trust needs to be put at the front and centre of people analytics strategies and is unquestionably the most important part of doing analytics. We can’t afford to get it wrong. We have not only a legal but a moral responsibility to employees and getting it wrong could set back people analytics years and cause irreparable damage to employee trust. It is not surprising therefore that the closing panel on ethics and consent provoked hot debate and differences of opinion. It was certainly a lively finish to the conference. For those interested in this subject, I highly recommend participating in this survey, which is being coordinated by Al Adamsen, Jonathan Ferrar and Volker Jacobs – participants will receive a report that will cover the items in Figure 11 below.

,

Figure 11: Click on the picture above to participate in the People Data & Ethics Survey

,

With three parallel tracks at #PAWorld, it was impossible to see all the sessions – I’m working on the David Green bot for next year! I’d like to thank my fellow chairs (Frode Hvaring and Stela Lupushor) plus other delegates for highlighting some of the key takeaways from the Action and Future stages. By all accounts, I missed excellent presentations from the likes of Stefan Hierl (Adidas), Ross Sparkman (Facebook), Becky Thielen (Microsoft), Ian Bailie (Cisco), Patrick Coolen (ABN AMRO), Olly Britnell (Experian), Eden Britt (HSBC), Sjoerd van den Heuvel, Blair Hopkins (EY), Kevin Moore (Gannett), Lance Mercereau, Tony Truong (DocuSign), Eugene Burke & Hani Nabeel and several others. I implore those that were at these sessions to add their key takeaways to the comments.

,

Having had the honour of chairing People Analytics World for the last three years, I continue to be impressed how the conference has grown and continues to improve year on year. It deserves its reputation as the premier conference in Europe on people analytics. Congratulations once again to Barry Swales, David Bebb and the Tucana team for organising such a superb conference. I’m already looking forward to the People Analytics Forum in London on 29th and 30th November.

,

#PAWorld17 has already inspired a number of other blogs and retrospectives:

,

Finally, the best conferences put networking at the front and centre of proceedings and this is something People Analytics World excelled at. I can’t possibly remember everyone I enjoyed speaking to, but other than some of the names already mentioned I’d like to give an additional shout out to: Andy Spence, Gareth Jones, Dave Millner, Jon Ingham, Andre Obereigner, Sam Hill, Martin O’Donnell, Anton Fishman, Ritvik Bhawan, Krysta Gough, Alex Gibson, Neil Claypole, Laura Stevens, Aki Ben-Ezra, Steve Bianchi, Ian Grant, Oxana Popkova, Mia Kim, Norman Burden, Laurent Geoffroy, Jodie Evans, Paul Seo, Tom Marsden, Renata Almeida Sabbat, Carol Braddick, Gordon Adam, James Allen, Brandon Cohen, Philip Gibbs, Matt Nowell, Ben Nicholas, David Gardiner, Nigel Dias, Pag Miles, Karen See, Fatih Subasi, Esa Karell and Klaas Toes.    

,

You all helped make the conference an even more enriching experience for me.

,

column3: Key takeaways from Wharton People Analytics conference 2017
column5:
[

Last week I attended the fourth edition of the Wharton People Analytics Conference, hosted by Adam Grant and Cade Massey, in Philadelphia. Here are my key takeaways from a fabulous two days.

,

I was motivated to attend the conference because of the many superlatives I’d received from practitioners that I respect. #WhartonPAC 2017 didn’t disappoint. The content at times was inspirational, the forum it provided for networking, sharing ideas and learning was superb and I met a number of practitioners who told me that this was the only conference they attend on people analytics. So, yes, the Wharton People Analytics conference is worthy of the hype and that has to be the first key takeaway.

,

Wharton PAC hosts Adam Grant and Cade Massey discuss the surge of interest in people analytics

,

Diversity was a central theme throughout the conference. Maxine Williams, Facebook’s Global Head of Diversity, contested, in a powerful speech sans slides, that people analytics was failing to address the needs of underrepresented (in this case, black and Latino) groups in tech. The problem Williams documented concerned people analysts advising her that the n sizes (number or sample size) are too small for the science to kick in or as Williams put it “if there was more of you, we could tell you why there was so few of you”. The irony, of course, is that means practitioners like Williams have to rely solely on experience and instinct – the very skills that people analytics is supposed to augment and greatly enhance. Whilst qualitative data can help complement the quantitative data that is available, the impact of institutional marginalisation also needs to be weighted. Williams’ call for a “Moneyball for diversity”, at least when it applies to underrepresented groups certainly lay down the gauntlet to delegates, although many I spoke afterwards felt that Williams could have said more about the initiatives, experiments and to a degree successes that have been conducted in the field.

,

Maxine Williams of Facebook delivers her conference keynote

,

As Arun Sundar writes in this excellent article, which was inspired by the conference, diversity must not simply be regarded as a ‘number’. Indeed as Adam Grant urged in his closing address, it’s not enough to reduce bias. Instead, we need to create experiences that make people empathise. Refreshingly, the conference provided several examples of diversity, and more to the point inclusiveness, in the context of analytics in action:

,

This was the question posed for the project presented at the conference by Dawn Klinghoffer, who leads Microsoft’s people analytics team and Ryan Fuller. For the managers out there – at least those at Microsoft, you can rest easy as the research demonstrated that managers do matter. The findings were fascinating in that it was factors such as managers with large networks, who provide consistent access and one-to-one time whilst promoting collaboration and work-life balance that fostered higher engagement, better performance and a stronger sense of belonging in their employees. Managers who work less hours and who send fewer emails out of work correlated with happier, more productive employees who are better able to manage their work-life balance. For more on Microsoft’s people analytics journey please see my interview with Dawn.

,

Highlights from Microsoft's Case Study presentation of 'Do managers matter' with top-left Dawn Klinghoffer and Ryan Fuller from Microsoft plus interviewer Martine Haas from Wharton Business School

,

The majority of the data Microsoft used to investigate if managers matter came from email meta data. For some, this is regarded as ‘creepy’ and the subject of employee trust and privacy was a constant theme throughout the two days. Whenever I speak to practitioners about the challenges they face, trust and privacy is always in the top three. Kieran Snyder summarised it perfectly: “the next decade will define the appetite for privacy versus benefit” and certainly employee trust needs to be placed at the front and centre of any people analytics strategy. Dawn Klinghoffer explained how Microsoft communicated what they were doing and why, as well as laying out the benefits to employees (see this blog by Microsoft CHRO Kathleen Hogan for more on this).

,

Being the last function of the business to adopt a data-driven approach may be embarrassing but it does mean that providing HR is prepared to put its head above the parapet it can draw plenty of experience and learning from outside the function. Marketing for example, as remarked by Peter Fader, has been fighting the same battle for 30 years. The conference offered plenty of inspiration from elsewhere including from sport and medicine. In his entertaining interview with Dan Pink, Adam Silver (NBA Commissioner) conveyed how analytics has revolutionised basketball across a multitude of areas from the uptake in three-point shots to informing strategies around resting players. Silver revealed that NBA players are equipped with wearables and sleep monitors and that this is accepted as normal - a precursor to the future workplace? Perhaps even more powerfully, Rosalind Picard from MIT spoke to an enthralled audience on how analytics has helped autism and epilepsy patients live more fulfilling and safer lives. The Empatica device that predicts seizures was designed as a result of exploring unexpected data – a prompt as Picard said to dig a little deeper when the data is strange. In a similar vein, a session on applying gaming to people analytics led by Ethan Mollick, revealed how a paediatric oncology game had enabled patients to adopt a more positive mindset - resulting in huge shifts in white blood cell count and other positive immune response indicators (thanks Kieran Snyder for capturing this point).

,

Much of the innovation in the people analytics space is being provided through the vendor community, and many of these firms were present at the conference. The companies that caught my eye (in no particular order) were: TrustSphere, CultureScope, Concentra Analytics, Humanyze, hiQ Labs, Twine, Peakon, Glint and Textio.

,

Malcolm Gladwell opened the conference with the cautionary tale of the ‘neurotic tortoise’ (see more in this excellent article by Tom Marsden) and the danger of assessment and selection methodology that doesn’t correlate to performance. In his interview with Adam Grant afterwards, Gladwell adopted a pessimistic approach to analytics remarking he is “more worried about becoming too dependent on analytics rather than not being dependent enough” and adding chillingly that he was “not optimistic about how analytics will go in the future”. 24 hours later, in closing the conference, Grant warned of the dangers of having “too much of a good thing” when it comes to analytics and urged the importance for people analytics to be focused on eradicating bias, increasing empathy and reducing defensiveness. As Grant commented, there is a danger that we like the data until it disagrees with what we believe. Instead, we need to get to the point where we express joy when the data shows we are wrong and couple it with judgement to make better decisions. Data alone is not enough. Data augmented with human judgement is the key to better decision-making for the benefit of the business – and for employees.   

,

The conference confirmed my thinking beforehand that people analytics is moving towards a second phase of evolution – even if many organisations are yet to even embark on their analytics journey in HR. As well as the focus on teams (see #4) and productivity data (see #5), speakers talked about the use of physiological data to measure health and wellness (Anita Woolley), providing employees with the means to give and receive feedback (Steven Huang), using network analytics to measure employee interaction and collaboration (Kieran Snyder) and measuring the link between organisational loneliness and attrition (Keith McNulty). Several speakers described our increased ability to analyse unstructured data or as Cade Massey put it  “text analysis now is as easy to run as regression”. Finally, Adam Grant spoke of how analytics is being used to improve collaboration and culture from the bottom up. All in all, if people analytics can overcome some of the challenges it faces such as privacy concerns (see #5), HR capability and fear, and institutionalising the practice then the future looks rosy.

,

Adam Grant closes the Wharton People Analytics Conference 2017

,

Finally, I’d like to highlight the competition winners and give thanks to the organisers. Eleven firms participated in the hotly contested Start-up Competition, with the People’s Award going to CultureScope – congratulations to Tom Price-Daniel and Hani Nabeel - the recognition is well deserved. The judges also gave awards to Stellar Employ (two awards for Most Impactful and Best User Experience) and Fama (Most Innovative Use of Data). Congratulations also to Linda van Leeuwen of Shell’s People Analytics team for taking away the spoils in the Research Paper Competition, as well as Andrew Ewbank, Ben Hodges and Justin Jones from Vanderbilt University for their triumph in the Student Case Competition (see more here). Last but not least, congratulations must go to the Wharton School for organising such a great conference – not just to Adam, Cade and Laura Zarrow from the Wharton People Analytics team, but also to the students who did much of the work. Adam highlighted Talia Stein, Gabrielle Levine and Jonathan Tugman. A bright future, hopefully in the people analytics space, awaits.

,

The conference has already inspired a number of blogs and articles:

,

Finally, the best conferences put networking at the front and centre of proceedings and this is something the Wharton People Analytics conference excelled at. I can’t possibly remember all the people I enjoyed speaking to, but other than some of the names already mentioned I’d like to give a shout out to: Shekar Nalle Pilli Venkateswara, Keith McNulty, Arun Chidambaram, Geetanjali Gamel, Antony Ebelle, Davis Carlin, Bennet Voorhoes, Manish Goel, Bharat Deore, Paul Edelman, Arun Sundar, Ramesh Karpagavinayagam, Ben Waber, Tom Marsden, Carla Arellano, Hani Nabeel, Russ Clarke, Linda van Leeuwen, Rupert Morrison, Dawn Klinghoffer, Tom Price-Daniel, Ben Teusch, Karyn Marciniak, Han Hu, Julian Holmes, Anu D’Souza, Nikhil Srivastava, Ryan Fuller, Jim Bell and Amelia Barker – you all helped make the conference an even more enriching experience for me. See you at #WhartonPAC 5!

,

Want more #WhartonPAC? - Click on the image above to listen to Cade Massey's interviews from the conference floor

,

,

column3: The role of People Analytics, Employee Experience and AI in the Workplace
column5:
[

I recently had the privilege of being invited as a guest on Jacob Morgan’s excellent The Future of Work Podcast, where Jacob and I had an in-depth discussion on the rise in the role of people analytics in the workplace.

,

Jacob and I conversed on a number of areas of people analytics, including:

,

You can listen to the Podcast here or by clicking on the image below. Please let me know your feedback and any questions in the Comments below.

,

Figure 1: The best practices of organisations leading the way in People Analytics (see here)

,


,

Jacob and I got to know each other as part of the research for his new book – The Employee Experience Advantage. From what I’ve read so far, this book is a must-read for anyone interested in people analytics, data-driven HR and the shift from employee ‘engagement’ to ‘experience’.

,

Read this taster to the book in HBR, which amongst other things outlines:

,

Figure 2: Companies that invest in Employee Experience Outperform Those That Don't (Source: The Employee Experience Advantage by Jacob Morgan - Wiley 2007)

,

Figure 3: How Investing in Employee Experience Affects Stock Price (Source: The Employee Experience Advantage by Jacob Morgan - Wiley 2007)

,

This data ties in nicely with part of the Podcast where Jacob and I discussed that the focus on employee experience and the consequent growth of AI tools to support this represent the ‘second wave of people analytics’. I believe that the growth in adoption of people analytics is likely to be fuelled in part by this phenomenon. Certainly, companies that have already invested in people analytics are well positioned to enjoy the benefits associated with investing in long-term experiential initiatives and AI/Cognitive tools that further enhance employee wellbeing and experience.

,

Thank you to Jacob for having me as a guest on the Future of Work Podcast. For more on Jacob and The Future Organization, please see his homepage.

,

column3: Top 20 HR Analytics articles: Jan & Feb 2017
column5:
[

The continued growth in people analytics takes many forms. Whether that’s increased adoption by organisations, the rise in the number of conferences devoted to the subject or the sheer number of articles published on the topic.

,

This is all wonderful, but it does mean I have had to revisit the number of times per year that I collate, shortlist and publish my favourite selection of articles on people analytics and data driven HR. In 2014 and 2015, it was once per year. Last year, it was twice. This year it seems that bi-monthly is the absolute minimum.

,

So, here are the articles that stood out for me in January and February 2017:

,

We start with not one, but two key takeaway summaries from the superb People Analytics & The Future of Work (PAFOW) conference convened and hosted by Al Adamsen in San Francisco at the beginning of February. Ben Teusch captures a selection of the many highlights from a memorable two days and focuses on a number of emerging trends in the space such as creating business impact, optimising the employee experience and the increasing focus companies are placing on understanding and driving team performance. In his round-up, Julian Holmes similarly emphasises the need for people analytics projects to have business relevance (see Figure 1 below). Julian also highlights two other trends in the space: i) the increasing role analytics is playing in underpinning organisational design and transformation, and ii) how a number of companies are building people analytics applications in-house such as Ernest Ng demonstrated he is doing at Salesforce.  

,

Figure 1: Activities that will make workforce analytics more relevant to the business (Source: Julian Holmes)

,


,

From the best people analytics conference in North America (PAFOW) to it’s pre-eminent counterpart in Europe – Tucana’s People Analytics conference series. Michael Carty draws the bulk of his five essentials from the talks given by Madhura Chakrabarti, Jim Matthewman and Jonathan Ferrar at the People Analytics Forum in London in November 2016, coupled with a telling quote from Josh Bersin that “Analytics is no longer a ‘good idea’ for HR – it is now mandatory”. Look out too for Chakrabarti’s advice on the key role required of HRBPs in making analytics the ‘new normal’ for HR, as well as Ferrar’s three key principles for communicating the insights from people analytics projects to decision makers in the business (see Figure 2 below). I will be chairing People Analytics World, which takes place in London on 25-26 April. Check-out the stellar line up of speakers, and register here using the code DG25 for a 25% discount.

,

Jonathan Ferrar delivers the keynote opening speech at Tucana's People Analytics Forum in London, November 2016 (Photo: Tucana)

,

Figure 2: Three Principles of Storytelling (Source: The Power of People by Nigel Guenole, Sheri Feinzig & Jonathan Ferrar)

,


,

This is a wonderful article. Amit Mohindra, one of the pioneers of data driven HR and presently leading the Talent Analytics function at Apple, revisits an article he wrote six years ago that provides guidance to a friend in the early stages of their people analytics journey. The advice offered still rings true today and anyone in the position that Amit’s friend was six years ago would do well to heed the guidance proffered. The company Amit’s friend still works for grew from strength to strength, went public, dominates its market and has steadily increased the size of its highly regarded people analytics team.

,


,

Most practitioners tasked with setting up a people analytics practice have to manage with limited budget and resources. In the face of high expectations, how do you succeed? Craig Starbuck, HR Reporting & Analytics Manager at Scottrade, shares his experiences of doing exactly this and provides ten guidelines for success. This is a truly engrossing and insightful read and it is hard to choose the best of Craig’s tips, but my favourite three are: Think Pro-Employee, Coalesce Around a Shared Vision and Facilitate and Demonstrate the ROI. Craig and the team at Scottrade won two awards at the hiQ Elevate Awards in October 2016, and it’s easy to see why when reading this.

,


,

Lorenzo Canlas heads up Talent Analytics at LinkedIn and in his previous article (featured in my 30 best People Analytics articles of 2016), he revealed that the ROI of his team is forecast to be 10X the cost of the team in 2017. This follow-up article explains one of the secrets to their success, which is founded upon understanding the three project types, the differing outcomes and the needs of their business partners for each type. These three types - inform, insight, or actions & accountability – and their corresponding ‘Conditions of Success’ (see Figure 3 below) are then described together with examples. Yet another insightful article from Lorenzo.

,

Figure 3: The three types of people analytics projects and their conditions of success (Source: Lorenzo Canlas)

,

It is rare that a day passes by without me reading at least one article on how artificial intelligence is set to revolutionise HR. It’s certainly true that a number of organisations that have reached a degree of maturity in people analytics are actively exploring how cognitive apps and machine learning can augment what they are already doing. This IBM research digs beneath the hype and provides findings on i) CEO/CHRO views on cognitive computing, ii) employee willingness to receive guidance from cognitive HR solutions, iii) the three areas in which HR is already leveraging cognitive - talent acquisition, talent development and HR operations and iv) recommendations for companies looking to take their first steps.

,

Figure 4: Highlights of IBM Institute for Business Value Cognitive HR Study (Source: IBM)

,


,

Deloitte’s Global Human Capital Trends is always a captivating read and the 2017 edition published just last week is no exception. First, Josh Bersin provides an executive summary of the 10 trends featured in the report, with an additional emphasis on what is perhaps the main finding of the study – that AI and robotics are entering the workforce much faster than we may have thought. Bersin's article itself is an absolute must-read. The same goes for the section on people analytics in the actual report itself. The headline finding is that people analytics is “no longer about finding interesting information and flagging it for managers” but is being utilised to “understand every part of a business operation” with analytical tools “being embedded into day-to-day decision making”. A detailed example from Chevron is provided, as are eight factors the authors believe are fundamental to creating a people analytics program. There are a number of invaluable insights in the report not least Figure 5 below depicting the old and new rules of people analytics. A must-read. 

,


,

Figure 5: People Analytics - Old rules vs. New rules (Source: Deloitte University Press)

,


,

One of the most knowledgeable and progressive practitioners I’ve had the pleasure of coming across in the people analytics space is Ian O’Keefe, who now heads up people analytics at JP Morgan Chase. Ian has previously held leadership roles at Google, Sears and American Express. Hence he has a unique vantage point to describe how different organisations leverage data to understand their people and has a wide array of experiences to draw from when talking about what works and what doesn't. As such, this episode of the superb hiQ Labs podcast is a must-listen as host Michael Housman and Ian have a fascinating and insightful conversation.

,


,

As Josh Bersin wrote in his 2017 HR Predictions, we need to rethink organisational design around how work actually gets done in the 21st century. As illustrated in Figure 6 below, this means moving from a traditional functional hierarchy to one that enables multi-functional teams to thrive. This is where Organisational Network Analysis (ONA) and its modern day counterpart Social Network Analysis (SNA) comes in. The opportunities this offers HR leaders and people analysts is perfectly described by Greg Newman of TrustSphere in this excellent article. Learn how ONA has evolved from a paper based process into a real time continuous flow of data that has transformed the ability of companies to map their informal networks and understand how work really gets done. Newman provides examples of how ONA/SNA can help identify influential employees, support succession planning, identify good/bad leadership behaviours and collaboration.

,

Figure 6: How work gets done (Source: Bersin by Deloitte)

,

One of the most prolific and best writers on people analytics is Tracey Smith. I particularly enjoyed this recent article, which analyses a recent McKinsey study that found that 86% of executives are still not getting value from analytics. Tracey focuses on the importance of the role of the analytics leader, their position within the organisation (the higher, the better), the need for them to ‘get out into the business’, and the importance of prioritisation and focus. An essential read for any current or aspiring people analytics leader.

,


,

Continuing one of the themes picked up by Tracey Smith, this HBR article by Thomas C. Redman makes the case that to be good at their job, a data scientist needs to get out into the business. Only then can they learn how the data is collected, understand the wider context, flesh out the specific problem and present insights in a language that will be understood and therefore implemented by the relevant stakeholders. Redman offers some great examples that whilst falling outside the realm of people analytics can easily be applied to the practice. 

,


,

Analytics in HR has rapidly emerged as one of the best sources of people analytics articles around. This guest post by Tom Haak is a perfect example. Inspired by Daniel Kahneman’s monumental ‘Thinking Fast and Slow’ and Rolf Dobelli’s ‘The Art of Thinking Clearly’, Haak summarises 15 cognitive biases that are relevant to the work and results of people analytics projects. As Haak states “there is a benefit for people analytics professionals to learn more about psychology and important cognitive biases, because no one is exempt from these biases”. Check out too Figure 7 below for Buster Benson’s Cognitive Bias Sheet, to which Haak refers.

,

Figure 7: Cognitive Bias Codex (Source: John Manoogian III and Buster Benson)

,

As Andrew Marritt writes in this insightful article, the way we measure employee engagement is changing. From a demand perspective, HR is playing catch-up with its peers in marketing who have adopted Voice of the Customer practices to gain deep insights to inform product and service strategies. Andrew then digs into the technologies that are revolutionising the supply side, which he breaks down into four categories: automation (which as illustrated in Figure 8 below is enabling a rethink of the end-to-end process), changes to mobile and user interfaces, big data technology (to support people analytics) and machine learning (text analytics and predictive). Andrew is an acknowledged expert in the fields of engagement and people analytics, so this is certainly a recommended read.

,

Figure 8: Rethinking the end-to-end employee feedback process (Source: Andrew Marritt | Workometry, Organization View)

,


,

If analytics is to become part of the DNA of HR then it simply has to embraced by HR Business Partners (HRBPs). As David Creelman contends in this excellent guest post on Analytics in HR, the long-term success of your people analytics program depends on it. The challenge is that many HRBPs are notoriously busy and not natural bedfellows for analytics. Creelman offers some invaluable advice on how to enthuse, equip and enable HRBPs and move them to the centre of your analytics equation.

,


,

The third entrant from one of Analytics in HR’s guest bloggers is this lengthy but riveting article by Raja Sengupta and Soumyasanto Sen. The article demystifies a ‘hot topic’ within HR and People Analytics – that of natural language processing (NLP). It describes the relevance of NLP to HR, the key benefits (and applications – see Figure 9 below), how it augments rather than automates HR processes and the vendor landscape as well as providing a case study of NLP in the recruiting process. There’s plenty to digest and learn from here.

,

Figure 9: Key application areas of Natural Language Processing in HR (Source: Analytics in HR, Raja Sengupta & Soumyasanto Sen)

,


,

Articles from Analytics in HR have rather dominated this collection, which is testament to the wonderful service Nando Steenhuis and Erik van Vulpen are providing to the people analytics community. This article by van Vulpen describes the importance of cleaning data and offers a helpful descriptive and visual (see Figure 10) six-step guide in how to actually do it. The checklist is featured in van Vulpen’s book – ‘The Basic Principles of People Analytics’, which I heartily recommend to anyone starting out in the people analytics space.

,

Figure 10: Six-Step guide to data cleaning (Source: Analytics in HR | Basic Principles of People Analytics book by Erik van Vulpen)

,


,

This short but highly apposite article by Anouska Ramsay, UK Talent Director at Capgemini really resonates. We mustn’t forget the ‘people’ element when we are doing people analytics. Whilst analytics can help identify insights that we can then test and implement, we need to remember those people within our businesses that don’t necessarily fit the trend but are also some of our best performers. This is a timely reminder from Anouska and one that highlights the role psychologists can play in interpreting results and as Morten Kamp Andersen has written ‘turn information into knowledge’ and mitigate bias and cognitive dissonance.

,


,

As interest and adoption of people analytics continues to rise, more and more organisations are looking to hire people who can lead, build and embed this capability within their companies. As Sam Hill writes in this article, this is no easy task – great people analytics leaders are in short supply and high demand. Hill then offers some helpful advice to recruiters that should help with their search such as who the role should report to (preferably the CHRO) and not to confuse analytics with MI/reporting (a common mistake).

,


,

Ben Eubanks is one of my favourite industry analysts. In this article, he draws on research he has undertaken to understand how companies globally are hiring people analytics talent, and outlines three options: build, buy or borrow together with a use case for each one. I’ve seen organisations use one or more of these three options as they build out their people analytics capability. A great article for organisations looking to start, grow or scale their analytics teams.

,


,

Last, but certainly not least, Thomas Rasmussen draws on some fascinating research from Stanford highlighting the role music plays in analytics. As Thomas explains, “the research team showed that music engages the areas of the brain involved with paying attention, making predictions and updating the event in memory”. So, perhaps Thomas has uncovered a previously hitherto unforeseen secret of doing great people analytics. Turn up the volume!

,


,

Hey, it’s my blog so hopefully you can forgive the mild self-promotion, but here are three of the blogs I published in January and February that seemed to have resonated with the people analytics crowd:

,

What constitutes best practice in People Analytics? – I’m fortunate to see at first hand the companies who have successfully adopted people analytics. They share a number of common good practices, which are described in this article and illustrated below.

,

Laszlo Bock on the future of HR and his new venture - All of us working in the people analytics space owe a debt of gratitude to Laszlo Bock for popularising and publicising the practice during his time as CHRO at Google. This article covers Bock’s thoughts on the future of HR, the role of people analytics and the latest on his new venture.

,

Demystifying People Analytics Part IV: 5 Examples of People Analytics Projects – As part of my column for the HRN Blog, I provide five case studies of people analytics projects covering different parts of the talent lifecycle including strategic workforce planning, talent acquisition, retention, compliance and engagement.

,

column3: Laszlo Bock on the future of HR & his new venture
column5:
[

Along with the likes of Josh Bersin, Adam Grant and John Boudreau, Laszlo Bock is one of the leading global authorities on the future of the HR function and the critical role that people analytics and data science has in driving this forward. When Bock speaks, the world listens.

,

The clamour for Bock’s thoughts has intensified since he announced in 2016 that he was leaving his role as SVP, People Operations (CHRO) at Google. What will he do next? Will he unveil some of the mystique about Google’s fabled approach to people? What does he believe the future of work and HR will be?

,

Some of these questions are addressed in a fascinating interview Bock gave to Steve Bates of SHRM in February 2017 (read full article).

,

Bock cites people analytics as the next stage in the evolution of HR and groups companies into two types when it comes to applying an analytical approach, which I’ve classified 'Believers' and 'Doubters':

,

Or ‘fast followers’ as Bock describes them: those companies that will be inspired to ‘really dig into analytical questions’ such as ‘Is performance management really working? Is compensation really fair?’ ‘We think our people are the best – how do we really know they’re the best and how do we make them better?’ Bock suggests that some organisations are going to implement people analytics ‘very, very quickly and they’ll be successful’.

,

On the flip side of the coin, Bock believes that many companies will fail to see the opportunity offering excuses such as ‘Oh I can’t do that, it’s too hard; my manager doesn’t support it; the company doesn’t want to do it; we don’t have the head count; it’s too risky.’ I share Bock’s fears that a lot of companies will be left behind.

,

The opportunity to bring insight to the HR profession has never been bigger – the knowledge to do it and the systems to support it both exist. As Bock says ‘there’s not a better time to be in it (HR) if you care about change and improvement’.

,

The article also provides a clue as to what Bock is planning next. Whilst he admits his new start-up is ‘very, very early in building this out’, it appears to be that he is developing an application that will help make work better and improve employee productivity. Bock teases that his team know what it will look like, they have the science behind it and that it will be available on mobile and as a plug-in to a corporate network. The intrigue and speculation that will undoubtedly accompany the application as it is built will make Bock’s new venture the HR technology version of the next Star Wars movie.

,

WATCH: Laszlo Bock on making work better

,

The article also delves into Bock’s thoughts on other subjects such as:

,

Read the full SHRM interview here.

,


,

All of us in the people analytics space owe a debt of gratitude to Bock. Whilst he and Google weren’t the first to embrace the possibilities of people analytics and data driven HR, he did more than anyone to popularise the space and provided an inspiration to other curious folk. Bock’s ‘Work Rules!’ book, published in 2015, should be on the bedside table of every forward-thinking CHRO or aspiring HR leader. That is why there is so much interest in what Bock does next and the advice he offers. For more on the impact that Bock has had on people analytics, read this wonderful tribute by Darren Kaplan.

,

WATCH: An animation of Laszlo Bock's Work Rules! book

,

I like how Bock classifies the two types of organisation/HR leader when it comes to people analytics, which tallies almost completely with what I have observed. Those that are curious or inspired by the opportunity analytics provides to help their companies make better decisions have typically succeeded in growing their capability in this area – especially when they exhibit these traits and competencies. However, ‘the doubters’ or those who are seemingly impotent in getting started (e.g. those I’ve come across at conferences who have been ‘thinking of getting started’ – bit still haven’t - for four years now) are being seriously left behind.

,

As Mark Twain is reputed to have said ‘the secret of getting ahead is getting started. The secret of getting started is breaking your complex overwhelming tasks into small manageable tasks, and starting on the first one’. Bock is an inspirational example for others in the HR fraternity who want to make a difference.

,
