column3: 6 Key takeaways from HR Tech Europe 2015
column5:
[

Those that think the pace of change we are experiencing now is too hot to handle may want to hold onto their hats as the speed of technological innovation, as popularised by the likes of Kurzweil, continues its relentless exponential growth.

,

The implications for business and the HR functions that are the custodians of their organisations talent are considerable. This was one of the overriding themes awaiting the 1,400 delegates as they gathered in London last week for the world’s fastest growing (as well as in my opinion the best curated and choreographed) HR event – HR Tech Europe.

,

As usual the organisers spoilt us with 11 differently themed parallel events and a plethora of outstanding speakers both within and beyond the world of HR, so picking out a handful of key takeaways is difficult, but here goes:

,

1. The network always wins = HR needs to enable (not block) the network

,

Peter Hinssen got the conference off to a tumultuous start with the Orwellian titled ‘The Network Always Wins’, which essentially challenged organisations – and critically the HR functions at their fulcrums - to move away from the 20th Century mindset of control, rigidity and silos. How can HR play a role in fuelling networks and enabling their respective organisations to stay ahead of the pack? Firstly, by allowing information to flow freely and unencumbered throughout the business and secondly, by taking a hammer to bureaucracy and sending the dreaded organisation chart the way of the dodo. Those that fail to grasp the mettle may not survive – see also ‘Never mind the bureaucracy, here’s Punk Rock organisational structures…’.

,

,

To help enable the flow of networks within the business, HR needs to lead the charge to abolish that outdated 20th Century concept - the organisation chart

,

2. Collaborate or die

,

Ex-acolyte of Bill Clinton and self-proclaimed expert on the collaborative economy, Rachel Botsman adopted a similar revolutionary zeal to Hinssen for her conferencing closing keynote on the ‘Future of Work’ in the collaborative economy. Botsman made a persuasive case that companies like Airbnb, Lyft, Wonolo, RecruitLoop, TaskRabbit and my personal favourite DogVacay are changing the way people use their time, skills and talents. The success of organisations like these is a huge threat to the old economy with whole industries (including the recruitment industry) set to disintegrate before our eyes in the next ten years. Employment legislation (particularly in Europe) will also come under pressure, but will this mean dismantling frameworks designed to protect employees? Or will it remove the red tape that holds organisations back and stymies competitiveness? That's a debate that's set to roll and roll.

,

Will the likes of Wonolo, TaskRabbit and RecruitLoop mean the end of the recruitment industry as we know it?

,

3. It’s time to stop just talking about HR Analytics and start actually doing it…

,

Volker Jacobs of CEB unveiled research that found whilst 100% of CXO believe they need HR data to make strategic decisions, only 19% have used HR data in the last year. Perhaps this is a contributory factor in why only 20% of HR transformations meet their targets? Certainly, the same CEB study concluded that the use of analytics led to 12% better talent outcomes (see below). The conference saw compelling presentations from the likes of LEGO Group and Google on how analytics underpins their people strategies. But the highlight of the two days from an HR analytics perspective was provided by Andrew Marritt of Organization View who did a live demonstration of analytics using open source software including a predictive modelling session using data from the Titanic – not the first time nor I fear the last that the HR function has been compared to the infamously doomed White Star liner.

,

Volker Jacobs of CEB illustrated how harnessing analytics leads to 12% better talent outcomes

,

4. Sometimes, great People Analytics can take time

,

It’s always fascinating to hear what the likes of Google are up to and Aimee O’Malley was on hand to talk about the tech giant’s gDNA initiative – something that certainly can’t be accused of lacking ambition. For the uninitiated, gDNA (see also HBR article here) is a 100 year project designed to improve understanding of productivity, engagement, how to cultivate leaders, how happiness impacts work and how work impacts happiness. The study is only three years old, but initial findings include that only 31% of Googlers are able to break free of the burden of blurring the balance between work and life – less than one in three maybe, but probably still a much better ratio than most companies I could mention.

,

5. But, do CEOs even care about HR?

,

Not according to Nick Holley of Henley Management College – or at least that’s the quote that was mistakenly attributed to him after last year’s conference in Amsterdam. Holley sought to nip the ensuing kerfuffle in the bud by explaining that what he meant was that CEOs were not interested in the traditional role of HR e.g. ensuring people are paid and receive their annual performance appraisal. But woe betide any budding HR leader that seeks to be ‘strategic’ before getting the basics right. Holley went on to reveal what CEOs DO want from their HR leaders (see Figure below), which interestingly valued integrity and courage above everything else.

,

Professor Nick Holley unveiled research from Henley Business School that found CEOs value integrity and courage from their HR leaders above everything else

,

6.There’s some really cool HR vendors

,

The conference floor a large of number of HR vendors displaying their wares and along with industry giants such as Workday, Oracle and IBM there were a number of companies I'd like to finish off my round-up by highlighting:

,

See you on the Champs-Élysées for HR Tech World Congress on 27-28th October for what promises to be some event.

,

column3: Robots vs Humans: where is the Future of Work heading?
column5:
[

Predicting the future can be a fool’s errand and as that scion of science fiction writing Arthur C Clarke observed, a concept that is increasingly part of a modern age where everyone seems to want to have a turn of playing Nostradamus:

,

Clarke may well have been thinking about artificial intelligence, robotics and the future of work when he penned this decidedly gloomy phrase. As technological progress gathers pace and more and more jobs are replaced by robots and software, is the future of work as bleak as the one painted by Clarke?

,

The biggest change since the Industrial Revolution

,

Whilst most commentators on the subject would agree that the next 10-15 years are going to see work change beyond recognition to an extent perhaps not seen since the industrial revolution, there are wildly opposing opinions on what the consequences will be.

,

These contrasting views were reflected in a fascinating study on AI, Robotics & the Future of Jobs (download full PDF here) conducted towards the end of last year by the US based PEW Research Center. The study asked close to 2,000 experts the following question: Will networked, automated, artificial intelligence applications and robotic devices have displaced more jobs than they have created by 2025?

,

Opinion was split pretty much down the middle with 48% envisioning a future in which robots and digital agents have displaced significant numbers of both blue- and white-collar workers. Moreover, many contributors expressed concern that this will lead to vast increases in income inequality, masses of people who are effectively unemployable, and breakdowns in the social order. This is the ‘doomsday’ scenario as also prophesied by the Luddites at the birth of the Industrial Revolution in England in the early 1800’s.

,

The other 52% surveyed took a more optimistic view believing technology will not displace more jobs than it creates even if they acknowledge that many jobs will be substantively taken over by robots or automation by 2025. These ‘anti-Luddites’ if you like, believe that just as transpired in the Industrial Revolution and indeed ever since, new jobs and industries will emerge to replace those lost to robots and AI.

,

We’re all doomed…

,

So which opinion will come to pass? Those in the pessimist camp will point to the fact that automation has already extended beyond the traditional blue-collar workers into professions previously thought immune such as lawyers, accountants, architects and even doctors. When it comes to speed and precision: solving mathematical equations, performing surgery and even driving cars computers will win every time.

,

The speed of progress will undoubtedly leave many people, countless organisations and most educational systems floundering as foretold by Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee in their oft quoted The Second Machine Age. The MIT professors warn that as technological process steams ahead:

,

A compelling and sobering thought.

,

…oh no, we’re not

,

But before ye abandon all hope and start smashing the machines in full Luddite style, one may want to consider that throughout history technology has been a net creator – not destroyer – of jobs.

,

This view is bolstered by the changing dynamics of labour supply and demand that will be prevalent in the workforce of 2030.

,

Indeed, as this entertaining Ted Talk from Rainer Strack of the Boston Consulting Group highlights, research by BCG (see Figure below) suggests that contrary to fears of mass unemployment as humans are supplanted by robots, 12 of the world's 15 largest economies (together representing 70% of the world's GDP), are actually projected to face a labour shortage by 2030.

,

Source: BCG 'The Global Workforce Crisis - $10 Trillion at risk'

,

Whilst Strack concedes that automation will make up some of the shortfall, predicting when, how quickly and to what extent is simply impossible to quantify. Indeed, Strack believes that AI and robotics are just as likely to compound the situation with the new jobs they will bring and the new skills the technology will require actually exacerbating the already serious labour shortages.

,

The future in Strack’s native country Germany is particularly stark with labour supply predicted to be 23% (or 8m workers) shy of demand by 2030. In this case, far from being a threat the benefits of AI, robotics and technology will be substantively required to prevent Europe’s biggest economy from contracting on a massive scale. Expect Kraftwerk’s - Düsseldorf’s finest - 1978 masterpiece ‘Die Roboter (We Are The Robots)’ to replace Das Deutschlandlied as the country’s national anthem come 2030.

,

Kraftwerk prepare themselves for the second machine age

,

What is HR’s role?

,

What about HR’s role in all this? The pace and extent of automation and the disappearance of old jobs and the emergence of new ones set against a climate of increasing labour shortages is perhaps the most tricky of a number of critical questions facing HR. Global strategic workforce planning is no longer a nice-to-have but an essential part of an HR leader’s toolkit if they are going to work with CXO to understand what jobs need to be filled in five, ten and fifteen years time.

,

How will HR bring more millennials, women, alumni and retirees into these newly highly skilled jobs? How will they adapt their corporate cultures to become a global destination for these employees? As work becomes more collaborative, more virtual, increasingly dependent on co-learning and context based, how will HR enable the fundamental changes that will be required to organisation structure and design?

,

Bureaucracy, hierarchy and the ghastly organisation chart are all likely to go the way of the dodo (see more here), which just goes to show that technology, automation and massive change can’t all be bad. Get strapped in HR and prepare yourself for the ride.

,

column3: 5 Things to look forward to at #HRAnalyticsLDN
column5:
[

As I wrote in my last post, many respected commentators such as Josh Bersin recently in Forbes have predicted that 2015 is the year that HR Analytics will finally go into orbit.

,

The timing therefore of the forthcoming HR & Workforce Analytics Innovation Summit at the London Crowne Plaza Docklands Hotel on 17th and 18th March 2015 couldn’t be better. I am fortunate to have been asked to reprise my role last year as Chairman and my company Cielo is one of the summit’s sponsors. Click here to register online - quote ‘CIELO20’ when booking for a 20% discount.

,

This year’s edition promises to be the best yet as the organisers have surpassed themselves in assembling a veritable who’s who of the HR Analytics world.

,

Here’s what I am particularly looking forward to:

,

1. Hear real-life case studies and solutions from all stages of the HR analytics journey

,

Perhaps the most striking aspect of the schedule for the two days is that it isn’t full of vendors selling their wares or industry thought leaders trying to foist big data onto a cynical bunch of HR leaders. Instead, it is HR leaders themselves telling their own stories of how they have successfully harnessed analytics. And these aren’t run of the mill organisations by any stretch. These are leaders in their field like Rolls Royce, Coca-Cola, Aviva and Nestlé

,

2. Meet and hear from the new breed of HR leader

,

To develop this point, one of the reasons I have heard repeatedly stated that HR struggles to supplant decisions based on intuition with ones founded upon data is that the latter is an alien concept to many senior career HR professionals. That may be true in some cases (our fictional HR Director being a prime example), but there is a new breed of HR leader emerging as evidenced by the stellar list of speakers at #HRAnalyticsLDN: Jabbar Sardar from Cafcass, Salvador Malo from Ericsson, Martin Oest from the Met and Hendrik Feddersen from the European Medicines Agency to name but four.

,

3. Break down the barriers to getting started with HR Analytics

,

According to oft quoted research by Bersin by Deloitte, only 14% of organisations have really got to grasps with HR Analytics, which leaves the vast majority that haven’t. Two of the barriers commonly cited are limited budget and resource as well as lack of knowledge. Both are addressed here. Andrew Gamlyn will outline the talent analytics journey on which he has embarked at SIG, despite the absence of any budget. Moreover, Day 2 will see a HR Analytics for Beginners Workshop, designed to help those organisations comprising the other 86% get started on the journey.

,

4. Learn how HR Analytics has progressed one year on

,

Some of the key takeaways from last year’s event included findings that that not many organisations were coupling strategic workforce planning and analytics, fewer had adopted predictive analytics and that non-HR ‘geeks’ were increasingly beginning to cross-pollinate HR and HR Analytics departments. One year on it will be fascinating to see how these themes have developed. Have more organisations managed to harness predictive analytics into their programmes? Will the call-to-arms pleas of the likes of Benjamin Taylor (see here) see more quants, physicists or chemists amongst the delegates? One thing’s for sure, the sheer pace of development in the HR Analytics space is likely to produce a number of pleasant surprises throughout the two days.

,

5. Network with senior-level HR Analytics thought leaders

,

Let’s be honest even with top subject matter and speakers, it’s the networking that makes events like these so invaluable. With a focused group of c150 senior-level HR Analytics thought leaders and delegates attending expect some fascinating discussions over the two days (and one night). I’m certainly looking forward to catching up with many of the leaders featured in my HR Analytics influencer series (see Part 1, Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4). See you there.

column3: HR Analytics - The New Gold Rush
column5:
[

Maybe it’s something in the water or perhaps it's simply the advent of a new year and all the hype that accompanies it, but it does seem there has been a visible momentum shift in in the adoption of analytics in HR.

,

Writing in Forbes, industry sage Josh Bersin boldly proclaims “the geeks have arrived in HR” and that HR departments are finally “getting serious about analytics. And I mean serious”. HR has been dipping its feet in the analytics ocean for years without fully taking the plunge, but Bersin asserts that instead of just “talking about the opportunity to apply data to people decisions, companies are now stepping up and making the investment.”

,

From my discussions with HR leaders I sense too that the accelerator pedal has been pressed to the floor even if many organisations are still in the embryonic stage of datifying their HR departments. On ERE, John Zappe latched onto Bersin’s article and cited supporting research from Wanted Analytics that the number of human resources jobs advertised in Q4 2014 requiring “big data” and analytical skills had risen markedly year-on-year by 54%.

,

Could we be on the precipice of the HR equivalent of a gold rush? CHROs and other CXO have watched with envy as companies as diverse as Unilever, ABN Amro, Shell and Sears have built HR analytics functions and reaped the benefits of applying a data driven approach to talent. HR has suddenly become an interesting career destination for a number of hitherto unlikely highly skilled ‘geeks’. In the same Forbes article, Bersin talks of “PhD statisticians, engineers, and computer scientists together, all working on people analytics for their companies”.

,

In another excellent recent article (A Quant, Physicist, & Chemist Walk Into HR), Benjamin Taylor – Chief Data Scientist (now that’s a job title and a half) at HireVue and one of the ‘geeks’ highlighted by Bersin explains what attracted him from Wall Street to HR. Taylor makes an irrefutable case of why HR is ripe for disruption, has multiple challenging data problems and demands cross-pollination from other industries. This clarion call defines why HR presents such a compelling career proposition if you just happen to be a nuclear physicist, chemist, mechanical engineer, data scientist or meteorologist.

,

However, before HR joyously exclaims ‘gold’, a note of caution. It wasn’t that long ago Bersin (yes, him again) published a fairly damning indictment of HR’s immaturity with analytics – see another Forbes article here. This study (see Figure below) showed that only 4% of companies had achieved the capability to perform “predictive analytics” on their workforce and only 14% had done any significant “statistical analysis” of employee data. This leaves a whopping 86% with fool’s gold rather than the genuine article. All the more reason to hope that Taylor’s call to arms for HR cross-pollination will be heeded.

,

Bersin by Deloitte's Talent Analytics Maturity Model

,

Initiatives like the CIPD led ‘Valuing Your Talent’, which aims to provide employers with a clearer understanding of, and common means of describing, the way in which people impact the performance of their organisation will certainly help HR sort the wood from the trees.

,

More help is on hand from a number of upcoming conferences that Cielo and I are fortunate enough to be supporting in the coming weeks, starting with in chronological order:

,

Time will tell if Bersin’s is right to call it as he has, but it does seem that the stars of HR analytics have finally aligned and 2015 will prove to be a pivotal year. Let’s hope so because as to paraphrase Mark Twain’s character Mulberry Sellers: “There’s gold in them thar data” and “there’s millions in it”.

column3: The 20 best HR Analytics articles of 2014
column5:
[

According to revered authorities such as Josh Bersin, 2015 promises to be the year that analytics goes mainstream in HR. As such, I thought it may be helpful to warm-up with a list of my favourite HR Analytics articles of 2014 (listed in no particular order):

,

1. iNostix – How HR Analytics will transform the world of hiring | @iNostix

,

Luk Smeyers and Jeroen Delmotte’s Leuven based firm iNostix is one of the most interesting and progressive vendors in the HR analytics space. This extends to their blog, which regularly churns out thoughtful and informative posts. The example selected persuasively provides five ways in which predictive analytics will transform recruiting.

,

2. Patrick Coolen – The 10 Golden Rules of HR Analytics | @PatrickCoolen

,

Patrick has developed a formidable reputation for his work at ABN AMRO where he has introduced predictive analytics into the HR space. Here he provides his version of the 10 commandments - related of course to HR analytics. For more on what Patrick has achieved at ABN AMRO check out this piece on the iNostix blog: The HR Analytics Journey at ABN AMRO.

,

3. Morten Kamp Andersen – 5 reasons why HR Analytics must sit in HR and 5 reasons why HR Analytics should not be located in HR | @MortenKamp

,

Morten’s excellent All About Human Capital blog has a number of gems on it (so do check it out) but if I had to pick one from 2014 it would be this two-part piece. It presents the case for and against HR Analytics being under the auspices of the HR department – they certainly provoked some healthy debate. If you were on the jury, how would you vote?

,

4. Andrew Marritt – 5 Types of HR Analytics Vendors | @AndrewMarritt

,

My co-chair at the People Analytics 2015 conference is one of the leading authorities in the HR Analytics space through his Organization View business. Andrew has published a series of blogs on LinkedIn - and several white papers that are well worth getting hold of. This one classifying the five types of HR Analytics vendors is a must-read for any CHRO considering ramping up their analytics efforts in 2015.

,

5. Ian O’Keefe - Exit HR Practitioners, Enter Talent Analytics Algorithms | @ianmokeefe

,

Ian runs the HR Analytics function at Sears and has driven a number of initiatives that have led to a direct and positive impact on the retail giant’s bottom line. Ian draws on his experience in this piece outlining, for example, how talent analytics algorithms can help drive individual productivity levels. Also check out Ian in conversation with iNostix on the HR Analytics Journey at Sears - it's hugely impressive stuff.

,

6. Dr John Sullivan - Why HR Needs to Get Serious and Adapt Workplace Analytics – Part 1 & Part 2 | @DrJohnSullivan

,

Sullivan’s pull-no-punches style has perhaps never been as powerful as in this two-part sermon on TLNT evangelising the irrefutable case for HR adopting data driven metrics and predictive analytics. Read it and prepare to be converted to the analytics cause.

,

7. Karen O’Leonard - Will HR Lose the Battle Over Analytics?

,

This excellent article from Karen O’Leonard of Bersin by Deloitte warns that as HR continues to drag its feet over adopting analytics it is running out of time before its cousins in Finance wrest control. Will HR get its act together in 2015 before it’s too late?

,

8. Josh Bersin, John Houston & Boy Kester – Talent Analytics in Practice: Go from talking to delivering on Big Data | @Josh_Bersin

,

O’Leonard’s article above draws on Bersin research that 86 percent of companies report no analytics capability in their HR function. In this detailed Deloitte University Press publication, Bersin and his cohorts outline how organisations can quickly go from talking (or even avoiding?) to delivering on HR analytics.

,

9. John Boudreau - What to do when you can’t predict your talent needs

,

In this HBR article, Professor Boudreau – one of the pioneers of HR analytics, explains why the ‘fox’ approach is better than the ‘hedgehog’ when it comes to coupling predictive analytics with strategic workplace planning. A must-read.

,

10. Jonathan Ferrar - Predictive Analytics: What Big Data Means for the Future of HR | @jaferrar

,

Jonathan leads strategy and product management for IBM’s Smarter Workforce and Big Blue features regularly in this piece that describes how HR as a function in flux needs to embrace analytics and be more data driven in its decision making.

,

11. Neil Morrison – You’re not as big as you think | @neilmorrison

,

Neil’s Change-Effect blog is widely and rightfully regarded as one of the premier HR blogs. His article from October arguing that for the vast majority of organisations data in HR is rarely ‘big’ really resonates.

,

12. Nathan R. Kuncel, Deniz S. Ones and David M. Klieger: In Hiring, Algorithms beat Instinct

,

According to this excellent HBR article, studies suggest that yes, algorithms do indeed beat instinct. Indeed, the authors recommend that a purely algorithmic system should be used to narrow the field with human judgment only called upon at the final selection stage. Controversial? Read the article and make your own mind up.

,

13. Matt Alder - Can you replace a recruiter with an algorithm? | @mattalder

,

Speaking of algorithms, this excellent article from November by Matt Alder ponders whether eHarmony is about to make a foray into the world of hiring, and if so what the implications are for all those recruiters out there.

,

14. Greta Roberts - From Human Screen to Machine: Predictive Analytics Helps Avoid a Major Point of Hiring Failure | @gretaroberts

,

In a similar vein, Greta – CEO of vendor Talent Analytics, outlines how predictive analytics can make significant improvements to the recruitment process and lead to hires that deliver more value to the organisation and drive business sustainability.

,

15. Benjamin Taylor – This is why your Data Scientist sucks | @bentaylordata

,

If HR is really going to get jiggy with analytics then chances are they will need to hire some data scientists. Here, Benjamin Taylor – Chief Data Scientist at HireVue (do check out their HireVue Insights product) shares his perspective and experiences.

,

16. Dave Millner: HR 2020: We Need Data Scientists Now! | @HRCurator

,

Just in case you hadn’t quite got the fact that more data scientists are needed in HR, this article by Dave Millner rams the message home further. If only Mario Balotelli was this clinical in front of goal...

,

17. CEB blogs - HR: Applying business judgement to data science | @CEB_HR

,

As a third musketeer to the above entries from Benjamin Taylor and Dave Millner, this article on the CEB blog balances the need for data and analytical expertise with the ability to use business and organisational knowledge to draw conclusions from talent data.

,

18. Josh Bersin – 2015 HR Predictions: #7 Leaders will invest in talent analytics and workforce planning | @Josh_Bersin

,

Every year leading industry analyst Bersin by Deloitte make their annual HR predictions. This year (as admittedly in previous years) Bersin predicts that leaders will invest heavily in talent analytics and workforce planning. Surely, Bersin will be proved right this year, won’t he?

,

19. Beth Ellyn Rosenthal - Why ConAgra Foods Decided to Outsource HR Analytics After Doing It In house

,

Talking about Mark Berry (who is cited in the Bersin's article above as a prototype leader in the HR Analytics space): this article on Outsourcing Center, describes how Mark built the HR Analytics function at ConAgra Foods from scratch and then, in order to take things to the next level, decided to outsource to an external partner.

,

Finally, if you’ve enjoyed these articles you may also want to have a read of some of the articles I’ve written on the subject:

,

column3: 10 Predictions for HR & Recruiting in 2015 - Part 2
column5:
[

Yesterday, I published Part One of my admittedly optimistic predictions for HR and Recruiting in 2015, so without further ado let’s crack on with the second and final part – predictions 6-10.

,

6. Anyone mentioning the ‘War for Talent’ is replaced by a robot

,

HR is full of lazy and over-used phrases like “seat at the table”, "process" and arguably “no”, but the one that really gets my goat is “war for talent”. It was first coined by McKinsey all the way back in 1997 when reality TV mercifully didn’t exist and yours truly was just embarking on a new career as a recruiter. When it comes to marketing slogans, analogies with wars – like sex – sells, but surely when it comes to the war for talent, isn’t it time for a new idiom? Let’s make 2015 the year that anyone in or connected to HR will be ridiculed and replaced by a robot for daring to mention this tedious phrase.

,

7. Someone (anyone?) gives LinkedIn a run for its money

,

Whilst I’m a paid up member of the LinkedIn fan club, it’s about time someone took them on before hubris or megalomania sets in (some may argue it already has). It doesn’t matter really if it is Facebook at Work (see Wired article), Indeed (see this ere.net article) or Google for Work or even better all of them. It will be interesting to see how LinkedIn react once someone starts to muscle in on their patch – one suspects that the cycle of spiraling costs may turn full cycle. So come on Zuckerberg, get on with it.

,

8. Candidate experience gets taken more seriously

,

With both scarcity and demand rising, top candidates have a multitude of options, so candidate experience is going to become increasingly important. These candidates aren’t going to spend time trying to decipher information on your organisation and how to apply. If it took 30 minutes to buy the average item on Amazon, how long do you think the company would survive? Not long. So, why do so many organisations put their candidates through purgatory by making them complete a ridiculously long application through an ATS? Indeed, as this excellent post by David Smooke on the Smart Recruiters blog suggests many organisations ATS have effectively become a HPS – a Hiring Prevention System. Is a passive candidate having been nurtured to the virtues of your organisation more likely to apply via an elongated ATS process or with one click from their LinkedIn profile? It’s not rocket science. Nor is ensuring your site is fully optimised for mobile. People do most of their web browsing, research, and job-hunting on their phone or tablet - LinkedIn doesn’t design its new features for mobile first to try and be clever. Organisations that fail to recognise this and provide a poor candidate experience will miss out on some great hires - and business as they decide to shop elsewhere.

,

9. ...so does employer brand.

,

Most organisations get how important their consumer brand is but neglect to give equal focus to their employer brand. Of course they are equally important especially when you consider that great products and services (and by linkage customers) need great talent to shape, design and deliver them. You can’t have one without the other and when that talent is scarce and in high demand, the messages and communication strategies used to spark potential candidate interest is paramount and needs to be personalised and nuanced for different target groups. Research from Lippincott and LinkedIn (see here) found companies with strong consumer and employer brands financially outperform their peers by 36%. So it is perhaps not surprising that Andy Curlewis, who heads up Cielo’s Global Brand & Digital practice, has been rushed off his feet in 2014. As employer brand goes into orbit, I expect that his feet won’t even touch the floor in 2015. Serves him right for being an Arsenal fan!

,

10. HR becomes an agent of change as opposed to blocking it

,

This could be my most wildly optimistic prediction of all, but as the pace of change intensifies and as the old ponderous bureaucratic ways of doing things continue to fail (why else would over 50% of the Fortune 500 from 2000 no longer be in existence?), HR needs to move from change blocker to change agent. Yes, it needs to consistently talk the language of the business and change its mindset of being a cost centre, but more importantly HR needs to be brave. It needs to embrace the opportunities offered through flux, changing employee attitudes, neuroscience, HR Analytics and technology to create real and lasting change in how talent is identified, recruited, activated and retained. Will this happen in 2015? Probably not but let’s at least start the New Year with a modicum of optimism.

,

column3: 10 Predictions for HR & Recruiting in 2015 - Part 1
column5:
[

Unless your name is Nostradamus, predicting the future is a mugs game. Well that’s my excuse anyway for the lack of prescience in my (admittedly optimistic) 2014 predictions for HR and talent acquisition (see links at bottom of this article).

,

Nevertheless whilst it is tempting to swap the word ‘predictions’ for ‘hopes’, like a lemming being merrily edged towards the precipice of a cliff, it’s time to take the plunge again.

,

Part 1 with predictions 1-5 is presented below, with Part 2 here:

,

1. HR destroys bureaucracy instead of cultivating it

,

Like those other discredited 20th century doctrines, communism and fascism, bureaucracy is way past its sell by date. Bureaucracy is more lethal than a particularly virile dose of salmonella and eats away at a company’s very soul. Instead of protecting it and allowing bureaucracy to multiply through mindless process, unnecessary approval flows and the dreaded organisation chart, HR needs to switch camps, don its superhero capes and stamp out bureaucracy wherever it finds it. Instead of Rules, Precedent, Hierarchy and Fear, let’s see more Values, Transparency, Aspiration and Peers.

,

2. Organisation charts start to disappear

,

One of the key tools of the oppressors is the organisation chart, which is arguably just as defunct as bureaucracy itself. How many organisation charts actually reflect reality? As the number of flexible workers grows the ability to capture this in an organisation chart diminishes. Organisation charts also imply that the ability to innovate and make decisions resides only in the upper echelons of the business. It doesn’t. Not anymore. Not in the creative knowledge economy we are now thankfully in. It’s time to send organisation charts the way of the dodo.

,

3. The death of the traditional annual performance review

,

Speaking of pointless and outdated tools and practices, hands up who thinks the annual performance review actually has any relevance? Not many hands. Ok, hands up who thinks they are a complete waste of time, money and effort? Nearly unanimous. How about employees regularly rating their immediate peers in order of how much value they provide? Now we’re talking. Over to you HR…

,

4. HR finally gets jiggy with analytics – and predictive analytics

,

This prediction didn’t come to pass last year, but that’s not going to stop me from boldly stating that 2015 will be the year that HR stops just talking about analytics but actually embraces it like its cousins in Finance and Marketing; not necessarily to replace traditional intuition but to validate it by making decisions that are also based on data. Moreover, predictive analytics that accurately predict hiring success, employee performance and retention will enable HR to be true partners to the business and helping drive long-term success.

,

5. Cost per hire loses its exaggerated importance

,

There aren’t many decisions more important to a business than determining who it hires. A cheap approach that leads to poor hires is one of the worst decisions a business can make. So why do many HR departments, Talent Acquisition functions and RPO companies focus solely on this single potentially harmful metric? 2015 will see the conversation become more rounded to include quality, agility, productivity and ultimately ROI because we all know that Cost Per Hire is the wrong recruiting metric Gromit. Don't we?

,

Predictions 6 to 10 follow tomorrow.

,

#HR #Recruiting #HumanResources #BigIdeas2015 #Hiring

column3: Cost Per Hire: "It's the wrong recruiting metric, Gromit"
column5:
[

I spend a fair amount of time helping companies build business cases to transform their recruiting functions. I never cease to be amazed by the myopic focus on cost per hire at the expense of everything else. Talk of return on investment (ROI) is rarer than a sighting of Haley’s Comet.

,

In every other business function whilst cost is an important factor, it is only part of a wider analysis on the value of outcomes produced by that expenditure. So why should this be different for HR and Resourcing?

,

The easy option?

,

McKinsey and The Conference Board's 2012 report on the Human Capital function – False Summit - provides a clue that you don't need to be Sherlock Holmes to latch on to. It concludes that HR has an inherent inability to relate the ROI or business impact of the function. Cost per hire, on the other hand, is comparatively straightforward to calculate.

,

Confirmation comes from the Society for Human Resources Management (SHRM), which describes itself as the world’s largest HR membership organisation. SHRM notes that many organisations monitor and calculate cost per hire data, as opposed to other HR metrics that may be more difficult to measure, because the components which make up the cost per hire calculation are frequently easy to calculate and track.

,

HR vendors including many Recruitment Process Outsourcing (RPO) companies have to take their share of the blame too. They have been too willing to participate in a race to the bottom in terms of price, rather than accentuating less tangible benefits centred on quality of hire. It seems cost per hire myopia is dangerously contagious.

,

Being hostage to cost is expensive

,

In reality of course, this zealous obsession with cost per hire is injurious. One doesn’t need to be a rocket (or indeed a data) scientist to deduce that continually shaving pounds and pence from hiring costs will eventually decrease quality, damage candidate experience and result in an increase in new hire attrition. This of course snowballs the total cost of recruitment by increasing the number of hires necessary to back-fill positions. Going down this road has to be recruiting equivalent of shooting yourself in the foot. Ouch!

,

Moving the conversation on to value

,

There is plenty of evidence showing how short-sighted this myopic approach is. Research from the Boston Consulting Group (see here) found a direct link between the capability of a company’s HR function and its business performance. Indeed, as the graphic below illustrates delivering on recruiting came out right at the top of the list. Companies adept at recruiting enjoyed 3.5 times the revenue growth and 2.0 times the profit margin of their less capable peers. This represents an irrefutable case to move the discussion on from cost.

,

Source: BCG - Creating People Advantage

,

We recently hosted a Think Tank for global resourcing leaders and their procurement counterparts in London on building the business case for global transformation. Consensus amongst delegates was pretty much unanimous that the conversation needs to shift from cost to value.

,

Getting jiggy with Procurement and data

,

Procurement can help HR build different business case scenarios based on ROI. It is surprising therefore that this bridge to the Finance department is rarely exploited. Too often the Procurement function is used by HR merely as a facilitator of RFPs and occasionally the dreaded e-Auction (surely a completely inappropriate mechanism for selecting a resourcing partner?).

,

Instead of going down the easy and one-dimensional cost per hire road, HR and resourcing functions need to be braver. They need to put data at the forefront of their decision making, be comfortable working with assumptions and translate all this into business cases that provide insight, different scenarios and demonstrable ROI. All this may help shift the perception within the business of HR being seen solely as a cost centre. Effective HR and Talent Acquisition strategies can drive business transformation.

,

Say hello, wave goodbye

,

For those that are content to continue living in the dark ages and believe that cost per hire is the recruiting equivalent of Nirvana, you may want to consider the following:

,

Whilst cost is important to track, it shouldn’t come at the expense of quality. It is just one indicator of the performance of a recruiting function. It should be measured alongside the likes of agility (time to hire, time to productivity) and quality as part of a comprehensive calculation of ROI.

,

column3: Never mind the Bureaucracy, here’s punk rock org structures...
column5:
[

I wonder if this is what it felt like to be in Paris in the late 1780s, St Petersburg as 1916 became 1917 or East Berlin as the 1980s drew to a close?

,

The hum of rebellion is palpable. The rot of discontent is in the air. Across the globe employee engagement levels are at an all-time low. Big companies have disappeared into the ether at an unprecedented rate (52% of the Fortune 500 of 2000 no longer exist). Every day we dutifully leave our 21st Century homes and travel back in time to our 20th Century workplaces.

,

Yet just as Erich Honecker and his East German politburo desperately tried to cling on to the last vestiges of power as the Berlin Wall came tumbling down around them, and Communism was shown to be a doctrine way past its sell by date; so CXO do the same with that other outmoded 20th Century dictatorial phenomena - bureaucracy.

,

But what is the alternative to Max Weber’s nightmarish vision?

,

Zappos and Holacracy

,

2014 was only into its third day when I learnt my first new word of the year.

,

The word was ‘Holacracy’ and it appeared in The Washington Post revealing how Amazon owned on-line retailer Zappos had decided to restructure under a new ‘radical’ organisational model.

,

To the uninitiated, Zappos CEO Tony Hsieh rivals Marissa Mayer as the business leader most likely to provoke comment from the HR community. But whereas Yahoo’s CEO deals in the contentious like zapping (see what I did there?) remote workers or poor performers via the stacked curve (another archaic 20th Century practice that even Microsoft has abandoned), Hsieh prefers the more unconventional route.

,

So what is Holacracy? Well according to Zappos’ own website:

,

At first glance, it all sounds a little bit anarchic, which as a childhood punk I have to admit has some appeal. You read it here first: Zappos does Punk Rock organisational structures. Zappos was advised by a management consultant (but don’t let that put you off) by the name of Brian Robertson, the founder of HolacracyOne - no self-interest there then, but do stay with us.

,

This article on Quartz explains the reasons behind Hsieh’s radical move, which was predicated on a desire to scale Zappos without letting bureaucracy set in.

,

Whilst Hsieh’s move created a whirlwind of publicity (no accident, one presumes), Zappos is not the only company to turn their noses up when it comes to bureaucracy.

,

Bureaucracy gets Hamel-ed

,

Indeed, the revolt against bureaucracy has its own Lech Wałęsa or Václav Havel figure in Professor Gary Hamel – see the excellent ‘Bureaucracy Must Die’ Forbes article for evidence. As detailed in my previous blog rounding up the highlights of HR Tech Europe 2014, Hamel put in a barnstorming performance to close the conference as he railed against the evils of bureaucracy. He also provided several examples of companies that like Zappos (but without the publicity hungry machine behind it) had sought a different path from Orwellian bureaucracy.

,

Now here’s a thing. The likes of Morning Star, Semco and WL Gore aren’t trendy tech companies like Zappos. Yet all have eschewed traditional management structures, possess highly engaged and empowered workforces and all (something to get CXO excited here) have better business performance and market share than their peers. Relinquish control and reap the dividends.

,

Another example is Handelsbanken, Sweden’s largest and most profitable bank and unlike all of its less nimble competitors a company that grew during the Swedish banking crisis of the 1990’s as well as the global financial crisis of the last six years. Handelsbanken is almost completely decentralised with power devolved to local branches rather than residing at the centre and has only three layers of management: CEO, Head of Regional Office and Branch Manager. No FOREX or Libor scandals here.

,

New century, new ideas - Choose Your Own Boss...

,

The 21st century is completely different from its 20th century forefather. The age of organisation has morphed into the age of creativity (as brilliantly articulated by Richard Florida in ‘The Rise of the Creative Class’). Speed now trumps process. Innovation is no longer the sole preserve of a small executive elite and employees are no longer prepared to tolerate being constrained in a box.

,

Hamel argues that it is way past time for Management 2.0 – a reboot where Values, Transparency, Aspiration and Peers replace Rules, Precedent, Hierarchy and Fear. And he has a manifesto – as referenced by Gareth Jones in his excellent ‘Management Innovation is the new HR technology’ piece on the HR Tech Europe blog:

,

Think BYOD is radical? How about CYOB – Choose Your Own Boss? Well, we vote for our politicians, so why not our leaders too?

,

I’m sold. Are you? Maybe Zappos’ holacracy move isn’t so wacky after all…

,

column3: Vive la Révolution: Key Takeaways from HR Tech Europe 2014
column5:
[

Two days, ten streams 150 speakers, 2,142 delegates and a lot of Heineken. The fourth (and final) HR Tech Europe Conference in Amsterdam flew by at a pace at which no HR Transformation could hope to compete with.

,

Revolution was in the air throughout the two days and that is hardly a surprise. Employee engagement is at an all-time low as employees are forced to take a time machine every day from their 21st century homes to their 20th century offices and employers.

,

Picking out just a handful of key takeaways is difficult, but here goes…

,

1. It’s way past time for a Management reboot and an end to the tyranny of bureaucracy

,

In a barnstorming close to the conference, management guru Professor Gary Hamel ripped into the archaic so last century bureaucratic hierarchical organisations that stifle innovation, decimate engagement and fail in the new creative economy. There is a reason why 52% of the Fortune 500 of 2000 have disappeared into the vapour - Max Weber’s nightmarish bureaucratic vision is no longer relevant. Speed trumps process, innovation is no longer the sole preserve of a small executive elite and employees are no longer prepared to tolerate being constrained in a box. Hamel argued that it is way past time for Management 2.0 – a reboot where Values, Transparency, Aspiration and Peers replace Rules, Precedent, Hierarchy and Fear. Companies as diverse as Semco, WL Gore and Morning Star (that's tomatoes not communism) have already embraced this new reality. Consequently, they all have engaged and empowered workforces and outperform their competition by a country mile. Think BYOD is radical? How about CYOB – Choose Your Own Boss?

,

I’m not sure if Hamel’s speech will ever be available on the HR Tech Europe YouTube channel, but if it is it should be mandatory viewing for all CEOs. Many of the presentations are available on the HR Tech Europe Slideshare page.

,

2. Simplicity. Beautiful Data. Digital Artisans.

,

Hamel’s was one of many great keynotes. To pick another three: Yves Morieux’s “Smart Simplicity” conference opener really resonated with the audience and was sprinkled with Gallic humour. Then David McCandless’ potent mix of data, visuals and humour proved beyond doubt that HR information is indeed beautiful (check out these visuals). Finally in a perfect antidote to the fuzzy heads caused by Thursday night’s parties (thanks Broadbean), Ray Wang opened up day two with an energetic performance as he prowled the main stage like a ravenous panther. Wang argued that it was proficiency rather than age that is the real digital barometer and eulogised digital artisans as the catalysts that will change the way companies think, design and deliver in the digital era. With his ability to sign up the best players around, if only HR Tech Europe’s head honcho Marc Coleman also ran transfer strategy for Brendan Rodgers at Liverpool…

,

3. HR is being disrupted

,

If the mood on the main stage was revolutionary, HR’s Bastille was breached continuously on the conference fringes. The #disruptHR zone saw raconteurs like William Tincup and Bill Boorman rubbing shoulders with start-ups like iNostix, Joberate, Recrout, Talmundo and SmartRecruiters. Other disruptive influences included the wonderfully laconic John Sumser whose ‘Computational HR’ described how the likes of Gild and IBM are taking HR into the realms of neuroscience – all it needed was an ominous Kraftwerk soundtrack to complete the futurist zeal. It wasn’t just the analysts and start-ups ripping up the rule book either - Dave Buglass had heads nodding as he described the journey of Tesco Bank from niche business to one with a full service offering.

,

4. How much longer will HR Analytics be the Elephant in the room?

,

HR analytics were omnipresent. Josh Bersin cited big data as the elephant in the room and one of three technology trends HR can’t afford to ignore. Holger Mueller outlined how analytics will increasingly disrupt HR and why recruiting is its biggest showcase. This was certainly evident in pitches made by the likes of Joberate and iNostix in the #disruptHR zone and also Patrick Coolen’s ‘Towards Fact Based HR’, which presented how harnessing predictive HR analytics has enabled improved business performance at ABN AMRO. There is a reason why IBM has bet its entire future on analytics, and even for HR this will become increasingly clear.

,

5. What of the HR Tech beasts?

,

The big three – Oracle, SuccessFactors and Workday were a ubiquitous presence and a number of their customers stood up to espouse the not insignificant benefits their organisations had gained from implementing their technology. Gareth Williams offered a particularly compelling case as to how Workday had proved a catalyst for change at Travelex. The Talking Heads session was fun as the big three squirmed uncomfortably in their chairs as Jason Averbook mischievously (and repeatedly) asked the leaders of Workday, SuccessFactors and Oracle to outline why they were better than the other two. For once all three seemed remarkably coy and as Holger Mueller observed sought to spin in unison. It will certainly be interesting to observe how these companies evolve as the predictions of the like of Hamel, Wang and Sumser take hold – will they be able to keep up with the pace and extent of change?

,

And finally...Guillotines at the ready; the revolution will be televised

,

Ancien régime diehards beware, the guillotines are being sharpened as the fastest growing and indisputably best HR conference (and before you ask, I was not paid to write that) heads to the Palais des Congrès in Paris next year. Whilst it will be difficult to top 2014 - the cherry on the top being the cool android badges for the kids from Google for Work - do you know I think Marc and his intrepid team might just succeed.

,

See you on the Champs-Élysées.

,

column3: 5 Things I'm Looking Forward To At #HRTechEurope
column5:
[

Cielo (check out our Talent Activation Index) is one of the sponsors of HR Tech Europe, which takes place in Amsterdam on 23rd and 24th October. Considered as Europe's most important HR event and claiming to influence more than 20m people, over 2,000 delegates are expected (a 30% increase on 2013) with the vast majority being HR decision makers. As part of the official Blog Squad, I will be posting throughout the event.

,

Whilst HR should be a case of strategy first, technology second, if you work in the HR space, you’re in the HR Tech industry - you simply can’t do your job without your systems functioning at peak performance.

,

The world of work is changing increasingly rapidly as we hurtle towards the much heralded Workplace 2020. The power of ‘networks’ is all encompassing and businesses face the not inconsiderable challenge of whether this growing band of global, expert, connected and mobile workers can best thrive within traditional hierarchical structures.

,

The convergence of consumer and employer brands, business and talent analytics as well as cloud and mobile has changed the playing field. At the same time, the lens on HR and Talent functions has never been so intense. Surveys of CEOs regularly cite talent as the key concern of business leaders, but most HR functions are failing to live up to the weighty expectations placed on their shoulders.

,

How will companies become networks and communities themselves, and evolve from static structures? How will we harness and decipher Big Data and let predictive talent analytics flourish? How can HR leaders capitalise on collaborative technology and the cloud? Perhaps most pertinently, when will HR and talent functions start talking the language of the business, which is economics and not talent management mumbo jumbo?

,

Whilst the conference cannot be expected to answer all these questions, it should provide several clues as to how organisations can tackle the state of flux we find ourselves in whilst providing a barometer as to how far HR is on the journey.

,

Here’s what I am particularly looking forward to:

,

1. Checking out the next generation of disruptive HR Technology

,

Whilst the big boys like Oracle, SAP, IBM and Workday will have a vast and visible presence, it is the new kids on the block that will hold my gaze. A great new addition this year is the Disrupt HR stream, where young agile start-ups will step into the Innovations Zone for a Warhol-esque 15 minutes of show and tell sessions that will provide a real sense of what’s really disrupting HR. Look out for the likes of iNostix, Joberate, Social Talent, GooodJob and eiTalent.

,

2. Predictive Talent Analytics

,

Analytics is HR’s big opportunity to deliver insights to the C-Suite that can predict the likely business outcomes of a whole raft of talent initiatives. It is disappointing therefore that research from the likes of Bersin continues to highlight that less than 5% of companies have achieved the level to perform predictive talent analytics and not many more have done any substantive statistical analysis of employee data at all. Talent Analytics is one of the key themes of the two days and it will be fascinating to hear whether the HR community sees Talent Analytics as an opportunity or a threat. Look out for Patrick Coolen of ABN AMRO’s session on 'Fact Based HR' and the keynote from David McCandless entitled ‘HR Information is Beautiful’. Many of our recently published ‘Who’s Who of HR Analytics’ will be present over the two days – see Part 1, Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4 to check out the key influencers in this burgeoning area of HR.

,

3. The Future is Digital

,

One of the keynotes is being delivered by Ray Wang, Founder and Principal Analyst at Constellation Research. He will outline why organisations are no longer just selling products and services but also outcomes and experiences that support a brand promise. This will have a huge impact not just on the skillsets business requires but on the digital outlook it needs to embrace. Ray will explain how organisations can build digital artisans and why they are needed in the era of complete transparency.

,

4. Be inspired by great speakers

,

One of the reasons that HR Tech Europe is so well attended is - like Liverpool in this summer’s transfer window - no expense has been spared on assembling a crack list of industry thought leaders and innovators (the organisers have done much better than Brendan Rodgers in this regard – thankfully Mario Balotelli will not be in Amsterdam). Those of you who have seen Jason Averbook in full flow, will know that there are not many better or more knowledgeable presenters in this field around. Other speakers not already mentioned that I am looking forward to hearing include Josh Bersin, Yves Morieux, Gary Hamel, John Sumser and Naomi Bloom whilst Nick Holley’s provocatively titled ‘Traditional Talent Management is Dead’ and Gareth Williams, Group HR Director at Travelex’s ‘The Future is Cloud’ both promise to be interesting. With 99 speakers to choose from, delegates are hardly spoilt for choice.

,

5. Network, network, network; blog, blog, blog...

,

Let’s be honest even with top subject matter and speakers, it’s the networking that makes events like these so invaluable. With over 2,000 delegates attending, the two days (and nights) are a fantastic opportunity to mix with some of the crème de la crème of the HR and HR Technology world. With the added plus of being part of the official Blog Squad allied to all that networking, I don’t expect much banter about the red lights (or even tulips) of Amsterdam; much more likely there will be plenty of red eyes come the end of the event.

,

column3: Top 72 HR Analytics Influencers - Part 4
column5:
[

Over the last three posts, I’ve published a three part series of what was initially 50 and is now 72 HR Analytics Influencers – see Part 1, Part 2 and Part 3. I’ve been overwhelmed by the response so thanks to everyone who has taken the time to read, comment, share and like.

,

As I suspected the growing interest in HR Analytics – evidenced again in the agenda of the recent HR Tech Conference in Las Vegas and HR Tech Europe conference in Amsterdam - and the absence of a list (I couldn’t find one anyway) compiling some of those who are driving this movement forward meant this series would prove to be a useful resource and provoke some discussion. Even better some of those already named have told me they have been contacted as a result with business opportunities. Every little helps as Tesco might say.

,

My original collection of 50 was never going to be definitive and I knew at the outset that I will have unknowingly omitted many influencers who should have been included. This has certainly proven to be the case – hence this fourth instalment making a round 72 - hey, who said data was perfect.

,

John Austin - Organisational Psychologist and CEO of Talegent, a provider of talent measurement solutions. John sold his previous business Talent Technologies to PreVisor (now CEB) in 2007. Follow on Twitter @JohnAAustin.

,

Laurie Bassi – Recommended by Salvatore Falletta (see below), Laurie is CEO of McBassi & Company whose raison d'être is to help organisations maximise their return on people by linking human capital metrics to future business results. Follow on Twitter @ljbassi.

,

Mark Berry – Mark has built the talent analytics function at ConAgra Foods from the ground up as this article describes. Follow on Twitter @s_markberry.

,

John Boudreau – One of the pioneers of HR analytics and measurement, John, a Professor at the University of Southern California, is recognised widely for breakthrough research on the bridge between superior human capital, talent and sustainable competitive advantage.

,

Marcus Champ – A regular contributor to the Measuring Human Capital LinkedIn Group, Marcus is a behavioural scientist with a passion for harnessing data to make better decisions and maximise the performance potential of organisations.

,

Salvatore Falletta - formerly led Intel’s HR research and analytics function, Sal now serves as the EVP/MD of the Organizational Intelligence Institute. He coined the concept of “HR intelligence” in 2000 and recently published the findings of The HR Analytics Project – the largest project to date in terms of number of participating companies (220 distinct Fortune 1000 & select global firms) and presents in the US & abroad on the topic.

,

Jac Fitz-enz - acknowledged as the father of human capital strategic analysis and measurement. He published the first human resources metrics in 1978 and later launched the discussion around “predictive analytics”.

,

Adam Grant – Professor of Management and Psychology at the Wharton School and author of the bestseller ‘Give and Take’.

,

Placid Jover – Recommended by a number of commentators, Placid leads HR Organisation, Performance and Analytics at consumer goods behemoth Unilever.

,

Michael Kennedy – the self-monikered ‘Analytics Evangelist’ works alongside fellow influencers Greta Roberts and Pasha Roberts (see Part 3) at Talent Analytics, one of the pioneering providers of predictive HR analytics. Follow on Twitter @TalentAnalytics.

,

Alec Levenson – an economist, Alec works with companies to optimise job and organisation performance and HR systems through the application of organisation design, job design, human capital analytics and strategic talent management.

,

John R Mattox – Director of Research at KnowledgeAdvisors, now part of CEB, John has created a number of predictive analytics models and recently co-authored ‘Predictive Analytics for Human Resources’ with Jac Fitz-enz (see above).

,

Alan Paling – Recommended by a couple of commentators, Alan is responsible for HR Analytics and MI for the Retail and Business Banking division of Barclays.

,

Gene Pease – CEO of Vestrics, a leading provider of predictive talent analytics, which was recognised by CIO Review Magazine as one of the Top 20 Most Promising Data Analytics Companies of 2013. Follow on Twitter @genepease7.

,

Michael Rosenbaum – CEO at Pegged Software which, as recently reported in the Washington Post, provides software that automates hiring decisions, and in doing so reduces turnover, hiring costs, and hiring time.

,

James Sesil – author of 2013’s Applying Advanced Analytics to HR Management Decisions, James is also developing state-of-the-art HR decision support software utilising the newest machine learning and AI technologies, which sounds riveting.

,

Naveen Seshardi – works closely with Ian O’Keefe (see Part 3) at Sears on driving analytical insights through personalisation of data to every employee using Gamification and HR Analytics to drive better engagement and increased productivity at work. Follow on Twitter @NaveenSesh.

,

Gene Tange – recommended by fellow influencer Kevin Wheeler, Gene is CEO at PearlHPS – a SaaS/Cloud enabled Predictive Analytics Platform that visually displays success probability for critical business initiatives 12 months in the future with an 80% accuracy claim.

,

Benjamin Taylor - Leads the data science team at HireVue and purveyor of very good (and very witty) blogs on cloud, predictive recruiting analytics and 'predicting the unpredictable'. Follow on Twitter @bentaylordata.

,

Heather Torres - Responsible for recruiting analytics at Facebook, having previously performed a similar role at AOL.

,

David Green – Last and definitely least - call it a bonus, if you like, to make a round number of 72. I enjoy writing and speaking on Talent Analytics and believe it is inevitable that HR will eventually be driven more by data than intuition. I guess that puts me in the optimist camp. Please feel free to connect on LinkedIn and follow me on Twitter @david_green_uk.

column5:
[

There are more ‘Top HR Influencer’ lists than you can shake a stick at, but up until recently one focusing on Top HR Analytics Influencers was much harder to find (I couldn’t find one, but that might just be me).

,

I felt this was an anomaly especially as I am regularly contacted by HR leaders and other interested parties alike asking not just why HR should adopt a more data driven approach, where they should start and how they can implement it, but more specifically who can help them.

,

This led me to compile (initially) a list of the Top 50 HR Analytics Influencers, which I published in three parts two months ago. A fourth part collecting some of the influencers I had missed took the list to 72.

,

The feedback and response to the series of articles has been fantastic – so thanks to everyone who has taken the time to read, share and comment. I’ve also had great feedback from the influencers themselves. A number have advised that the flow of career, speaking and business opportunities coming their way has risen since the series was published.

,

Correlation? It would appear so. Causation? Maybe…

,

It is humbling to have helped – even in a small way – to increasing the profile of HR Analytics and those that are pioneering its use within (arguably) the last bastion of business to embrace a data driven approach. As such, I am republishing the series over the next week or so. Again, please let me know what influencers I have missed and who should be added.

,

See also Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4 here.

,

Morten Kamp Andersen – Ex-investment banker who has swapped corporate finance for a new mission of making the Head of HR as important as the CFO. Follow on Twitter @MortenKamp and check out his excellent All About Human Capital blog here.

column3: 5 key takeaways from #HRTechEurope 2.013
column5:
[

,

My company, Cielo (previously Pinstripe & Ochre House) is once again sponsoring the HR Tech Europe conference in Amsterdam on 23-24 October - the largest and premier gathering in Europe of professionals in the HR and Recruitment technology space. In the run-up and immediate aftermath, I’ll be publishing a number of blogs on the conference. This first one looks back at my key takeaways from last year:

,

The pulse on the floor in 2013 was that HR was playing catch-up, so it will be interesting to see the progress made in the last 12 months:

,

1. In chaos, there is opportunity

,

Radical changes are taking place in almost everything we do in business today. Standing still is not an option. If businesses fail to be agile and don’t continue to innovate then they will die. Blackberry has gone from 51% market penetration to 3% in four years. How do you fail so badly? By failing to innovate, being complacent and by having less deep specialist expertise than your competitors – the last in particular is a call to arms for HR and Talent Management professionals. Ten years ago, the average organisation was involved in M&A activity every 7.2 years; now it is every nine months. Integrating M&A talent quickly and seamlessly – without losing it - is of paramount importance – and the responsibility for this resides squarely with HR. Amidst the chaos and sheer velocity of change, HR has an opportunity to become the architect of the organisation. Hiring, integrating, developing and retaining talent in parallel with developing the context, values and processes that the new generation of employees with their different values, mindsets and priorities demand is a tough challenge. But if HR can grasp it, they can secure their role within the organisation and actually increase their influence at the top table.

,

,

2. The future of work is already here

,

The new technologies of the social era have already changed the way businesses interact with their customers with every touch-point having the potential to be a global PR disaster – or triumph. They are also changing the way businesses operate with far-sighted companies moving from internal R&D to open innovation – if you want a new product, just ask. This prompted Professor Costas Markides of London Business School in his barnstorming opening keynote to proclaim that “the hierarchy is dead”. This seismic shift was borne out in the remainder of the two days. John Sumser ran a particularly insightful session on how technology will reshape and redesign the HR function. For instance, how will organisations cope with the likelihood that 15% of its employees will be wearing Google Glass to work this time next year? The good news for HR leaders struggling to cope with the sheer speed of change is that the thinking and the supporting tools and technology are there if they are prepared to embrace the revolution.

,

,

3. HR Technology is exploding with ideas

,

As Technology has continued to evolve, it has in many ways become easier to quickly establish a start-up and the conference demonstrated that the HR Technology space is exploding with ideas. Once one got beyond the sheer magnitude of the Success Factors spaceship, Oscar the Oracle robot and the other big vendors, there were some particularly interesting tools from the likes of:

,

4. Analytics could be HR’s last chance to be relevant

,

Josh Bersin provided an irrefutable case for talent analytics, suggesting that the datafication of HR will be as important for business as electrification was 100 years ago. Nick Holley was even more frank in his session entitled Talent Management - Big Data = Unsubstantiated Rubbish arguing big data in HR is not only inevitable but that it will revolutionise the function. Astonishingly, research by Holley’s Henley Business School uncovered a number of cases where HR was deliberately undermining the business case for a more data driven approach. This can partly be explained by the vast majority of HR professionals being uncomfortable with data and the fear that it will reduce their culture of intuition. Daniel Pink, in another conference keynote, argued that the two should not necessarily be exclusive and that there is room for both data and hunches – that should be a compromise that those gut instinct HR professionals should be able to live with.

,

,

5. The HR space has heroes in abundance

,

Judging by the quality of the thought leaders and speakers over the two days, HR has plenty of choice to as Jason Averbook pleaded for, identify its heroes. Who will be the HR Ali’s, Mandela’s and Einstein’s? The next few years will tell. Sumser, Holley, Markides, Bersin, Naomi Bloom, Armin Trost and William Tincup all suggested to varying degrees that they will by jockeying for position, but it was Averbook himself who stole the show. His witty, insightful and utterly compelling keynote on ‘Why We Can’t Afford To Waste Another Generation Of HR/Workforce Technology’ demonstrated that knowledge, preparation, audience participation, humour and a story are all vital ingredients in delivering a captivating conference speech. Technology with a human face.

,

,

column3: Talent Economics - HR's chance to be the hero?
column5:
[

Just occasionally a television programme, album or book comes along that is just so jaw droppingly good that it leaves you lost for words (a rare thing indeed for yours truly). The BBC’s current Hugo Blick penned and directed drama, The Honourable Woman ticks the box as far as television goes. The last great album for this writer was five years ago (perhaps a sign of my age as much as the insipidness of the modern music scene), when Yeah Yeah Yeahs went all electronic with ‘It’s Blitz’.

,

As for books, Nicholas Lovell’s formidably good ‘The Curve’ shone a new light on how businesses in the 21st century should price their products and services. But when was the last great book about HR or Talent? That would be like expecting One Direction to sing in tune, or Arsenal not to fade away miserably in February or March; or so I thought.

,

Then I came across Talent Economics by Gyan Nagpal. Just like Nessa Stein, Karen O and The Curve, this is a seminal piece of work.

,

Talent Economics brings workforce analysis, management practice and business strategy together. It uses economic inquiry as a discipline to present a refreshingly new perspective on talent management and examines the macro- and micro-economic factors that are driving the future global demand and supply of talent. Critically, it then goes further in outlining a methodology designed to enable HR leaders to diagnose, design and deliver a high impact talent strategy that is data driven and in a language that business leaders understand.

,

Last week I asked why HR and talent strategies get deprioritised when companies embark on major business transformations despite CEOs regularly citing talent as the biggest enabler (and blocker) of growth. I surmised that it may be due to HR's inability to talk the language of the business and its continuing failure to link the initiatives on which it embarks to the bottom line. Certainly, many commentators argue that HR’s failure to embrace big data and a more analytical approach is holding it back (see Is HR ready for the big data and analytics revolution?). Indeed, respected authorities like Ram Charan in a recent and much debated HBR article have even called for HR to be split or extinguished completely.

,

The ideas outlined in Talent Economics could be the great leap forward many organisations and HR leaders have been yearning for. Since reading the book, I’ve shared it with a number of progressive HR and Talent Acquisition leaders and the feedback has been overwhelmingly positive.

,

At Cielo we are fortunate to have partnered with Gyan to design a Certified Talent Economist Program (CTEP) that will equip graduates of the programme with:

,

Sound interesting? If so, please do sign up for our webinar on 26 August where Gyan will provide an introduction to Talent Economics. Alternatively, if you are reading this after the webinar, please check out our Events Page, which features a number of Talent Economics themed events. If you are a senior HR, Talent Management or Talent Acquisition leader that is interested in the CTEP program, please contact me (see below) or Amy Murray for further details.

,

It's time for HR to be the hero.

column3: How can HR & Talent drive your company's business transformation strategy?
column5:
[

For the umpteenth time, the oft quoted and much revered PwC Global CEO Survey, now in its 17th edition and unveiled amidst much grandeur each January in Davos, revealed that talent strategies are regarded by business leaders as the biggest enabler of transformative growth but also its most significant threat (see figure below).

,



,

As Thom Yorke would doubtless drone No Surprises there. However, why is it then that when a business actually begins to execute a transformation strategy does talent get pushed down the list of priorities?

,

Customer growth and retention, R&D and innovation as well as investments in technology all typically come to the fore and understandably so. But what is it that links all these together? What is it that enables growth, innovation and return on investment to flourish? And conversely what is it that stymies growth, inhibits innovation and reduces ROI? The answer of course to all three questions is the talent (or more pertinently lack of it) within the business.

,

Survey after survey and white paper after white paper documents the link between talent centricity and business performance. The more aligned and integrated talent management is with the business strategy, the greater the impact on the bottom line and the bigger the competitive advantage.

,

The difference between those who excel at talent management and those that don't is marked. As I referred to in my recent Blackadder referencing post: The War for Talent – it’s time for a new idiom, research by the Corporate Leadership Council found that the average revenue growth per annum over a 20 year period of talent centric organisations was 7.7% compared to just 0.6% for laggards. That is pretty compelling in my book and something that was echoed in our recent Cielo Talent Activation Index, which established a clear correlation between organisations that effectively aligned talent strategies to business priorities with their ability to execute on these goals.

,

The example of Google is habitually held up as the epitome of a talent centric organisation with one celebrated example being the hiring algorithm they have developed to predict which applicants will be successful at the company. Google’s detractors counter that it is easy for the technology giant to invest in talent strategies because they are operating at margins of over 60%. Whilst this at least warrants a mention in dispatches, I would counter with what came first - the fabulous business performance and seemingly unstoppable business growth or the culture of talent centricity? Maybe, just maybe it was the egg rather than the chicken on this occasion.

,

Being talent centric is just as important as being customer centric. You can't have one without the other. Customer trends and needs define and dictate the products and services a business provides. Great talent within the organisation innovates, shapes and delivers great products and experiences to its customers. One is irrelevant without the other. For organisations that get this right, the opportunity is competitive advantage through people and improved business performance.

,

So we return to the question as to why talent strategies so often get relegated to the periphery when an organisation embarks on a major transformation.

,

The answer may lie in HR's inability to talk the language of the business and the function’s continuing failure to link the initiatives on which it embarks to the bottom line. HR continues to measure the wrong things. Mr Spock would call it illogical, I call it nonsensical. For example, with regards to measuring the effectiveness of a talent acquisition initiative the time-to-hire is largely an irrelevance compared to the time-to-productivity of a new hire. Similarly, the number of open requisitions is less important than the loss of revenue arising from having posts unfilled.

,

I’ve said it before and no doubt I’ll say it again but the transformation of HR into a data-driven function is inevitable. Whilst some early-adopters have embraced it, most haven’t. Research last autumn from Bersin found that just 4% of companies have achieved the level to perform predictive talent analytics and only 14% have done any substantive statistical analysis of employee data at all.

,

It is time to stop holding back the tide. Big data is arguably HR’s last opportunity to be relevant and by grasping the bull by the horn and coupling a data driven approach to aligning and integrating talent management to the business strategy, HR can finally converse in the language of the business.

,

As the evidence mounts up on the correlation of a twin-pronged approach of customer and talent centricity is to superior business performance, then talent will stop being pushed down the list of priorities when it comes to maximising the ROI of business transformation. HR has the keys in its hands. Will they open the door to talent’s equivalent of E=mc (as soundtracked by Big Audio Dynamite)? Or will HR fumble them down the nearest drain?

,
