column3: Is HR ready for the Big Data & Analytics revolution?
column5:
[

We live in a world of Big Data, and whilst it is a subject that has been hyped more than Lady Gaga’s insipidly bad eighties retro Europop, many people believe it will change the world. Some even claim big data will be bigger than the Internet. That is as an outlandish a claim (minus the blasphemy) as the one made by the late, great John Lennon in the mid-sixties when comparing the relative size of The Beatles to Jesus Christ. But does it stack up? And what is the impact on HR and Talent Acquisition professionals?

,

To put the amount of data we generate in the world into context it is worth revisiting the staggering revelation Google CEO Eric Schmidt made in 2011:

,

“Every two days we create as much information as we did from the dawn of civilisation up until 2003”

,

Think about that for a minute. As stats go that’s up there with Donald Bradman’s Test batting average of 99.94 – surely the most remarkable sports stat as it is over 50% better than the second best average in history. Anyway, I digress…

,

Sir Martin Sorrell said last year that “the future of advertising and marketing services belongs as much to Maths Men (and women) as it does to Mad Men (and women)”. A similar trend is taking place in HR, where CIO magazine reported the function being “invaded by Data Scientists”. But is HR ready for the revolution in Talent Analytics that big data has ignited?

,

In a business world dominated by numbers, balance sheets and return on productivity. HR is increasingly isolated in its inability to talk the language of the business. McKinsey’s 2012 report on the Human Capital function – False Summit, concluded HR has an inherent inability to relate the ROI or business impact of the function. This was echoed by Josh Bersin in Forbes where he presented findings from research that suggested only 14% of organisations studied had done any significant “statistical analysis” of employee data at all.

,

The extent of this chasm between the ‘haves’ and the ‘have-nots’ is reflected in Cielo’s Talent Activation Index (download a copy here), which found that Leaders are 12 times more likely than Laggards to rate their use of data and analytics to inform workforce strategies as “very effective” (72% vs. 6%).

,

Generally speaking there is a paucity of data-driven analysis and where it does exist, it is not tied to financial measures or communicated well. The consequence is that this can prevent HR from gaining buy-in for innovation, no matter how much it is needed.

,

So, is there anything that HR can do to rectify this situation? Is this an opportunity to not only gain that long sought after seat at the table, but actually provide insightful talent analytics that have a quantifiable impact on business performance?

,

Fortunately, the answer to both questions is a resounding yes. HR actually sits on a gold mine of data, but sadly is often not using it well. This is the critical point. The answer does not lie in purchasing expensive technology solutions – a fool with a tool, is still a fool - but in simply doing a better job of applying existing data insights to critical business questions. Moreover, it needs to present the insights in a language the business understands. Chief Executives want HR data to be like financial data: standardised, specific and clearly linked to outcomes.

,

Take the following example. The HR Director of a large financial services organisation had identified it was taking an average of 55 days to hire Insurance Sales Agents. Having benchmarked his competitors and confirmed that this was too long, he called in a team of external consultants. Several workshops later the HRD signed a contract to install a new Talent Acquisition system. Twelve months on, the HRD and the partner from the consultancy firm were in the CEO’s office excitedly telling him that the $1.5m investment had reduced time to hire from 55 to 37 days. The CEO was distinctly unimpressed. “You mean it takes 37 (insert expletive) days to hire an insurance agent? Get out” he shouted as they scuttled out of the office.

,

Initially flummoxed after the unexpected hairdryer treatment, the HRD and consultant regrouped and decided to look at how they could present the data differently. A fortnight later, things duly went a lot better. “We hire 3,000 Agents per year and their average revenue per day is $700” ventured the HRD. “By reducing the average time to hire by 18 days, we estimate that we generated additional revenues of $37.8m in the last 12 months”.

,

The CEO, for once smiling and full of bonhomie, came over and slapped them both on the back and acclaimed “now that’s the kind of data I want from my HR function”. Lesson learned.

,

Whilst in part anecdotal, this story is an all too common example of one of HR’s main weaknesses. Conversely, it also provides a clear indication of the huge opportunity available if HR is prepared to do things differently. First, by adopting a scientific approach to collecting and analysing data biased towards answering critical business decisions related to talent. Then by presenting it in a language that the business understands, HR will help drive the business agenda , gain influence and have a positive and quantifiable impact on the bottom line.

,

However, as Bersin highlights and as I heard for myself when I chaired the recent HR & Workforce Analytics Summit in London (read my six key takeaways here), a growing number of HR functions have made the great leap forward and have analytics and data at the centre of their HR strategy. One notable example is provided by Patrick Coolen at ABN AMRO – read how his analytics journey has unfurled on the excellent HR Intelligence Blog.

,

HR can’t afford to continue being the laggard within the organisation when it comes to talent analytics and big data. It has a huge opportunity and now is the time to seize it.

,

,

column3: Ten Predictions for Talent Acquisition in 2014 - Half-Term report (2 of 2)
column5:
[

Marissa Mayer ponders on what HR taboo to break next...

,

Yesterday, I applied a Nostradamus rating to the first half (read Part 1 here) of the ten predictions for Talent Acquisition in 2014 I authored for Ochre Talk (now Cielo’s HR Leader Blog) back when the mince pies had yet to be added to my waistline. Today, we conclude by looking at predictions 6-10 as well as the bonus one featuring our cover star Marissa.

,

So Nostradamus or nonsense? Here goes…

,

6. Companies that don’t enhance the candidate experience, will lose candidates

,

Just as having a segmented approach to attracting and hiring will become increasingly important so will the experience candidates encounter once they are in your process. Top candidates have lots of options, so they aren’t going to spend a lot of time trying to decipher information on your organisation and how to apply. If it took 30 minutes to buy the average item on Amazon, how long do you think the company would survive? Not long. So, why do so many organisations put their candidates through purgatory by making them complete a ridiculously long application through an ATS? Is a passive candidate more likely to apply this way or with one click from their LinkedIn profile? It’s not rocket science. Nor is ensuring your site is fully optimised for mobile. People do most of their web browsing, research, and job-hunting on their phone or tablet - LinkedIn doesn’t design its new features for mobile first to try and be clever. Organisations that fail to recognise this and provide a poor candidate experience will miss out on some great hires. Nostradamus rating – 9 (out of 10): whilst there are still some shocking examples of companies serving up a dog’s dinner to candidates, the focus on candidate experience and mobile is definitely there.

,

7. The rise of referrals, boomerangs and acqui-hiring

,

Many studies conclude that effective referral programmes produce better quality of hires through high performance, good retention rates and reduced time and cost of hire as well as engaging the best talent already in the organisation. The social media revolution has enabled technology companies like Careerify and Zao to harness the networks of an organisation’s employees to make referrals easy and fun through gamification. This trend is set to continue. As will ‘boomerang’ rehiring of alumni and also perhaps the ‘acqui-hiring’ strategies popularised by the likes of Facebook, Google and most recently Yahoo. Mark Zuckerberg has boasted previously that “Facebook has not once bought a company for the company itself. We buy companies to get excellent people”. This phenomenon may extend beyond the Technology sector as merger and acquisition activity heats up. Nostradamus rating – 6: the market (at least in Europe) is still at the early adopter stage in terms of getting clever about referrals and alumni, but with Careerify now counting the likes of Deloitte amongst its customers, watch this space.

,

8. Video killed the radio star

,

With great talent getting scarcer and in higher demand, companies will need to cast the net further afield and with live video interviewing continuing to grow in acceptance, this is good news for the likes of Hire Vue, Sonru and Montage. Along with the previously mentioned Careerify and Zao, expect them to be acquisition targets for some of big HR Technology boys. Nostradamus rating – 5: Surprisingly, many organisations (or at least the ones I speak to) are suspicious when it comes to embracing video, although a growing number of our US customers have adopted video particularly for sales roles.

,

9. Co-sourcing – a middle ground between RPO and in-house

,

A more segmented and agile approach requires a more flexible and capable service and that means that organisations will increasingly implement a third way to the traditional ‘eggs in one basket’ wholly outsourced or fully in-house options. The ‘Third Way’ is not some dodgy leftover of New Labour but a different perspective to outsourcing whereby an organisation transfers in expertise from a third party to work alongside its in-house team. This partnership model could for example involve each party having responsibility for certain segments within the ‘Talented Many’, ‘Skilled Few’ and ‘Expert One’ segments of an organisation’s workforce I outlined yesterday. This is a model that Cielo has pioneered with a number of customers where we deliver a ‘hybrid’ solution – neither fully outsourced nor fully in-house. As more agile talent acquisition strategies are required expect this marriage of the best of both worlds to become the norm rather than the exception. Nostradamus rating – 9: The growth in co-sourcing is rapid particularly in certain industry sectors and certainly in Europe. This requires a more agile and collaborative approach from RPOs – it will be interesting to see how many can step up to the level we have already attained at Cielo

,

10. A challenger emerges to rival LinkedIn

,

Admittedly more of a wish than a prediction, not that one has anything against LinkedIn just to be clear. It’s just that with the social media company becoming ever more dominant it may only be a matter of time before megalomania or hubris sets in and neither would be good for recruiters, candidates or indeed LinkedIn itself. So come on, are there any challengers out there? Nostradamus rating – 1: For now this falls into the nonsense category, particularly given LinkedIn's latest quarterly results, which are exceptional. This analysis by Josh Bersin of Workday’s acquisition of Identified makes for interesting reading

,

And the bonus prediction…

,

11. Marissa Mayer breaks (at least) one more HR taboo

,

Ok, this one is not strictly limited to talent acquisition, but after sending the HR doves into hysteria with her cull on remote working and introduction of the stacked curve for ranking employees, it can only be a matter of time (maybe hours) before Yahoo’s publicity shy (I jest) CEO breaks another taboo. When it does happen expect an avalanche of criticism and the odd smidgen of praise. Nostradamus rating – 0: Marissa has been remarkably quiet on this front, but still has five months to get the HR doves in full throwing toys out of pram mode.

,

So overall, not bad considering some of the predictions bordered on blind optimism. Let’s see if we can get the talent acquisition revolution in full swing in time for Santa’s annual road-trip.

,

,

David is a Director at Cielo (formerly known as Pinstripe & Ochre House) and has worked with a number of organisations to design talent acquisition and talent management programmes that drive growth and competitive advantage. You can contact David by email,LinkedIn or Twitter.

column3: Ten predictions for Talent Acquisition in 2014 – Half-Term report: (1 of 2)
column5:
[

Back when the days were short and Santa was readying his reindeer, I wrote a two-part piece for Ochre Talk on ten predictions for Talent Acquisition in 2014. With over half the year gone, now seems a good time to revisit those predictions and see whether they were Nostradamus or nonsense.

,

The first part is presented today with each prediction followed by the judgement. Part 2 (Trends 6 to 10) can be read here.

,

#1 The economy improves; the War for Talent intensifies

,

It’s been a tumultuous journey since the crash of 2008, but the signs are that the patient is back on her feet and entering recovery mode. But what is good news for the economy, presents a real challenge for Talent Acquisition departments. Premium talent that has retrenched in the last few years will either be actively looking for the next career move or will be susceptible to an approach. The War for Talent (isn’t it time for a new idiom?) is set to intensify and organisations with antiquated, homogeneous resourcing models solely dependent on active candidate pools will find they are not fit for purpose. As companies hemorrhage talent or lose out on fresh blood to their competitors, the C-Level will start asking questions of their Directors of HR and Talent Acquisition, but will they be able to answer them? Nostradamus rating (out of 10) – 7: The heat is on (as Glenn Frey once sang) but there’s still room for it to get much hotter; and it will...

,

2. Talent Economics – the keys to the kingdom

,

In simple terms, Talent Economics means recognising that to prosper in the intensifying War for Talent (oh dear, that idiom again), organisations will need to segment and personalise their approach to acquiring and engaging talent. It takes less effort, sophistication and cost to fill some roles than others, but many organisations – irrespective of whether they have an in-house or RPO model – apply the same approach across the board. ‘One size fits all’ models simply will not work anymore. They are inefficient in that too much cost and/or effort is applied to some roles and not enough to others. Just as Nicholas Lovell’s excellent book ‘The Curve’ explains that the future of business is about variation: tailoring products for customers of all stripes; so organisations will need to vary their approach to engaging with and hiring different segments of talent. We recognised this some time ago at Cielo and refer to these segments as ‘Talented Many’, 'Skilled Few’ and ‘Expert One’ (see figure above). Interested? Get in touch to find out more. Nostradamus rating – 8: Excusing the shameless promotion (apologies for that), we are seeing a marked increase in organisations taking a more intelligent segmented approach to how they hire.

,

3. Employer Brand goes into orbit

,

Most organisations get how important their consumer brand is but neglect to give equal focus to their employer brand. Of course they are equally important especially when you consider that great products and services (and by linkage customers) need great talent to shape, design and deliver them. You can’t have one without the other and when that talent is scarce and in high demand, the messages and communication strategies used to spark potential candidate interest is paramount. Similarly, just as a varied hiring strategy is integral for the ‘Talented Many’, ‘Skilled Few’ and ‘Expert One’, so a personalised and nuanced employer brand that resonates with different target groups is compulsory. Cielo is unique in the global RPO space by having its own in-house full service brand practice. Research from Lippincott and LinkedIn found companies with strong consumer and employer brands financially outperform their peers by 36%. So it is perhaps not surprising that Andy Curlewis, who heads up our Global Brand, Digital and Comms practice, has been rushed off his feet in 2013. As employer brand goes into orbit , I expect that his feet won’t even touch the floor in 2014. Serves him right for being a Gooner! Nostradamus rating – 8: I’m pleased to write that Andy has been busier than Arsenal keeper Wojciech Szczęsny at Anfield back in February this year. What was the score again, Andy?

,

4. Focus on metrics shifts to outcomes not cost of hire

,

Five years of relentless cost-cutting since the onset of the financial crisis with regards to how most organisations hire will reach a tipping point in 2014. For too long there has been an obsession with cost per hire metrics and when this becomes the only objective this is counterproductive. Sadly, this is a game we see too many in-house functions and RPO providers willing to play. There aren’t many decisions more important to a business than determining who it hires. A cheap approach that leads to poor hires is one of the worst decisions a business can make given all the possible costs associated with making a poor hire and the benefits of snaring the right talent. As this realisation dawns (and a buoyant economy will only exacerbate this), organisations will need to shift emphasis to data on outcomes of hiring over costs of hiring and demand this from in-house functions and external partners alike. Nostradamus rating – 4: Sadly whilst all of this is true, cost still holds sway over agility, quality and outcomes. This revolution is taking longer than envisaged, but we are on to the nickel and diming RPOs. Talking about data...

,

5. It’s all about the data, baby

,

2014 will be the year that HR stops talking about (or even avoiding) big data and embraces it wholesale like its cousins in Finance and Marketing; not necessarily to replace traditional HR intuition but to validate it. As recruiting converges ever closer with marketing (see Employer Brand trend above), it is only natural that the tools and techniques utilised to target potential consumers will be tailored to target desirable talent audiences. Moreover, predictive analytics that will enable talent acquisition functions to gain visibility on future requirements and the probability of success for potential new hires will mean that they will be able to make the kinds of decisions that will set them and their organisations up for long-term success. Nostradamus rating – 2: Hmm it seems my cup of optimism overfloweth (too much eggnog in the run-up to Christmas?). HR is still strangely resistant to embracing big data and especially predictive analytics. This one might have to wait until 2020.

,

Half-term report on predictions 6-10 follow tomorrow…

,

column3: Getting funky with HR Analytics - an HR Director's Tale (Part 2)
column5:
[

Our intrepid HRD's attempt to disguise his likeness to the hapless David Moyes backfired badly...

,

Last time (read Part 1 here) our intrepid HR Director had been given a volley of abuse from his CEO and told in no uncertain terms that he needed to come up with a HR Analytics strategy quick smart. Being a resilient sort of chap, the HRD had swiftly dusted himself down and formulated a plan to get to grips with a subject he knew little about and had previously assumed to be the preserve of the Finance and Marketing departments.

,

So will the HRD flounder or flourish at this unexpected opportunity to get HR on the top-table? Will he get funky on the HR Analytics dancefloor or will his attempt to get data on the HR agenda prove as embarrassing as Boris and Dave’s Dad dancing at the 2012 Olympics?

,

Well it’s been a couple of months and our HRD has been busy…

,

,

Don't call me baby Moyes...

,

Whilst he resented his CEO for the arduous task that had been imposed upon him, it had dawned on the HRD that Dear Leader was correct (for the first time actually when it came to HR) in that the HRD needed to get his act together and fast. His colleagues had taken to calling him ‘Moyes’ and he knew if he didn’t get it right the knives would be out just as they had been for Alex Ferguson’s hapless successor at Manchester United.

,

,

That chap Bersin

,

As revealed in Part 1, the HRD had immersed himself in HR Analytics books, white papers, blogs and on-line discussion groups as well as partaking in one of his favourite activities – hobnobbing at conferences. At one of these he’d met a chap called Bersin who had introduced him to his four-stage HR Analytics maturity model outlining how organisations evolve from highly scalable reporting systems to advanced analytics. Whilst this had been helpful, the HRD conceded that they might have to invent a Stage Zero for his company.

,

,

The mythical beasts of HR Analytics

,

His plan had started to form when he attended the HR & Workforce Analytics Innovation Summit in London. At first he had thought he must be in the wrong place. A significant proportion of the delegates had not spent their whole careers in HR - the horror. He had been stunned to learn that Shell’s HR Analytics team comprised a statistician and a clever chap with two Economics degrees. The HRD felt like a bit of a dinosaur but had quickly realised that he didn’t need to (and probably couldn’t) do it all himself and would actually progress quicker if he could get a boffin or two in.

,

He had heard that genuine HR Analytics expertise was hard to come by but here he was in a room full of legions of the mythical beasts. He collected a plethora of business cards – no expense would be spared to get the right expertise in. The HRD also resolved to sniff around the Finance department for any nascent talent. He now understood that he needed someone who could make sense of and create compelling stories and insight from the myriad of data that existed in the nether regions of his HR systems.

,

,

A twin-pronged attack

,

At the summit he liked what he had heard from Vanessa Varney of Coca-Cola Enterprises. Their journey seemed to be a prime example of building your HR Analytics house from the bottom up – à la what that chap Bersin had been banging on about in his four stage model.

,

Given the notorious impatience of his CEO he was excited at what Patrick Coolen of ABN AMRO had told him over lunch. They had adopted a two-speed approach to scaling their analytics mountain by getting the operational reporting right in parallel with experimenting with some predictive analytics. The HRD knew it was the latter the CEO was demanding – “stop reporting and start predicting” the HRD had been harangued with in the staff canteen the other day. If he could dress it up with a big dollar saving sign hanging over it all the better. This would enable the HRD to be more van Gaal than Moyes.

,

,

Start with the business problem

,

Being about as numerate as his pet poodle, the HRD had been relieved to hear that not a single person he spoke to about HR Analytics had suggested that you should start with the data. Instead, the advice he continually received was that you needed to begin with the business problem. This was not only easier, but was something where he could actually contribute. For example, his recruitment function was in a bit of a mess – agency hiring had historically been too prevalent (partly due to the HRD’s reluctance to say no to a boozy lunch) and as such hiring costs were too high, time to productivity of new hires was off the scale and attrition levels continued to be a bone of contention.

,

The HRD reasoned that getting his talent acquisition function ship-shape would be a good place to start and if he could use data to diagnose the problems and help drive the solutions, all the better. He booked a meeting with his Head of Recruitment for the following afternoon. His HR Analytics journey was beginning to get funkier by the minute. Tune in next time for Part 3 to see how he gets on with presenting his plan to the CEO.

,

column3: The War for Talent - after 17 years is it time for a new idiom?
column5:
[

,

,

,

,

,

Captain Blackadder was prepared to go to extreme measures to banish forever mention of the Great War for Talent. Wibble...

,

To echo Bloc Party’s career high business is in a continual ‘state of flux’ as we transition from the certainties and rigidity of the organisational age to a climate that is increasingly more unpredictable, complex, collaborative, knowledge-based and global.

,

Back in 1997, when Kele and the rest of Bloc Party were still in short trousers, Manchester United had a decent football team (yes, it really was that long ago) and yours truly started his HR and recruitment career. It was also the year that McKinsey coined the term ‘The war for talent’ to describe the increasingly competitive landscape for recruiting and retaining talented employees.

,

It was a term that resonated widely and one that has been used ad verbatim ever since, but 17 years on isn’t the phrase becoming a little tiresome? If there was a war (and as far as I know no shots have actually been fired), then it is over; talent has won.

,

In any case, ‘war’ has negative connotations for most people – especially those caught in the crossfire – and an effective talent management strategy should rather accentuate the positive. Moreover, given in 2014 we are commemorating the 100 year anniversary of World War I – supposedly the war to end all wars – maybe it is time to call a ceasefire on the war for talent.

,

Staying with The Great War for the moment, Blackadder Goes Forth (despite what Education Secretary Michael Gove believes) was a stark and satirical take on life in the trenches. If Lieutenant George and Captain Blackadder were sharing a cup of hot mud courtesy of batman Private Baldrick, the unlikely triumvirate would doubtless stress the need for a “cunning plan”.

,

Whilst this plan may not be "as cunning as a fox who's just been appointed Professor of Cunning at Oxford University", it does allow for a negative to be turned into a positive. Organisations should cast aside the khakis and instead focus on delivering excellence in talent management.

,

Indeed, organisations that excel at talent management dramatically outperform their peers. Research from the Corporate Leadership Council indicates that the average annual growth rate over a 20 year period for organisations that lead the way in talent management is 7.7% compared to just 0.6% for the laggards. As business becomes more complex, knowledge based and collaborative this gap is only likely to grow.

,

So what are the foundations of excelling at talent management? Whilst not exhaustive – this is a blog post not a thesis - the pointers below should prove a good basis from which to start:

,

Get all this right and your organisation should be well-placed to recruit, retain, develop and reward employees in a way that supports their business objectives. Sounds easy? Of course it isn’t even for the likes of Google, but it sure beats going over the top and venturing into no-mans land brandishing a bayonet.

column3: Six takeways from the HR Analytics Innovation Summit
column5:
[

iNostix's 'Evolving from Tracking to Predictive HR Analytics' model

,

I recently had the honour of chairing the HR & Workforce Analytics Innovation Summit in London. There were c150 delegates in attendance and speakers from the likes of Shell, Unilever and Coca-Cola Enterprises. What made the summit such a pleasure to chair was that rather than the usual blend of vendors and industry experts, the floor was very much reserved for HR Analytics leaders themselves to outline their personal HR Analytics journeys. As opening speaker James Rule of Thomson Reuters remarked this enabled some “positive deviancy” to infiltrate proceedings.

,

Here are my key takeaways from what was a very productive two days:

,

#1 – Start with the business challenge, not the data

,

There was universal agreement that unless the work of the HR Analytics team is aligned to a specific business challenge or strategy, then the data needn't be analysed or measured. Effective HR Analytics should not be about HR falling into the common trap of creating data that is inward looking, but should be tied to the function’s impact on the business. Indeed, as James Stringer of Unilever succinctly answered his own question on how to get the C-Suite interested in HR Analytics – you put a monetary value on it.

,

,

#2 Quite a lot of people in HR Analytics don’t have an HR background

,

Many of the delegates were not HR careerists. For example, the team describing the impressive HR Analytics journey at Shell included a statistician and a chap with two Economics degrees. Neither had previously worked in HR. This prompted quite a contretemps in a lively panel debate on whether a background in HR was required to interpret the implications of the data. It would seem that a blend of the two is sensible with the mix depending on the stage of the journey each organisation is on. HR may be a dark art, but it is positively bright compared to the intricacies of data science.

,

,

#3 Strategic Workforce Planning (SWP) and HR Analytics make ideal bedfellows

,

The general consensus was that these two areas are intrinsically linked. Patrick Coolen of ABN AMRO provided the perfect justification explaining that i) Analytics can help prove or disprove theories thus providing real value at the outset of SWP and ii) SWP is a more natural way for HR to engage with the business about their needs. We heard a number of examples as to how Strategic Workforce Planning and HR Analytics had provided clear business benefit. One speaker from a FTSE250 organisation explained how she had implemented a People Strategy hand-in-hand with the Business Strategy over the course of a three year business transformation. This has enabled the business to now fill 50% of hires internally, reduce annual recruitment spend by £1m and help shift Employee Engagement upwards by 16%. The results from a business perspective are even more impressive as the organisation has more than trebled its market capitalisation, achieved a two-and-a-half fold increase in its share price and is on the verge of entering the FTSE100. These are the types of figures guaranteed to get the C-Level giddy with excitement about HR.

,

,

#4 Everyone’s HR Analytics journey is different

,

If one was to read analyst reports by the likes of Bersin, an HR leader seeking to embark on an HR Analytics voyage would likely deduce that the journey was a) likely to be long, and b) should follow a tried and tested progressive path of getting the basics right before considering the Holy Grail of predictive analytics. Whilst this appeared to be the journey undertaken by most of the organisations present there is no hard and fast rule. One financial services organisation for example, has adopted a dual approach through outsourcing reporting to a third party whilst in parallel embarking on predictive analytics with another partner.

,

,

#5 Predictive HR Analytics is a relatively immature concept

,

Whilst the general consensus was that predictive HR Analytics is still a relatively immature phenomenon – perhaps for the reasons illustrated in the graphic prefacing this post - a number of the delegates present concurred that their companies had started on the road to something that is guaranteed to get attention at C-Level. As one speaker sagely observed the weather forecast is predictive analytics. HR though still lags behind their cousins in Finance and Marketing in Predictive Analytics with Luk Smeyers of iNostix and author of the excellent HR Intelligence Blog observing that HR is 5-10 years behind. This is an area where there is still much work to do.

,

,

#6 The future for HR Analytics is exciting

,

Judging by the calibre of the people relaying their HR Analytics journeys and the keen interest with which delegates from other prestigious organisations lapped it up, HR Analytics is set to explode. Indeed, when you consider the relative success of the organisations present to their peers within their respective industries, one could surmise that there is a positive correlation between the relative maturity of the HR Analytics function and the performance of the business. This is certainly borne out in one of the key findings to emerge from Cielo's recent Talent Activation Index, which revealed a direct link between talent metrics and business success. The survey reports that respondents from high performing businesses are nine times (43% vs 5%) more likely to use sophisticated metrics to measure the quality of their workforce than low performing organisations. Data like this means that the future for HR Analytics is an exciting one.

,

,

column3: Getting started with HR Analytics: An HR Director's Tale - Part 1
column5:
[


,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

Our HRD plans to resort to James Bond style tactics to crack HR Analytics in his business

,

Picture the scene. The chastened HR Director stumbles out of the CEO’s office having received an almighty rollicking. The CEO had just got back from a few days of hobnobbing with his peers and he was furious. The reason for his ire was the fact that he was so damn impressed with the HR Analytics the likes of GE had. He had heard how they had used this data to directly inform business strategy and that the positive impacts on business performance and bottom line had been marked.

,

Never one to be made to feel behind the curve in any way to his peers, the CEO wanted HR Analytics and he wanted it now. He’d given it to the HRD with both barrels and as the shellshocked recipient reflected, the CEO’s hairdryer treatment made Alex Ferguson’s look like a mere breeze in comparison. He now had a month to compile a plan on something he’d previously regarded as a mere fad – “Data in HR? What’s wrong with intuition?” the HRD muttered to himself.

,

Where was he going to start? Remembering that the CEO had blasted that “big data was the last chance for the HR function to be relevant in the business”, he resolved that he’d better begin at the start.

,

,

Read some books

,

First thing’s first the HRD thought, was to get on-line and download some reading material onto his Kindle. He was surprised at the number of books there were on HR Analytics and immediately felt a bit foolish. He really was a bit out of touch he had to admit to himself. He bought three books: HR Analytics: The What, Why and How by Tracey Smith, Keeping Up With The Quants by Thomas Davenport and People Analytics by Ben Waber.

,

,

Join some LinkedIn Groups

,

Having mentioned the predicament to his Generation Y daughter, the HRD had been advised to join a couple of LinkedIn groups focused on HR Analytics. After much searching and a couple of additional calls to his daughter to help him navigate his way around LinkedIn he found what seemed to be two excellent groups: People Analytics: Data Driven HR and what would become as time wore on a very familiar hang out for the HRD – Measuring Human Capital.

,

,

Sign up to some HR Analytics blogs

,

His daughter also advised the HRD to seek out and subscribe to some specialist blogs on HR Analytics. The HRD was flabbergasted at how many blogs they were. Some chap called Bersin was particularly ubiquitous so along with his The Business of HR, the HRD subscribed to the excellent HR Intelligence Blog and All About Human Capital.

,

,

Start utilising his Forbes and HBR subscriptions

,

Last time the CEO went to Davos he came back and eulogised to the extended leadership team (the HRD wasn’t on the ACTUAL leadership team although he was beginning to think he might if he could crack this HR Analytics gig) about how they should all read the likes of Forbes, The Economist and Harvard Business Review. The HRD had wondered if this was really relevant to him preferring to occasionally browse the odd HR publication alongside his Harry Potter obsession but had signed up to the company paid subscriptions in any case. Now he was visibly shocked at the treasure trove of information he had had access to all along. It was going to take a month to read it all!

,

,

Go to a conference and network

,

Being in HR, the HRD liked nothing better than going to a conference and networking with his peers. He wondered whether there were any conferences coming up where HR Analytics was one of the key themes. He was surprised to see that there were 14 HR Analytics conferences in 2014 alone and asked his PA to sign him up to a couple straight away.

,

,

Get all James Bond with Google

,

The HRD didn’t know much about HR Analytics (although he was already quickly beginning to learn) but he did have a nephew who worked at Google and he knew that when it came to HR Analytics, Google was the daddy. Indeed, his nephew had sent him an article that had appeared in The Atlantic entitled How Google Uses Data To Build A Better Worker. He put in a call to see if his nephew could fix him up with a meeting with someone from Google’s People Analytics Department. He chuckled to himself, he would be like James Bond infiltrating Spectre except he would be going undercover at Google.

,

,

This should give him the basics, the HRD thought. At least he’d know what HR Analytics actually was after all of this. Read Part 2 in a week or so to see how he gets on...

,

,

All characters appearing in this work are entirely fictitious. Any resemblance to real persons, living or dead, is purely coincidental... though perhaps not a surprise.

,

David is Director of Business Development for Cielo (formerly known as Pinstripe & Ochre House) in Europe. Please feel free to connect on LinkedIn or follow him on Twitter @david_green_uk

]
